item.title: Visitors from NY seeking WVO
item.dc:creator: RegenCSA
item.content:encoded:
Hi folks,

We are a couple of farmers and permaculturalists travelling thru Seattle, and looking for some WVO.  It definitely seems a pretty tight area for WVO here, but we are hoping perhaps someone has a private stash with some surplus?

We would be happy to exchange whatever we have to share, or work something out. Of course if anyone is thinking of travelling to the NY area anytime in the future, we have plenty of WVO to share out there!

thanks much,  any help much appreciated

our website:  www.regenerationcsa.org

our cell here in seattle: 845 264 2401

we hope to get on the road by this weekend. Our planting season is calling us.

item.title: Punk Rock Flea Market
item.dc:creator: prfleamarket
item.content:encoded:
It's on!
Punk Rock Flea Market returns to the Underground Events Center this summer! On June 6th, from 10:00 in the morning until 10:00 at night, the Punk Rock Flea will rock your world and fill the trunk of your car! The Underground is at 2407 1st Ave. in Belltown, Seattle. For those of you keeping track, this is PRFM #6!
This is a full on flea market selling everything you can imagine, including records, clothing, furniture, computers, stereo equipment, housewares, haircuts, toys, videos, bicycles, tacos, falafels, vegan treats, skateboards, political propaganda, information from non profit groups, books, art, bike repair, baby stuff, tarot readings & whatever else we can fit into the space. Don't let the name lead you to believe that we only welcome vendors selling punk records, clothes etc. The "Punk Rock" of the name refers as much to the DIY spirit of the event as it does to any particular music or lifestyle. 'Nuff said.
Since it's the height of summer, we're gonna use the outside parking lot in addition to the Underground inside, so we've got 80 spaces for rent. The first 80 forms to come back with $25 will get those spaces. No exceptions. We have a few tables available, but if possible, bring your own. You should also plan to bring all of your own lighting and display equipment. Space at the PRFM always sells out, so I recommend reserving a space sooner rather than later. Send me an email to get the form – PRFleamarket@gmail.com. If you've done this before and know the drill it's okay to just send your check and vendor info.
As always, the market opens to the public at 10:00 am and bands will begin to play at around 6:00 pm. Vendors are welcome to stay for the entire event, but it isn't required. The 6:00 transition will be a natural moment for tired vendors to close up shop.
Once again, the space we are using has been generously loaned to us for the day by the Low Income Housing Institute, aka. LIHI. LIHI is a non-profit organization that builds homes for homeless and low-income people all around the Puget Sound. Your table fees and entry donations go toward paying insurance and advertising costs for this event. Once those expenses are covered, all additional proceeds will go to LIHI. You are most welcome to make additional donations to LIHI if you feel so inclined. More info about them at www.lihi.org.
The PRFM is put on by volunteers and amateurs, so you can help make it work by communicating your needs and by letting us know if we're missing something important. We want this event to be successful, and we want to do it again!
To reserve a space or ask questions contact producer Joshua Okrent at PRFleamarket@gmail.com or (206) 957-8076. More info at http://www.myspace.com/punkrock_fleamarket.

item.title: Last ditch effort:
item.dc:creator: TheBikeShack
item.category: Seattle bike shack repair community shop volunteer
Seattle bike shack repair community shop volunteer
item.content:encoded: Hey all you bikey DIYers. The Bike Shack has been hoping to have its annual brew fest this March 14th (Pi day!) but while we have several brewers, we're still short on brew. More importantly, we're missing a venue! We're still hoping to do a brewfest as it brings in the vast majority of our rent (and due to the recent burglary, tool replacement) for the year. Please let us know if you would like to donate a brew (you are compensated for ingredient cost) or know of a location which is willing/able to host the brew fest. It generally pulls in 100-150 people and serves 40 gallons or so of brews. If we can't get something together the 14th, there's still time to reschedule, but we have rent for sure out to the end of July assuming we don't replace our tools (at least $150 wholesale) or any of our supplies (of which the Spring season will quickly wipe out many of them.) Again, if you've never used us, the Bike Shack is a volunteer-run community bike shop dedicated to facilitating personal bike repair in allowing tool use, donated parts, and teaching hands-on bicycle repair. We're always in need of new volunteers. Come during any of the hours posted on BikeShack.org [particularly 4-7 Thursdays, the only ones I guarantee!] and come check us out! Behind the Wayward Cafe on the corner of 9th and 55th NE in the U-District/Ravenna.

item.title: housemate wanted!
item.dc:creator: yeahrachel
item.content:encoded: HouseMate Wanted! New Crompton (4711 12th Ave NE, in the U-District) is looking for a fourth roomie, to move in on April 1st! A collection of musicians/book readers/video game dominators/bike ride adventure-having folks, seeking someone that doesn't mind band practice (Blanket Truth/Iji share a practice space in the house), talking about twee pop, and having cute shows in the living room, to be followed by bubble tea and basketball. Necessary talk: Rent is due on the 1st: $515 a month (currently cheaper ($435) while there is a temporary fourth roommate) No deposit required, last months rent is paid! The lease is up at the end of July No pets Free Cable Wifi ready Super close to Trader Joe's, Safeway, Whole Foods, numerous bus lines, city parks (Ravenna, Gas Works), sweet dumpsters, UW, and abounding rad cafes and restaurants. Plenty of storage space and not to forget the sweet primary colors in the living room. SO If this sounds good, and you have questions/want to move in/check out the space, please contact: Rachel Frances at frommyhandlebars@gmail.com

item.title: Roommate sought for 3br house in July
item.dc:creator: crstopher
item.content:encoded:
Hey SDIYers,

We're seeking a roommate for a 3br Wallingford house, starting on July 1st. Rent is $475/month plus utilities, with first/last/security deposit as well as a $35 credit check required by our landlord. The house is a block from Greenlake and close to bus routes, and in addition to your personal room there is a small shared office/studio space.

Our ideal roommate is a student/artist/whatever who is creative, clean, and responsible. We're a low-key couple who're looking for a roommate who doesn't come with any drama or pets. My girlfriend is an architecture student, and I work at a teen center on the Eastside.

We're omnivores but have no problem w/ Vegans/Veggies and aren't obsessed w/ meat or anything.

item.title: West Coast Bicycle Music Tour! Needs show in Seattle.....
item.dc:creator: jamesmiska
item.content:encoded:
Hey everyone, my name is James Miska, and I play acoustic music on a bunch of different instruments with a lot of singing involved. My friend Chaz Prymek and I are starting a tour in Vancouver, BC in July, and going down the whole west coast from there, all the way to San Diego. Can anyone here help us out in possibly booking a show, of any sort, preferably a house or something, in Seattle? We're low maintenance, I promise!

We'll be there July 10th or 11th!

Ok, thanks everyone who looks at this! Talk to you soon!

Is there a group or a regular meet up. I would like to find community and I'm interested in volunteering or helping out wherever needed. Please help!

item.title: anti-authoritarian communal space -- fundraiser and cash
item.dc:creator: bartek
item.content:encoded:
i'm new park to get some money together. and i myself have no other point in life but to work to fund suto posting here, but i've been in the community some time. i've been working with food not bombs @ cascade, the occidental park branch. there are key members on that side of the fence who are determined to get a communal space open to all, lacking any heirarchy.  i as well. we have planned a fundraiser for august @ volunteer ch a center. i just stumbled onto the seattleDIY efforts to bring one into existence. long story short, i actually have some money to invest, and will work three jobs if necessary to get a place together. we had an idea for a "peace and justic center" to try and get non-profit status with gov grants... anyone paying attention, please drop me a line @ ryanbartek@hotmail.com or visit me @ www.myspace.com/ryanbartek

thanks

RBT

item.title: The Office of Dr Glorious-gem of the Central District-Seeks a new roommate $310
item.dc:creator: amrewhitt
item.content:encoded:
The Office of Dr Glorious is looking for a lovely new roommate! We are a Central District house with four bedrooms, typically housing four people. The room you would be living in is a large forest green dwelling with high ceilings and three windows. We have a basement space suitable for musical projects, art projects and anything else you think you may want to use it for. We have some quiet house shows from time to time as well. The three roommates that are staying are in their mid twenties and early thirties and all work with children. All you really need in order to fit in here is the ability to wash a few dishes now and then and generally be a friendly, open, un-turdlike human. Ideally looking for a female-ish person to take the room in order to keep things balanced but any and all who apply will be considered. As noted in the title this room is available anywhere between the 1st and 15th of August, utilities are not included in the rent price but tend to stay low, usually the put the rent for the place up to a whopping $360 a month.
Please call or email to set up a time to view the room, and meet and greet the roommates.
Best Wishes,
Amanda
360 888 9514

item.title: Casa Luna Seeking Housemates
item.dc:creator: plastic.goldfish
item.content:encoded:
The members of Casa Luna are searching for a new housemate and co-op member, and have an opening now. Casa Luna is an artists' cooperative house, organized by creative and unique individuals. We seek a person who will be excited to participate in the not so mundane daily goings-ons here at Luna, and have a life of their own that can be enhanced by involvement in a supportive home.
Please contact us if you're interested in the following:
Cooking and enjoying vegetarian, 'freegan' and vegan meals Taking long bike rides around the city and surroundings Creating art, music, and performance Shedding layers of pre-established behavioral conditioning Sharing duties of cleaning and organizing Gardening, reading in the hammock, building campfires Dumpster diving for fun and profit
We have twice-monthly house meetings, and a regular monthly potluck for our friends and extended community. Occasional parties too, with music, food, and not a small amount of revelry!
For rent is a downstairs, daylight basement room with a large window and modest closet. As much as we love kids and animals, we are not looking for any at this time. Two fabulous cats currently reside here, and though our house is kid friendly for short visits, we generally cultivate a more adult environment.
We are excited to meet somebody who is interested in taking a part in our community -- If you're a busy student or professional -- and you're still reading -- this might not be the best place for you to focus -- there's usually something fun and distracting going on at the casa. That said, we're also uninterested in substance abuse and anti-intellectualism... but we'll talk.
If you're interested, please respond to this ad with brief responses to the following questions: -Hi! Who are you? -What kind of place do you actually want to live in? -What might you contribute? -How long do you plan on sticking around when you find a home? And of course, anything else you'd like for us to know.
Moving in requires a payment of first and last months rent + a 200 dollar deposit (150 of which is refundable), and co-op dues (currently $50, which covers bills, lightbulbs, cooking oil, etc) We can be flexible on the move-in sum for the right candidate- so be sure to let us know how serious your interest is. Write to us if this is clearly someplace you ought to check out.
Thanks for reading! Casa Luna <!-- START CLTAGS -->

Hey guys, I moved Seattle earlier this year and live at a house in the U-District that has done some random shows every now and again, and with summer rolling around we are going to try and throw more, starting now!

Come check out a sweet pop punk band from Arizona, Rumspringer, and some Seattle locals, Smokejumper (ex dateless) and The Damage Done.

super fun latterman-y/jawbreakerish stuff!!

item.title: Holocaust-denial event in Seattle, July 18
item.dc:creator: Rose City Antifa
item.content:encoded:
David Irving’s Holocaust-Denial Speaking Tour: The Show that Must Not Go On

This July, David Irving, a British neo-fascist and fraudulent historian, goes on the road in the United States, planning to hold approximately one and a half dozen speaking engagements over the course of a month. As militant anti-racists and anti-fascists, we are making a public call for resistance at each stop along the way of this tour.  

Who is David Irving?

David Irving is a British writer of histories who has been involved with the fascist political scene since the 1960s. Always known for the pro-Hitler bias of his books, approximately two decades ago Irving made the transition to being a fully-fledged Holocaust-denier, when he testified at the trial of neo-Nazi Ernst Zündel in Canada, and also arranged the publication of Fred Leuchter’s widely-refuted report on gas chambers at Auschwitz. In addition to spreading blatant historical lies, Irving has publicly stated that “The Jews are the architects of their own misfortune”. Unsurprisingly, Irving has been an extremely popular speaker at neo-Nazi rallies in Germany.     

In the British libel case Irving v. Penguin Books and Lipstadt, the final ruling in favor of the defendants confirmed that Irving “is an active Holocaust denier” and that “he is anti-Semitic and racist and that he associates with right-wing extremists who promote neo-Nazism.” In 2006, Irving was jailed in Austria after pleading guilty to a charge of “trivializing the Holocaust”, which is a crime in that county. Since his release, Irving has been marketing himself as a former “political prisoner”.

Why Oppose These Events?

Irving’s current tour focuses on “"Re-writing history, using the decoded Nazi messages" (see: http://www. focal. org/speaks/index.html). The re-writing of Third Reich history—especially in relation to the Nazi “Final Solution” for Europe’s Jewish population—is a major preoccupation for modern neo-Nazis and neo-fascists, who correctly believe that memory of the Holocaust is a significant barrier to the mainstreaming of their beliefs. The Holocaust is denied so that, paradoxically, it can be repeated. Wherever Irving appears, he is backed and promoted by virulent anti-Semites and fascist organizers.

Irving’s bogus history is both blatantly offensive and incorrect. However, we oppose Irving not for what he thinks, but rather for what he does. As the name of his own publishing project suggests, Irving serves as a “focal point” to bring Jew-haters and goose-steppers together. He is part of a political tendency that is actively organizing for ethnic and racial hostilities, and in particular to persecute Jewish people. (James von Brunn’s murder of a security guard at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum is one recent example of where this anti-Semitic and neo-Nazi tendency can lead. Von Brunn moved within many of the same circles that promote Irving’s work.)

We believe that fascist activism and movement-building should meet with organized resistance. As the Anti-Racist Action Network states in its Points of Unity:

“Whenever fascists are organizing or active in public, we're there. We don't believe in ignoring them or staying away from them. Never let the nazis have the street!”

We invite you to help this effort along, by organizing in your own community.

When and Where?

At present, the dates for Irving’s speaking tour are as follows:

July 3 Friday: Kansas City, 19:00

July 6 Monday: Oklahoma City, 19:00           

July 8 Wednesday: Albuquerque, 19:00            

July 10 Friday: Phoenix, 19:00           

July 12 Sunday: Las Vegas, buffet, 19:00            

July 13 Monday: Salt Lake City, buffet, 19:00            

July 15 Wednesday: Boise, buffet, 19:00         

July 16 Thursday: Spokane, buffet, 19:00     

July 18 Saturday: Seattle 15:00       

July 19 Sunday: Portland, OR, buffet, 15:00          

July 22 Wednesday: Sacramento, buffet,18:30           

July 23 Thursday: San Francisco, buffet 18:30            

July 25 Saturday: Costa Mesa, 18:30          

July 26 Sunday: Sherman Oaks, 15:00            

July 29 Wednesday: Denver, 19:00           

July 30 Thursday: Omaha, 19:00           

July 31 Friday: Chicago incl. de luxe dinner, 19:00        

The exact location of Irving’s talk in each city has not been made public, due to Irving’s fear of encountering the opposition he so richly deserves. Any determined group of individuals ought to be able to pinpoint the event location in their city, however. Many of these events are probably booked under false pretexts, and venue owners may not necessarily know who they are hosting.

Further dates may be added (or subtracted!) as the tour progresses. Irving also plans to speak on the East Coast later this year, although dates have not been announced for this yet. Let’s set the tone for the East Coast wing of Irving’s tour right now!

No platform for fascists, no compromise!


- Rose City Antifa / Portland ARA

fight_them_back [at] riseup [dot] net

971.533.7832 (voicemail)

item.title: rad show at the Greenhouse
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I find shows like this really exciting - a crap load of bands, all approaching their music from different angles, yet somehow fitting so well on a bill together. Night Train, for example, spawned from the awesome "Hot Grits" performance - an all Black, all female garage punk band who are fun and dancy, while Purple Rhinestone Eagle are also an all-female band who bust out shredding epic metal. The common threads between these bands may not seem immediately noticeable, but they're none the less there. Ex Monday, August 10th @ the Greenhouse! Purple Rhinestone Eagle (PDX) Telepathic Liberation Army Caucus (JPN) Herr Jazz Generifus (OLY) Night Train Doors @ 7:30pm. Show @ 8:15pm. ALL-AGES! $5 suggested donation! GREENHOUSE! 2515 S. Charles St. CENTRAL DISTRICT SEATTLE!

item.title: TARNAC 9 BENEFIT AT ARCTIC CIRCLE
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Please join us this Friday, August 21st for food, discussion, literature, and music to benefit the Tarnac 9. The Tarnac 9 are facing terrorism charges in France and have been accused of authoring The Coming Insurrection. Who are the Tarnac 9? On November 11th 2008, French Anti-Terrorism Police arrested around twenty people, mostly in Tarnac, a small village in the Corrèze region of central France. Nine were subsequently accused of “criminal association for the purposes of terrorist activity” in connection with the sabotage of train lines which had caused delays on the French railways. Very little evidence has been presented against them, but central to the prosecution is their alleged authorship of a book, The Coming Insurrection, and their association with what a scare-mongering French government and media have termed an “ultra-left” or “anarcho-autonomous movement”. They and others are the victims of a witch-hunt in which the word “terrorism” is applied to any ideas and practices which challenge the status quo--much like the U.S. government's Green Scare. An international movement is emerging in their support. What is The Coming Insurrection? It's important to note that the Tarnac 9 have maintained they are not the authors of The Coming Insurrection, which was penned by the anonymous group The Invisible Committee. That said, the booklet claims that recent financial crisis, civil unrest and environmental degradation stem from capitalism. According to the authors, "Thirty years of 'crisis,' mass unemployment, and flagging growth, and they still want us to believe in the economy... We have to see that the economy is itself the crisis. It's not that there's not enough work, it's that there is too much of it." The book aims to motivate the reader to direct action, promoting a form of insurrectionary anarchism. Here's what Fox News' Glenn Beck has to say about it:

-RSB

item.title: ARCTIC CIRCLE EXPLODES
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
Let's face it. We all knew Arctic Circle was a lonely old powder keg down there in Georgetown, teetering toward its own destruction even as no one paid attention, because . . . you know, Georgetown's kind of far away, right? And finally, some spark or another has set things off, and we're breaking up like the fireworks we didn't set off on the 4th of July because . . . we don't believe in that shit, right?
BANG! In one last brief flash of light on Friday, November 20th at 8 PM, come to 6633 Ellis Ave S for:
World History (message to land-dwellers: sing along) Witches of . . . . ( Silhouettes (the humid breath of basking buzzards) The Subtle Knife (for a limited engagement)
Afterwards, the wind carries our embers in a few directions, all away from Georgetown. A piece lands in an organic farm in the southwest, some land on a boat and then gesture (far) south, a few more gather in the Central District. The breeze whispers rumors that we may still have a few sparks left in us, so don't mourn. Party.

item.title: Uncle Franks Wild Gay Winter Lodge seeks sublet
item.dc:creator: neinfrankenstein
item.content:encoded:
Uncle Frank's wild gay winter lodge, a queer punk shared living house in the central district is seeking a temporary subletter for february and possibly march. We are (currently) female identified queer folks who love gardening, playing music, drinking whiskey, two-stepping, watching movies and preparing large sumptuous meals together. Our ideal match would be someone who identifies with, or is an awesome ally to the queer/ genderqueer/ trans communities that we're a part of. Also, being small living quarters, we desire a roomie who can help keep it somewhat tidy, because it can get out of control real fast. We have two cats, a bunch of vegetable gardens, about ten cast-iron skillets, and often one or two house-guests. Interested? Come over for dinner and drinks and see if we're a good match. xoxo!
Contact Nein-
neinfrankenstein@yahoo.com

item.title: Solidarity is FUN.
item.dc:creator: worldhistory
item.content:encoded: Seattle Solidarity is a volunteer network of working people who believe in standing up for our rights. Our goal is to support our fellow workers' strikes and struggles, build solidarity, and organize to deal with specific job, housing, and other problems caused by the greed of the rich and powerful. The Seattle Solidarity Network has been battling with a local real estate company (Lorig & Associates) and, as a result, Lorig has filed a lawsuit. They are attempting to silence the network, so they can continue "enhancing communities" (read "catering to rich, white people, while pushing around anyone who gets in their way"). Help them raise some cash for legal fees! They're a completely volunteer-run group & could really use your support. Saturday, February 27 The Big House (a large house in Capitol Hill - email bighouse@dodiy.org & ask for the address) 8:00PM MUSIC BY: The Pica Beats Thousands Joe Martin Wet Paint The Greatest Place To $8 at the door goes directly to Seattle Solidarity. NOTE FOR EVERYONE: Everyone will enter through the back door & it is wheelchair accessible. Only the basement (where most of the music will happen) is wheelchair accessible. Please be kind to people with chemical & scent sensitivies - Please Don't Wear Scented Deodorant or Perfumes & Don't Smoke Near The Non-Smokers. We're trying to make this event accessible to as many people as we can, so please send an email to bighouse@dodiy.org if you need any accommodations. Also Read This: www.scn.org/activism/calendar/disabilities.html

item.title: old protest response.
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I don't often do "editorial" type posts on this website, but I feel that doing this one is appropriate. I just attended the protest against police brutality that just took place today (read about it here and here), and I was given flyers published by folks regarding the action. One thing I was given disturbed me: a pamphlet entitled "Some People Shoot Back", which describes Christopher Monfort and his acts of counter-violence against a member of the SPD. While I somewhat appreciate critical and provocative discourse of ideas and challenges to institutions of power and violence, I became upset when I saw the back of the flyer, which listed "Resources for getting involved". Listed on there was SeattleDIY.com, this very website. I would like to state unequivocally that SeattleDIY should not be seen as a resource to get involved in insurrection and violence against the state/against police. The DIY culture, community, and movement is not about "Doing [acts of violence] Yourself", rather DIY is about coming up with creative solutions that make our lives more fulfilling, more engaged, and more empowered. While there are certainly parallel values that DIY shares with anarchist theory, I personally do not see reclamation of violence as one of them - I would like to believe that this is a movement based around creativity, not destruction. And while I personally am disgusted with the routine acts of violence by the police and by the state against vulnerable and marginalized people all over, and while I personally would like to do what I can to resist these institutions and build a future free of domination and oppression, I do not think it was appropriate to associate the name of this website with an inflammatory and provocative pamphlet that seems to advocate and endorse acts of physical violence against members of the police department. Such advocacy and endorsement are not part of this website or the mission of the people who run it. In the future, please contact me, the maintainer of this website, before associating it with similarly controversial materials in the future. So, to be clear: as the webmaster and moderator of this website, I appreciate and support the dialogue and actions of people who want to make a more empowered and accountable society by way of protest and direct action, but personally don't see this site as a resource to become more involved in committing acts of violence against members of the state/police. As I see it, this is not the appropriate forum for that particular brand of activism. The SeattleDIY.com website and the other things we publish are utilized by a large and diverse community, and endorsements of a tactics, political views, etc, should not be considered representative of the DIY movement as a whole. The DIY movement is large, nebulous, and diverse, and much of it celebrates canning and pickling done by conservative Mormons as much as efforts made by folk who want to create more accountable communities that don't need the police/jails/prisons. The ideals and values here are not monolithic, and should understood and a reflection of a particular approach to both social change and daily living, rather than a prescription for specific activities or ideologies. I hope this is clear and understandable, and I hope none of what I've written here disappoints any members of the DIY movement. If anyone would like to have dialogue about this, reply to this post, or email me directly at sdiycollective at gmail dot com. Thanks for reading. ***this has been edited as of 4/10/10 to reflect insights and address concerns made by people in the community. Thanks for your input.***

item.title: MAY 3RD 2010 in UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON, SEATTL
item.dc:creator: May3rd.Seattle.Strike
item.content:encoded:
MAY 3RD 2010 in UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON, SEATTLE
On May 3, the UW campus will be striking together.  Students will be setting up picket lines at the main campus entrance at 15th and 40th, and we will set up lines at other entrances if we have enough people.  We may also have roving picket lines at various worksites throughout campus.  UAW local 4121 may officially strike or rank-and-file UAW members may unofficially walk out to protest the layoffs of hundreds of TAs and the large class sizes that will result.  WFSE local 1488 and SEIU local 925 both passed resolutions supporting the UAW and reminding their members of their right not to cross the picket lines of another union or employee organization for safety reasons."
Calling anti-authoritarians from around the Seattle area to assist at potential entrance blockades at the University of Washington, Seattle.  The plan is to hit them where it hurts, disrupt the function of the institution.
Potential intersections for disruption:
15th NE and 40th NE

item.title: Spoken Word Compilation Project
item.dc:creator: Ed Halliday
item.content:encoded: http://www.seattlediy.com/?p=1133 I’m going to elaborate on my spoken word project 4 yall -I posted a post that Kenneth posted about it but now I’m posting about it so I can re-post it in other places so I don’t have to post so many posts.- “the long and short of it”: I’m working on a spoken word compilation cd/tape, you should record yourself reading a spoken word piece with accompaniment and send it in Mp3 format to Zebrajones01@gmail.com I’ll elaborate a bit: This is a project with very few guidelines, it doesn’t even have a deadline, because I will just always accept submissions for spoken word comps because I plan on always making spoken word comps. This is vol. 1. There are two really broad guidelines 1) Record a spoken word piece. It doesn’t have to be a poem, it can be a story or a conversation or just like, I dunno, anything I guess. 2) It needs to have accompaniment. This is also pretty open, it doesn’t have to be instrumental, it can honestly be anything. I mean I guess it has to get my stamp of approval but don’t let that sway you from trying anything and everything from noise loops to field recordings to sound effects to guitar chords to drumming to whatever. “think outside the box” Once vol. 1 is all put together there will be more ways for you to help out but we’ll get to that when the time comes.

item.title: SLICE: Strengthening Local Independent Co-ops Everywhere Conference
item.dc:creator: caplemelton
item.content:encoded: Saturday, October 23, 2010, at Seattle Central Community College, join regional cooperators for a powerful day-long conference on everything ranging from cooperative basics for people starting or interested in starting a new co-op to general information for anyone who supports co-ops and cooperation, and advanced collaboration opportunities. GET ENERGIZED • Hear the opening keynote address from Rosalinda Guillen, executive director of Bellingham, Washington’s De Comunidad a Comunidad (Community to Community), a women-led grassroots organization that works on practical solutions to social injustice through self-organizing by disempowered communities to build their own institutions to meet their own self-identified needs. Among other innovative and exciting projects, Guillen and Community to Community are working to create a culturally appropriate cooperative development center, and are supporting local farmworkers in their efforts to establish worker cooperative agricultural enterprises. • Enjoy a lunchtime keynote address from Jim Anderson of Ohio Employee Ownership Center at Kent State University and a founder of Evergreen Cooperatives, an inspiring Cleveland-based project designed to build a federation of worker cooperatives modeled on the Mondragon Federation in Spain. Evergreen Cooperatives includes an industrial laundry, a solar installation company, and a nascent large-scale urban greenhouse for growing lettuce. Commitments from the “Eds and Meds” (large educational and medical institutions in the University Circle area of Cleveland) enable these new worker cooperatives to hit the ground running, hiring and building equity for workers from surrounding neighborhoods devastated by the ongoing collapse of our industrial economy. GET SKILLS • Attend workshops on the following topics: decision-making, communication, and governance; incorporation; finances; eating cooperatively; living cooperatively; and working cooperatively. GET CONNECTED • Participate in a cooperative primer and discussions concerning cooperative economics, the next generation of cooperators, and the global cooperative movement. GET YOUR SLICE To register, visit Brown Paper Tickets. For additional information, contact Central Co-op’s cooperative advancement department via telephone 206.329.1545 or email. SLICE Work-Trade We have a limited number of work-trade opportunities available. In exchange for a 2-hour volunteer shift worked at the pre-conference social, October 22, or at SLICE, October 23, work-traders receive a $30 credit toward their conference ticket. To apply, please email us your full name, telephone number, and a response to the following questions. • Are you able to comfortably and safely lift 20 pounds? • Between 7:00 a.m. through 7:00 p.m. Friday, October 22, what is your availability? • Between 7:00 a.m. through 7:00 p.m. Saturday, October 23, what is your availability? • Are you licensed to drive? • Do you have a registered, insured vehicle? Applicants approved for work-trade will be notified via email. A shift assignment and Brown Paper Ticket registration instructions will be provided. SLICE Scholarships We have a limited number of scholarship opportunities available. To apply, please email us your full name, telephone number, and a response to the following questions. • Why are you interested in attending SLICE: Strengthening Local Independent Co-ops Everywhere? • How will you apply the skills and knowledge you gain at SLICE (e.g. cooperative projects, relationships, etc.)? • Do you permit the SLICE co-organizers to publish your responses? If so, how do you want your name to appear? Applications will be accepted until 8:00 a.m., October 11. Applicants awarded a scholarship will be notified via email October 14. Brown Paper Ticket registration instructions will be provided.
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how to start and develop your own co-op.

item.title: Folklife Performer Applications Available!
item.dc:creator: NW FOLKLIFE
item.content:encoded:
Folklife Performer Applications Available!
Northwest Folklife is now accepting performer applications to the next Northwest Folklife Festival, May 28-31, 2010. Applications are available online at http://www.nwfolklife.org, and the application deadline is November 2, 2009. You can apply entirely online, or you can download and print an application to send in. If you don’t have internet access, call us at 206-684-4189 and we will mail you an application.

If you play, sing, dance, create, or perform in the Pacific Northwest, be sure to apply to Folklife, our nation’s largest community arts festival. Every year more than 250,000 people attend the four-day event—it’s one of the best ways to get known in the Northwest.

Every application is reviewed and notifications to all applicants will be in late February or early March. We’re looking forward to hearing from you!

Fill out your application now!

Thanks,
Northwest Folklife Programming Team

item.title: GEMS Proudly Presents - We Made This Together
item.dc:creator: gemssneakershop
item.content:encoded:
On 12/31/09 starting from 5p-9p GEMS SNEAKER SHOP will be throwing a New Years eve art collective! Featured artist Ian Toms,Michael Rioux,Eamonn Parke. Location: 615 Western ave Seattle WA.98104


GEMS Proudly Presents - We Made This Together artists: Ian Toms,Michael Rioux,Eamonn Parke
Location: 615 Western Ave. Seattle,WA.98104

Time: 5p-9p

Date: 12/31/09

Admission: FREE-RSVP Required,register at RSVP@GEMSSNEAKERSHOP.COM

AGE: All

We Made This Together ; it is a photography show documenting moments of intimacy and voyeurism between the photographer and subject.

GEMS Sneaker Shop will be hosting this event on 12/31/09 starting at 5:00 p.m. in Seattle,WA.(Pioneer Square District.)

Artist Introduction:

Ian Toms is a painter from Chicago, Illinois. Mr. Toms has recently shown work in the 2009 PONCHO Auction, as well as the East/ West Emerging Artists Exchange at CoCA. Mr. Toms continues to produce work from his downtown studio and is involved in several curatorial projects. Mr. Toms received his BFA from Cornish College of the Arts in 2009 and currently lives and works in Seattle.

Michael Rioux makes performance and visual art. He is originally from Chicago. He has performed with Mordine & Co., Lucky Plush Productions and Luna Negra Dance Theater among others. In 2001 Michael founded Impetus Dance Theater. He served as artistic director and resident choreographer until 2005 when he moved to Seattle. Current projects include performing with Scott/Powell Performance, Salt Horse, Lingo, and directing the performance group The Sho. Michael received his BFA in printmaking and video from Cornish College of the Arts. His concern as an artist is to be full of joy and full of discovery.

Eamonn Parke originally from Boise

, Idaho. His photography captures, admires, and criticizes the health and beauty of life. Eamonn’s motivation stems from an admitted fear of forgetting his own existence, and therefore documents his environment, both familiar and strange. With great affection for analog, and a necessary concession to digital techniques, his work marries old and new. Eamonn Parke Holds a BFA from Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle, Washington.

This is a limited engagement, You and guest must RSVP for this EVENT! - rsvp@gemssneakershop.com
Art, Entertainment

For more information:
615 Western Ave. Seattle,WA.98104 WWW.GEMSSNEAKERSHOP.BLOGSPOT.COM

item.title: In search of vocalist/musical collaborator
item.dc:creator: KR
item.content:encoded: I'm a 24 year old guitarist, and I'm looking for someone with whom I can collaborate. Specifically, I'm looking for a vocalist. If you play an instrument, that's a plus. I'm influenced largely by so-called alternative and "indie" music. I'm also interested in some electronic and experimental music. Just to give you an idea, I especially love Stereolab, Sonic Youth, and Portishead. If you're interested, please reply, and I can direct you to some samples of some of my works in progress. If you'd like to contribute to them or start something new, great! I'm also up for contributing to your works in progress if you're interested. Thanks!

item.title: Part-time job cooking for ladies/kids at a residential drug treatment center
item.dc:creator: vegancookies
item.content:encoded:
Hey, I'm the M-F cook at Perinatal Treatment Center in North Seattle (on the #5 and #358 bus routes). We're looking for a relief cook to work every saturday, sunday, most holidays and random times (with notice) when I take a vacation or something.

I'm posting it here because I think someone with a FNB background or similar food philosophy would be best for the job. Those are the skills that have come in handy the most for me -- cooking for large groups, improvising (about half our ingredients are from weekly donations and the rest we purchase), working on a small budget, having a big ol' heart and wanting everybody to get great, healthy food.

I cook veg*n M-F so the facility specifically wants someone who will cook meat meals on the weekends. We do get a lot of meat donations, and I would love a cook who could work with that as much as possible instead of having to purchase a lot of meat.

job description my boss wrote up:

Perinatal Treatment Services looking for a part time cook.

Help turn lives around and build stronger families! Work at a 26-bed residential chemical dependency treatment program for pregnant and parenting women.

Seeking a kitchen professional to fill our Relief Cook Position in our North Seattle location (130th and Aurora).

The ideal candidate is reliable, creative, and has the ability to prepare/serve lunch and dinner for 26 women and up to 17 children. Needs to love real food, have patience, good boundaries and love people!!

Hours are 9:30 am – 5:30 pm Saturdays and Sundays. Work hours may also include occasional holidays to cover for the full time cook.

The Lead cook serves a vegetarian diet 5 days a week so candidate must be able to prepare meat dishes.

Will insure the DOH procedures and regulations regarding storage, transporting, and preparations are followed. Background training highly recommended. Equal Opportunity Employer.

Candidate must be able to demonstrate no alcohol or drug misuse for 3 years prior to employment, and no misuse while employed.

Starting pay $11.50 DOE

Email cover letter and resume asap to darcyf@ptswa.org and also vegancookies@gmail.com (both email addresses are mine.)

--Darcy

item.title: Website for up and coming local bands
item.dc:creator: Aueraliano Buendia
item.content:encoded: Hey my name is Leland Corley and I'm working on building a website that will provide booking information, venue locations, and other necessary information. I will also include links to sites that stream music such as Pandora, Lala, justhearit, projectplaylist, and seeqpod. There will be a blog section to this website that will give bands a chance to collaborate in a sort of band pool esque fashion. My aim with this project is to help local bands thrive in the contemporary music sceneand to promote musical learning. I was wondering if it would be at all possible to collaborate with the adminisatrators of this site in order to get an idea of how to set up an effective web site and blog. I would also like to work with Seattle DIY because Seattle's local bands embody the spirit of doing things themselves.

item.title: January 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: January 2008 News! This month, some amazing people are organizing Seattle's first ever Really Really Free Market! It'll be on Saturday January 19th at the C.A.Y.A. (23rd & Yesleter in the Central District) from 9am to 2pm. Here's some info: The RRFM movement is a non-hierarchical collective of individuals who form a temporary market based on an alternative gift economy. The RRFM movement aims to counteract capitalism in a non-reactionary way. It holds as a major goal to build a community based on sharing resources, caring for one another and improving the collective lives of all. Markets often vary in character, but they generally offer both goods and services. Participants bring unneeded items, food, skills and talents such as entertainment or haircuts. A RRFM may take place in an open community space such as a public park or community commons. For more, go to wikipedia.org/wiki/Really_Really_Free_Market DIY Academy! We're going to start organizing a magnificent series of summer workshops and events. The work is going to begin soon, and if you'd like to get involved, come to a meeting at Healthy Times Fun Club on January 20th at 6pm. As many of you know, the Zine Archive and Publishing Project has fallen under hard times in the past few months. In September, Richard Hugo House decided to put the zine archive on hiatus for an indefinite period, citing organizational problems and a lack of volunteer commitment as reasons for closing the library. This decision was made without the input of ZAPP volunteers, and after the closure many were left wondering about the future of the archive. Since then, the Hugo House has promised to oversee the formation of a committee to reopen the zine archive and to reimagine its direction and purpose within the Hugo House structure. However, this committee has yet to meet, the budget for the archive has been cut, and the library has been moved out of the basement despite the protests of volunteers. In light of these many setbacks and disappointments, a group of former ZAPP volunteers has bound together. We are working to reopen the zine archive and restore its status as an invaluable community resource. If you are interested in joining the ongoing efforts to save ZAPP, please contact savezapp@gmail.com Go to the Home Alive Social Hour! “The Social Hour is a place for all Home Alive friends and fans to gather together, and build community for lives free from violence and hate. Bring a friend, an idea or just yourself. Come enjoy free pizza, games, question of the month, and more!” It's on January 16th, 5-7 p.m. We'll be there, and there will be free pizza courtesy Zeeks. At Home Alive’s Studio: 1415 10th Ave, 2nd floor, Capitol Hill The SeattleDIY Collective is working on a couple zines – The Guide To Seattle, and The Guide To Putting Shit On. If you'd like to help us, come to a meeting at The Ark on January 6th at 6pm, or go seattlediy.pbwiki.com and edit the zines in Wiki format (the password is diyordie). The Vera Project has just hired the wonderful Joshua Powell as its new Program Director. He's been a huge advocate for the DIY community and we can be sure to see a lot of really great things happening at the Vera.

item.title: February 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: February 2008 News! We had to cancel our February Really Really Free Market due to lack of a place to have it. Sorry! It'll be back next month! Not much else is going on this month!

item.title: March 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: March 2008 News! We had to cancel February’s Really Really Free Market, but it’ll be on for March! The Next Really Really Free Market will be on March 29th. We're planning on having the Free Market on the last Saturday of every month. Don't know what a Really Really Free Market is? Go to wikipedia.org/wiki/Really_Really_Free_Market The Seattle Free School has started to offer classes! First, there will be a class on urban chicken keeping, then later in the month a class on getting Irish Citizenship. Check out their website at seattlefreeschool.googlepages.com Also, if you have a class or workshop you’d like to offer, get a hold of them! Home Alive is now hosting their Social Hour on the first Wednesday of every month! Social Hour is seriously fun – the March Social Hour included crafts, a band, and free pizza. 6-9pm at Home Alive HQ. Gallery 1412 is now having a monthly movie night, call “Flim Night!” They’re showing some amazing stuff, and all proceeds benefit Food Not Bombs! Punk Rock Flea Market! The event is back, and will be a huge deal with lots of vendors. prfleamarket.com for details. Seattle Food Not Bombs has a new website that’s pretty rad, which means that there’s more updated information about how to get involved. FNB is always looking for more help – so hit them up! The Bike Shack also has a new website, and now you can see who is volunteering on what days and when it’ll be open! Huzzah! Bikeshack.org The SeattleDIY Collective is working on a couple zines – The Guide To Seattle, and The Guide To Putting Shit On. If you'd like to help us, come to a meeting at The Ark on January 6th at 6pm, or go to seattlediy.pbwiki.com and edit the zines in Wiki format (the password is diyordie)

item.title: April 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: April 2008 News! The Vera Project and SeattleDIY are going to have a fund raiser for an upcoming event called Ok?Ok! We're having a movie night fund raiser @ the Vera Project, 6pm, april 14th. Bring donations for snacks. The movie will be The Legend of Billie Jean interested in starting a book club? I bet you are! Contact Jake HTFC @ their myspace page: myspace.com/healthytimesfunclub Healthy Times Fun club recently held a benefit show for Milo, a 2 year old with a genetic liver defect that inhibits the processing of protein. He's coming to Seattle for a transplant. The recovery time will be several months and his family will need to find housing and money for food while they are here. Oregon Health Plan takes care of Milo, but his parents will not be working and will have various expenses while this is all happening. The benefit at healthy times on Saturday March 22nd went really well, raising almost 400 dollars for Milo but his family could still use a lot more money and support. If you did not get a chance to donate and would like to please access the paypal account under btsy.b@hotmail.com ! Interested in joining an amazing bicycle collective? The Bikery is having their members meetings on the first Monday of the month at Dancylvania. details: thebikery.org Seattle Food Not Bombs is looking for more volunteers! They have a new website where you can find out about what all is going on, and you can sign up for their mailing list. sfnb.revolt.org Really Really Free Market! The next free market will be on Saturday April 26th. For more info, visit the website at myspace.com/seattlereallyfreemarket At the moment, we're looking for a space for April and following months. If you know of a public space that would be good, email us or message our myspace. Members of the SeattleDIY Collective just finished a zine entitled, "Punk Rock Finances," writing about how those of us with uncomfortable relationships with money can make wiser and more deliberate choices. If you want a copy, write to Benji at heartxmurmur at yahoo dot com or go to seattlediy.pbwiki.com to read it.

item.title: June 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
The SeattleDIY Collective is having a Secret Cafe fund raiser on June 29th! We'll be unveiling our new community recipe-book zine, and making fabulous featured dishes. Email secretcafe@seattlediy.com to rsvp! The times you can rsvp for are 11am, 1:30pm, and 4:00pm. Money raised will support SeattleDIY with printing costs, webspace, and all the other stuff we do.
Really Really Free Market! The next free market will be on Saturday June 28th. For more info, visit the website at myspace.com/seattlereallyfreemarket
Bend-It Extravaganza is here! It's a festival by and for queer people and their friends, and it's all free. There's workshops, performances and bands, food, and film! It'll be absolutely amazing, and you should check out the schedule on seattlediy.com or at myspace.com/bend_it
Seattle Food Not Bombs is looking for more volunteers! They have a new website where you can find out about what all is going on, and you can sign up for their mailing list. sfnb.revolt.org
Field Trip time! On the 2nd Saturday of June we're going to have a field trip to Discovery Park! We'd like to make an effort to help acquaint people with the often neglected and hidden parts of town, as well as have an opportunity to meet new people. Email news@seattlediy.com or message us on our myspace page (myspace.com/sdiy) and we'll let you know where we're meeting, at what time, and how we'll be getting there.
Home Alive is still needing some major support to keep their doors open. The Greenhouse is having a benefit for them on Saturday June 7th with amazing bands. Also, they're having their monthly Home Alive Social Hour on the first Wednesday of every month. Come on June 4th from 6-8:30. It's always mega-fun. Homealive.org for more info!
SeattleDIY & The Vera Project's collaborative event, Okay? Okay! was a great success! We raised some money for Home Alive, and we had a really good turnout for the workshops with CARA, Home Alive, and the Feminist Karate Union. Thanks so much to everyone who came, the bands, and the volunteers! You are all amazing.

item.title: August 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
Carousel Festival!!! The lovely Nathan from The Greenhouse and the SeattleDIY Collective have organized Carousel Fest's third year of awesomeness, and this year is going to be a doozy! Check myspace.com/carouselfestival for the schedule. This year we're going to have some amazing artists to help us celebrate the local DIY community and raise money for Communities Against Rape And Abuse (CARA, cara-seattle.org) and Home Alive (homealive.org), including Kimya Dawson, Bloodhag, LP+BB, Madeline, and tons more!
A shit storm has landed in Seattle following a violent exchange that occurred at the July Critical Mass ride. Most media outlets are placing blame on bicyclists. Let us first acknowledge that the actions of a few DO NOT represent the intentions of the whole. Also, it's important to get accounts from witnesses of various perspectives – pedestrians, drivers, and bicyclists. Critical Mass is still a relevant expression of solidarity amongst bicyclists, despite this incident, and bicyclists deserve the right to safely express their desire to live in a bicycle-positive town. Stay safe, and keep riding.
A good friend of many people in the local DIY community has been arrested and is being charged with causing property damage. Please support Bryan LeFey! We're sad to say goodbye to a few DIY spaces! Dearborn on Woodland had their last show on July 5th. The Ark is inhabited by new people and is now called Chilladelphia. It saddens our hearts to let you know that Dog City is going to be torn down at the end of August. Dog City will be hosting the first night of Carousel Festival, which may be their last event. Dog City/Camp Nowhere has been an incredible place to meet people, eat food, and watch bands. RIP.
There are a few new spaces popping up! The former inhabitants of the SS Marie Antoinette have begun a new space, The Josephine (myspace.com/thejosephine). There's a house in South Seattle called The Jolly Roger (myspace.com/thejollyrogervenue) that hosts hardcore shows, and House 2301 will apparently be hosting a show/month or so. The Holy Mountain (myspace.com/holymountainvenue ) is still new on the scene, and thus far has hosted some amazing events. We'd like to welcome the House of Zanzibar (myspace.com/thehouseofzanzibar), who have pledged to host some great events and pick up the slack left by the dearly departed houses.
Exciting event alert! The Spruce House (myspace.com/sprucehouse) is hosting a “DIY Happy Hour” on their stoop every other hursday from 6-9pm. They're hosting these events to help build community, and they ask people to “BYO music, food, drinks, shenanigans, stories, hidden talents, skillshares and show and tells.” Email them at sprucehuset@gmail.com or message them for details. The first one is on August 7th.

item.title: September 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: September 2008 News! Carousel Festival!!! We raised $1084 for Home Alive and Communities Against Rape And Abuse (CARA) this year at Carousel Festival. Thanks so much to those who came, participated, volunteered, and performed. It was a magical weekend, and we look forward to doing it again next year! A huge thank you goes to Nathan from The Greenhouse for all the hard work he put into organizing. We love you! Sustainable Ballard will be happening from Sept 27th to 28th at Ballard Commons Park. Seattle Free School will be there, along with a lot of other great organizations. Do it! Couch Fest Films! Some local film makers are having an amazing event on September 27th. All day long at different houses short films will be shown, each house showing films of a different genre. Every hour it will switch to a different house. This is an excellent celebration of local film and community. Go to couchfestfilms.com for more info. On September 21st, Scribbles (a house) will be hosting a benefit Breakfast Cafe at 10am. Vegan meals (w/ wheat free options), and drinks. $10/guest. Get your reservations: leave a voice mail at 206-424-4501. Critical Mass last month was great – though it did have an incredibly awkward Police escort. Critical Mass is still a vital and important expression of bicycle solidarity and an exercise in community building, so please continue to ride or come if you've never been. Exciting event alert! The Spruce House (myspace.com/sprucehouse) is hosting a “DIY Happy Hour” on their stoop every other Thursday from 6-9pm. They're hosting these events to help build community, and they ask people to “BYO music, food, drinks, shenanigans, stories, hidden talents, skillshares and show and tells.” Email them at sprucehuset@gmail.com or message them for details. The first one is on August 7th. Stitch n' Bitch! Dancylvania will be hosting a weekly stitch & bitch, every monday from 7-9pm. They have some supplies, but feel free to bring your own. Myspace.com/dancylvaniahouse

item.title: October 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: October 2008 News! Seattle has a wonderful new group doing organizing around preventing, addressing, and talking about sexual assault and perpetrator accountability in an anti-authoritarian setting. They're called For Crying Out Loud. For more info, visit forcryingoutloud206.wordpress.com or myspace.com/forcryingoutloud206, and attend their next meeting on October 3rd at the Scribble Squat (6pm-9pm). Healthy Times Fun Club has opened a craft store! There's now a space at HTFC by the show-room where you can get art, hand-crafted goods, and zines! Money raised goes to the artists/crafters and to the SeattleDIY Collective. We're looking for more people to get us stuff for the store – let us know! Myspace.com/healthytimesfunclub ZAPP has reopened! The Richard Hugo House's Zine Archive And Publishing Project has reopened, and the 20,000 zines are now upstairs. ZAPP's new open hours are Wednesdays 4-8 pm and Thursdays and Saturdays 1-5 pm. Allyship is an amazing group that will be hosting a series of community discussions around various topics connecting LGBTQ rights and their connection to other issues. October 23rd's discussion will be Beyond Marriage, at the Langston Hughes Center, 6:30. Support these wonderful people and the work they're doing! myspace.com/allyship Really Really Free Market! The next free market will be on Saturday October 25th. What's a Really Really Free Market? A RRFM is a monthly event that happens in opposition to the "Free Market" which really isn't free. Everything at the Really Free Market is FREE. Nothing is for sale, trade or barter! It is a place for people to congregate and bring things to the community they no longer need or use. Sometimes people even give free massages or haircuts or whatever other skill or services they want to donate. Usually other organizations come and donate their services, also. The Really Free Market is nothing without your participation! Come and bring things you don't need that can be re-used. The Seattle Really Free Market happens on the last Saturday of the month. For more info, visit the website at myspace.com/seattlereallyfreemarket Bend-It Collective is having meetings twice a month now, and is organizing workshops on various art projects like zine making, bicycle helmet decorating, circuit bending, silkscreening, and who knows what else! Want to help them organize a workshop? Attend a meeting! Every other Monday at Kaladi on Capitol Hill, 7pm. Next meetings will be on October 13th and October 27th. Local organizers for the homeless and the houseless community have been doing some direction action to get shelter built as a response to Mayor Nickels announcement to disallow all camping and sleeping on city property. The result is Nickelsville, which soon after being built was served an eviction notice and demolished, with some residents and supporters arrested. Visit their website for more info (nickelsvilleseattle.org), and get involved! The 2008 Election is coming up, on November 4th. It's not just the president of the US that's being elected – there's plenty of local officials and issues to vote on also. Registration is easy and you can download the form online at kingcounty.gov/Elections. Whether you vote or take a principled stand against it, just remember that oppressive systems always view silence as consent.

item.title: November 2008 News
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
UMOJAFEST P.E.A.C.E. Center, an up-and-coming new community center! The Umojafest “Positive Education Activating Contact Elevation” Center, located on 24th and Spring, is a “multi-purpose facility currently being developed… in the heart of Seattle’s historically African-American Central District” that will primarily function as a “Center for Hip-Hop Culture, Business, and Technology.” When completed, this space will be an amazing resource to empower communities in the Central District and throughout Seattle in creating a D.I.Y., youth-oriented Hip-Hop culture that reflects the values of those who participate. The center will provide tools such as Hip-hop oriented entrepreneurial development, music and video production equipment, classes on subjects ranging from life skills to creative writing, office space for community organizations, and an outdoor theatre, stage and place for community events. Stay tuned for more events at Umojafest! To get involved, contact wyking@gmail.com.
Cascade People’s Center may close December 31st ! Some of you have attended Seattle Free School classes at the Cascade People's Center. Without the Cascade People's Center many of the classes Seattle Free School offers simply would not be able to happen. Unfortunately the City Council hasn't put the Cascade People's Center into next years budget, and without this funding the Center will have to close December 31st. Many people ask us what they can do to help Seattle Free School and now we're letting you know that helping Cascade People's Center is indeed helping Seattle Free School. For more information about how you can help please go to http://seattlefreeschool.blogspot.com/
Thanksgiving is this month. Some indigenous groups in the United States do not celebrate at all. Some use it as a day of mourning and remembering the dead. While still others take this day to celebrate indigenous people’s survival and resistance.
Day after Thanksgiving is BUY NOTHING DAY!! Don’t open that wallet for a thing come to the Really, Really Free Market at Pratt Park Saturday November 29 noon-4pm.

item.title: About the SeattleDIY Collective:
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
SeattleDIY is a collective whose mission is to promote and support the DIY ethos and its associated growing community in Seattle. Our goal is to help this large and nebulous group of people stay informed about what the community is doing, hopefully leading to greater communication, participation, and collaboration. Our Values: We believe in being the creators of culture rather than consumers. We believe in promoting a just society that supports itself through mutual aid and without hierarchies. We believe in fighting against institutionalized oppression (racism, sexism, ageism/adultism, and homophobia), and we support environmental justice, animal rights, egalitarianism, and human rights.

We meet weekly to discuss what we can do to address the needs of the community and work on projects, and we're always looking for new members and new ideas. If you'd like to see what we've been up to, visit our blog at http://www.seattlediycollective.blogspot.com/ All SeattleDIY meetings are open to everyone! Check the calendar for information about the next meeting.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hello, I am an intern with Reel Grrls, a local non-profit organization that empowers young women through teaching filmmaking and media literacy. The staff and mentors of Reel Grrls are competing in the Hot Docs International Documentary Challenge where we create a documentary in 5 days. We may be interested in doing this documentary on the Seattle DIY scene, and I was wondering if there was someone from the SeattleDIY Collective who would be willing to be interviewed by us. We will be making the documentary this weekend, so I apologize for the late notice. However, we are still unsure if DIY will be the topic because it is dependent on the theme of the Doc Challenge, which we will hear on Thursday (3/5). At this point, I am wondering if you would be interested in some kind of participation. Thank you,

item.title: Food Justice
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: Here are some websites the address local food justice issues: Community Alliance for Global Justice - Food Justice Project: http://www.seattleglobaljustice.org/food-justice/ Seattle Permaculture Guild: This site is meant to be a gathering point for folks in Seattle wanting to practice, play with, and learn more about Permaculture. http://seattlepermacultureguild.org/ Permaculture wiki: http://seattlepermacultureguild.org/wiki/wiki.php?n=Main.HomePage Solid Ground - Marra Farm: Marra Farm is a model urban community farm engaging people in sustainable agriculture and education while enhancing local food security. Tucked into the South Park neighborhood of Seattle, it has 4 acres of historic preserved farmland. http://www.solid-ground.org/Programs/Nutrition/Marra/Pages/default.aspx Cascadia Food Not Lawns: http://www.foodnotlawns.com/ Guerrilla Gardening: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guerrilla_gardening http://www.laguerrillagardening.org/ books on guerrilla gardening: http://www.newsociety.com/bookid/3945 http://www.amazon.co.uk/Guerrilla-Gardening-Handbook-without-Boundaries/dp/0747590818 Seed Bombs: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_bombing recipe: http://www.carbonsmart.com/carboncopy/2008/03/seed-bombs-for.html

item.title: Regular Community Events
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
Regular DIY Events in Seattle!

Hollow Earth Radio!
hollowearthradio.com
HER is an online DIY radio station featuring live performances, interviews with locals, and lots of incredible music. 24/7!

The Bikery
http://www.thebikery.org
A collectively run bicycle shop and learning center. Work on your bikes, volunteer, or buy em' cheap!
Regular Shop Hours: Saturdays: Noon-6pm, Sundays, Mondays, Tuesdays: 2pm-8pm.
Plus check the website for special classes.

The Bike Shack @ 55th and 9th
Free volunteer run bicycle shop.
For hours check Bikeshack.org

Richard Hugo House Zine Archiving and Publishing Project
http://www.hugohouse.org/house/zapp/
Seattle's own volunteer-run zine library.
Wednesdays 4–8 p.m., Thursdays 1–5 p.m. & Saturdays 1–5 p.m

Marginal Way Skate Park
marginalwayskatepark.org
Diy and community built skate park in SODO

Northwest Film Forum
Non-profit cinema & filmmakers' collective
1515 12th Ave (at Pike)
nwfilmforum.org

Mondays:

Books to Prisoners!
Help BTP send books to inmates.
Every Mondays and Tuesday, 6-10pm
Call 442-2013 or email
bookstoprisoners at cs dot com

The Bikery hosts Queers, Gears, and Cheers - Mondays, 2pm – 8pm
In addition to our regular open hours, we are welcoming Queers, Gears, and Cheers into the Bikery's fold. While the Bikery is always proudly queer-friendly, Mondays you can drop in and work on your bike in a Queer-identified space. All skill levels welcome, and tools and helpful hands provided. All identities welcome. Queers! Gears! & Cheers! is aimed at creating a more visible Queer presence in Seattle's bike culture and providing a fun, safe environment for underrepresented folks to become empowered through the Do-It-Yourself (DIY) theology.

Tuesdays:

Punk Rock Yoga
http://www.punkrockyoga.com | seattle@punkrockyoga.com
Unpretentious yoga, for everyone. Experienced teacher. Comfortable, setting. All levels welcome. PRY offers an open-minded and straight-forward approach to yoga philosophy while embracing the ancient yoga tradition of Do-It-Yourself.
Live music (mellow, not “punk rock”) at most classes.
$10 drop in, punch cards available.
Tuesdays at 20/20 Cycle
6:45pm. 20th & Union in the CD.

Tuesday Night Bike Rides
7pm at Red Square on UW Campus

Wednesdays:

Craft Night!
Weekly art/craft/political project night.
craftnightseattle@gmail.com
myspace.com/craftnightseattle
for info and location.

Thursdays:

Bike Works Volunteer Repair Parties
Volunteer Repair Parties - Every Thursday, 6:30pm - 9:30pm
Help repair bikes so we can get them back on the road! You bring the skills, we provide shop tools, work stands, plenty of bikes, a choice selection of music, food, and good company. Drop in. The bikes we repair during these sessions are donated to Treehouse, Farestart, local non-profits, and our annual Kid’s Bike Swap. Last Repair Party May 7th until Fall 2009!
Bike Works - 3709 S. Ferdinand, 206 - 725 - 9408
bikeworks.org

Thursday Night Bicycle Ride
Meet at 7pm at Westlake Center

Fridays:

Justice Works! general meeting. 6:30.
JW! Is a grassroots criminal justice reform organization, focusing on supporting people who face the problems inherent in the criminal justice system. They seek to undo institutionalized racism by working with communities and individuals in an accountable, safe space.
4206 Rainier Ave S Seattle 98118
www.justiceworks.info

Saturdays:

Food Not Bombs - Saturday Free Market
Free groceries and household goods!
Saturdays at noon @ the Yesler Terrace Community Center
contact fnb at scn dot org to get involved.

Food Not Bombs Saturday Dinner
Cook at 10am @ Sherwood Co-op, Serve at 1pm @ Campus Parkway (U-District)
seattlefnb.blogspot.com



Sundays:

Food Not Bombs Sunday hot meal!
Cooked at Rainer Unitarian
Universalist Center at 3:30
Served at about 7pm at
Occidental Park @ Occidental and S. Main, in Pioneer Square. - sfnb.revolt.org

Food Not Bombs Cascade Free Market
FNB free produce distribution! Sundays at 1:30pm
@ Cascade People's Center
309 Pontius Ave N. - sfnb.revolt.org

Slow Sunday bike ride
http://www.myspace.com/slowsundayz
A weekly bike ride open to all cyclists at all ages, identities, and and bicycle types. Typically roll 20-30 miles over 4-8 hours, but the pace is easy. The ride will hit up parks, farmers markets, dumpsters, coffee shops, bike shops, workshops, house parties and more.
1pm meet-up at Cal Anderson Park, 1;30pm depart

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Heja! Actually, the Bike Works weekly Volunteer Repair Party is on Thursday eves, not Tuesday. And they are wicked fun!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: About the website: SeattleDIY.com is intended to be a hub of information and resources for the DIY community in Seattle. * We have a community calendar that anyone can add events to, as well as a list of weekly regular events and monthly events. * On our main page we'll be keeping track of community news, posting it here so that we can all stay informed and better able to support each other. * We work to keep track of what DIY and community-oriented venues and projects and organizations exist in town. * The SeattleDIY Collective is going to be actively working on highlighting an issues each month and creating a page with information and resources for that topic. For example, we chose the issue of Food Justice for December. * The collective has been working on a number of zine projects that we publish, and we aim to host the zines on this website also, keeping them in a wiki format that anyone can edit. We're going to make pdf files of our zines that will make it easy to download and print them yourself. * We have a message board / forum that people can use to connect with others in the DIY community. * Flickr - we have a flickr group, so if you have a flickr account you can add your photos to the flickr group and the 8-most-recent will show up on our main page. flickr.com/groups/seattlediy * Twitter - We're working out how to have a twitter account that the community can update. More details to come. http://twitter.com/seattle_diy How to use this website: Make a user account! In the upper right corner there is a link to register a user account. You'll need an email address (which we will not use to spam you or anything) and you'll have to verify it. With your account you'll be able to post news items on the front page (please keep it relevant - we'll moderate them!) and post in the forum. Even without a user account, you'll be able to comment on any of the pages, and you can add an event to the event calendar. To add an event to the calendar, go to the DIY Event Calendar then click on Edit/Add Event. Please read the rules and criteria for posting an event, and please don't include a big picture. We'll generally remove pictures to make the calendar load faster (a lot of people use it), even if your flyer is really cool. (If you have a flyer that you want to promote, add it to our flickr group!!) Click "Edit Calendar" on the rules page. The log-in is "seattle" and the pw is "diy". Then click on the "Add Event" button in the upper-right corner of the page. When adding an event: Make sure the category of the event is correct. Don't leave out information: who/what, where, and when. We prefer events that are donation-based, but please specify if it isn't (be aware of legal recourse for mandatory entry-fees without a banquet or business lisence). Otherwise assume that events are $5-suggested sliding-scale donation. Please be aware that we don't get paid to do this - this is purely a labor of love. We spend our own money on everything we do and spend lots of volunteer hours. Please try to keep this simple and easy for us. Thanks! How this website was built: We are hosted through AN Hosting. This site is built using WordPress (wordpress.org), using the carrington theme and a bunch of widgets. The calendar system is EasyPHPCalendar (easyphpcalendar.com), which we bought a registered copy of. This was built by Benji, with contributions and invaluable input from Seth, Jenna, Garrett, and others. Want to make a website like this for your own town? Let us know, and we can point you in the right direction. sdiycollective at gmail.

item.title: What is "DIY"?
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: From the wikipedia article: The DIY ethic (do it yourself ethic) refers to the ethic of being self-reliant by completing tasks oneself as opposed to having others who are likely more experienced complete them. The term can indicate "doing" anything from home improvements and repairs to healthcare, from publication to electronics. DIY questions the supposed uniqueness of the expert's skills, and promotes the ability of the ordinary person to learn to do more than he or she thought was possible. In the punk subculture, the DIY ethic is tied to punk ideology and anticonsumerism, as a rejection of the need to purchase items or use existing systems or processes. Emerging punk bands often perform basement shows in residential homes, rather than at traditional venue, to avoid corporate sponsorship. The DIY punk ethic also applies to everyday living, such as learning bicycle repair rather than taking a bike to a mechanic's shop, sewing/repairing/modifying clothing rather than buying new clothes, starting vegetable gardens, and reclaiming recyclable products by dumpster diving. Punk impresario David Ferguson's CD Presents was a DIY concert production, recording studio and record label network. Subculture The term 'DIY' or 'Do-It-Yourself' is also used to describe: * Self-publishing books, zines, and alternative comics. * bands or solo artists releasing their music on self-funded record labels * creating crafts such as knitting, sewing, handmade jewelry, ceramics, etc.[2] * creating punk, indie, or hipster musical merchandise through the use of recycling thrift store or discarded materials, usually decorated with logo art applied by silk screen.[3] * Independent game development and game modding. DIY as a subculture arguably began with the punk movement of the 1970s[4]. Instead of traditional means of bands reaching their audiences through large music labels, bands began recording themselves, manufacturing albums and merchandise, booking their own tours, and creating opportunities for smaller bands to get wider recognition and gain cult status through repetitive low-cost DIY touring. The burgeoning zine movement took up coverage of and promotion of the underground punk scenes, and significantly altered the way fans interacted with musicians. Zines quickly branched off from being hand-made music magazines to become more personal. Zines quickly became one of the youth culture's gateways to DIY culture, which lead to tutorial zines showing others how to make their own shirts, posters, zines, books, food, etc. Political action With the rise of the modern multi-national corporation, North American and European DIY culture has increasingly become a social and political ideology as well as a hobby and fashion aesthetic. Similar to the Arts and Crafts movement of the 1900s, the modern DIY movement is viewed as a reactionary response on an individual scale to modern industrial society's reliance on mass-production. In response to the perception and belief that these large multi-national companies exploit labor in developing countries, (such as Gap, Nike, and Coca-Cola), the DIY subculture has increasingly seen its choices as consumers motivated in part to not support such perceived cruelty and abuse. A common sentiment expressed in DIY culture is to "think globally, act locally," meaning that support of multinational corporations supports exploitative labor and environmental practices, so to purchase goods and services made locally in effect boycotts these organizations. In addition, the making, recycling, or otherwise following a doctrine of "non consumption" as part of DIY subculture lessens the amount of sales taxes one pays, such taxes being viewed as similarly aiding such morally repugnant institutions as governments which wage war. This view of "consuming less as political statement" is not agreed upon in the subcultures it is found in, but is a motivating force for many of its adherents. DIY culture is not limited to hand-making items such as clothing and housewares, but extends to choices of public transportation such as biking and bike repair, walking, taking public transportation, making electric, hybrid or bio-diesel vehicles and modifying existing vehicles, to avoid supporting traditional car companies, which are perceived to be amoral. Listening to and making community radio, pirate radio, and watching and making community television instead of advertising-filled traditional media is also common.
