item.title: Food Not Bombs Benefit Show
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
What's your favorite freeform food movement? If you said "the Panama Canal", go to school. I mean- literally- go get an education because that made no sense...

... Oh, you were indulging in a non sequitur. We're cool.

This Saturday (October 17th) there will be a Food Not Bombs benefit occurring at Healthy Times Fun Club. The money will help the FNB out with costs like... Buying food! Other than that, the more important aspect of this benefit show is to inform others of FNB and all the great work the people involved with it do. It also may lead you to perhaps volunteer your time to Food Not Bombs. I'd say that would definitely be a great idea!

There will be four acts performing that night:

  • Team Awesome! (San Diego) - myspace.com/weareteamawesome
  • The Taxpayers (PDX) - myspace.com/thetaxpayers
  • Premise Beach (Tacoma) - myspace.com/premisebeach
  • My Parade (Seattle)
  • Sky Larkin (England) - myspace.com/skylarkinskylarkin

Some things that should be known about this show is not only is it a benefit but also the last show that Premise Beach will play. The two members of that band will be moving to separate parts of the east coast. Sky Larkin are from England. That's here. I think we should show them how awesome Seattle is and how amazing it is that they decided to play in our fair city.

The lineup for this show is great because they're not all local acts. Come, let's have fun, and eat food. Oh, did I mention that Food Not Bombs will be serving food for us?

It'll be great!

Love,

-Kenneth-

item.title: No Olympics on Stolen Native Land Speaking Tour - Nov. 10
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded:
No Olympics on Stolen Native Land Speaking Tour November 10th 7 PM Cascade People's Center (309 Pontius Ave N)

Resist 2010: Eight Reasons to Oppose the 2010 Winter Olympics. (LOW RES) from BurningFist Media on Vimeo.

As you may be aware, in February 2010, Vancouver (Canada) will be host city for the 2010 Winter Olympics. Due to the negative impacts of the Olympics, including homelessness, ecological destruction, huge public debt, and a greatly expanded police state, a movement has arisen to challenge the Olympic industry & expose to the world its true nature. Beginning in mid-November, 2009, organizers from No2010, an Indigenous anti-Olympics organization, will travel down the West Coast of the US to conduct a speaking tour on the resistance to the 2010 Olympics, to share their experiences, and to promote an anti-colonial & anti- capitalist convergence that will coincide with the opening days of the Games in February, 2010 (Feb. 10-15, the Olympic Games begin Feb. 12). Since 2007, No2010 has been a primary source of information on the anti-Olympic struggle, publishing almost daily news accounts, reports & updates. They have published several PDF/magazines, leaflets, posters, stickers, and t-shirts as well. In 2009, they produced a 15 minute video entitled Resist 2010. They are also part of the Olympic Resistance Network (ORN), which was established in 2008 and is comprised of numerous grassroots autonomous groups & individuals. The event will feature 1-2 speakers from No2010 and the Olympic Resistance Network, a short video, with time for questions and discussion. Speakers will also be available to do presentations at schools, universities, radio shows, etc., and to answer any inquiries from local media (corporate or alternative). For more info: www.No2010.com, www.OlympicResistance.net Event Sponsored by Common Action & Democracy Insurgent Flyer attached. Please post. Please Forward Widely! Bus Routes: 8, 25, 70-73, 74, 77, 79, 304, 317, 355, 377. Cascade People’s Center is wheelchair accessible. If you have any questions about accessibility or require any other accommodations, please call 206-612-2962 or E-mail lambert@riseup.net. If you require childcare call or Email and we will work to arrange it upon request.

item.title: Bloggers wanted!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Hey dear friends, We're looking to have more people writing on this blog about all the amazing events and projects that are going on in this fabulous city. Would you perhaps like to join in the fun? What we're looking for is people to write with some journalistic flair about events, activities, and projects in town that give more detail than the usual "time/location/cause" that we get on a calendar. We want to uncover the background, context, and detail that make up the DIY community. Specifically, we'd like to see more on this blog from different aspects of the movement - news about & from the DIY community, local sellers and craft community, underground hiphop, noise and improvisation, activism (especially of the anti-authoritarian kind), workshops and skill-shares, youth-led organizations and movements, reviews of past events, etc. If you're interested, register and make an account on this website (upper right side of the page, "register" link), and send us an email describing what you'd like to write about. Email us at sdiycollective at gmail dot com.

item.title: November News
item.dc:creator: NaNa
item.content:encoded:
Seattle has a new infoshop opening mid-November. The L@s Quixotes Infoshop and Lending Library will carry radical books and zines for check-out. They will be located at 219 Broadway, upstairs inside of Pilot Books. Check out www.losquixotesinfoshop.wordpress.com for updates and more information.
Thanksgiving is celebrated in the United States this year on November 26. While many people in the United States will be celebrating with friends and family, indigenous people throughout the country will gather in protest. Many travel to Alcatraz island for Unthanksgiving Day to honor indigenous peoples of the Americas and fight for their rights or participate in the New England National Day of Mourning to honor indigenous ancestors and the struggles of indigenous peoples today. So, on this day remember the land that you are on and how you got here.
November 11 is Veteran's Day. Right now the United States is involved in two major wars and has military deployed in more the 150 countries around the world. Some great work is being done by veterans against war at Coffee Strong, a G.I coffee house just outside the gates of Fort Lewis in Lakewood, WA. Their goal is to provide soldiers, their families and recent vets a place where they can learn about their rights, receive non-military counseling, access alternative information and learn about resources available to them. Check it out! www.myspace.com/coffeestrong
Last month SO many people came out for the Anarchist Bookfair. Thanks to the organizers so much working their asses off. The vendors were great but the workshops were amazing. Cannot wait for next year!
The Really, Really Free Market Festival will be held on Black Friday or Buy Nothing Day on November 27. On this day instead of buying all your presents for the holidays maybe you could come hang out with some folks downtown and pick up some free stuff. Free zines, workshops, buttons, theater and so much more. What is also great about this is that it falls so close to the 10th anniversary of the World Trade Organization (WTO) protests.
Speaking of the 10th anniversary of the WTO protests there will be a lot going. There will be a Week of Action from November 27-December 5. Look them up at seattleplus10.org for more information about the events of this week.
World Vegan Day is November 1. Get together and make a vegan meal with your friends, start a garden, do whatever you want to support this lifestyle of non-oppressive dining. Today is all about good food and good friends!
Do not forget to vote! Local elections actually matter, like for real. So, remember to mail-in your ballot. Approve Referendum 71 to keep the domestic partnership law that provides legal protections for lesbian and gay couples and seniors in committed relationships. Everyone deserves healthcare!

item.title: couch fest films is still looking for host houses
item.dc:creator: couchfestfilms
item.content:encoded:
Couch Fest Films is a shorts film fest hosted in strangers' houses all in one day in Seattle. We are currently still looking for a few more host houses for Nov 7th, 2009.  Do you like where you live? Do you like film? Do you like strangers? Well, why not open your residence to film loving strangers for couch fest films 2009? Share your unshakable fever for film with other compulsive cinephiles! Couch Fest Films is currently looking for Seattleites who are willing to open their home to host a short film program for this one day community film event. You could be an honored host of a 30-minute shorts film program that will play every hour from 11am to 7pm. If you are interested, email us: propaganda@couchfestfilms.com http://www.couchfestfilms.com/

couch fest films promo 1 from couch fest films on Vimeo.

item.title: show at fbk
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: The venerable and crusty punk house FBK (originally "the Fire Breathing Kangaroo" - just to be annoying and poke fun at the long history of dumb punk house names that everyone's lived at) has been hosting shows for a long time, and this is going to be a great cross section of some of the stuff that's gone on there. RVIVR is a rad pop punk band that blends east-coast style anthems with west coast sentimental sensibilities (think early Hot Water Music meets Jawbreaker) and also clearly rep their back-woods Olympia home in a way that makes it so I can't help but think about permaculture farms and home brew. Shamefully I'm not too familiar with Filth Matress, who I hear rule, but I'm also excited about The Witches Of, a two-piece that combines Bratmobile style guitar and singing with technical and dancey druming. This show will be all over the place, but definitely totally awesome.

item.title: Just around the corner, and not in Seattle (but close!): GenderJam!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Gender Jam: LAD.I.Y. & TRANS FEST OLYMPIA 2009 November 20th-22nd Downtown Olympia We don't normally post about things going on outside of Seattle, but maybe we should start giving some shout-outs to some regional DIY fun? Here's a great one: a festival in celebration of efforts to create a supportive and safer community for women, transfolks, and generqueer people, with workshops and performances by regional notables! If you plan on attending or participating you should be sure to read about their values and how you can support them in ways that they want to be supported, or just come to the evening shows at the Studio on November 20th (8 PM) and 21st (9 PM) and at Rainy Day Records on the 21st (1:30-4:30 PM). Visit their website for more info: http://olyladiyfest.wordpress.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: a couple seattle bands are playing, too!
The Saturday Rainy Day Records show has been moved to Last Word Books, just around the corner on 4th Ave. Same time, same performers, even more awesomeness.

item.title: ARCTIC CIRCLE EXPLODES
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
Let's face it. We all knew Arctic Circle was a lonely old powder keg down there in Georgetown, teetering toward its own destruction even as no one paid attention, because . . . you know, Georgetown's kind of far away, right? And finally, some spark or another has set things off, and we're breaking up like the fireworks we didn't set off on the 4th of July because . . . we don't believe in that shit, right?

BANG!

In one last brief flash of light on Friday, November 20th at 8 PM, come to 6633 Ellis Ave S for:

World History (message to land-dwellers: sing along)
Witches of . . . . (hit hard and fast)
Silhouettes (the humid breath of basking buzzards)
The Subtle Knife (for a limited engagement, related to Traitor)

Afterwards, the wind carries our embers in a few directions, all away from Georgetown. A piece lands in an organic farm in the southwest, some land on a boat and then gesture (far) south, a few more gather in the Central District. The breeze whispers rumors that we may still have a few sparks left in us, so don't mourn. Party.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: organic farms could actually save us from carcinogens and toxins';:

item.title: Really Really Free Market saturday is cancelled - attend the Really Really Free Festival on Friday instead!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: This Friday (yes, BLACK FRIDAY!!) there will be a celebration and gathering of folks to hang out and celebrate the free exchange of lovely and fun things, rather than partaking in the holiday consumer craze that happens every year on the day after Thanksgiving. Details are still forthcoming, so stay tuned. And on a side note, the Really Really Free Market that's been taking place at Pratt Park every last Saturday of the month will be postponed until January (or perhaps later). It's the cold season, and we'd like to get more organized before we get back into it. If you're in the area and on the look out for free groceries, you can attend the Food Not Bombs Saturday Free Market - "Each week, FNB members and individuals from Yesler Terrace -- a government housing complex -- collect food donated from local co-ops and distribute it at the Yesler Terrace Community Center (917 E Yesler Way) at noon. Occasionally other household goods are donated for distribution. Please contact seattle-fnb@riseup.net or call (206) 729-0384 if interested." (taken from seattle food not bombs webpage)

item.title: Want to be a collective member of Gallery 1412?
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded:
Hey all you friends of Gallery 1412! The gallery is currently seeking new members. If you have a need for space on a regular basis (or just for the short term), please consider becoming part of the 1412 collective. Collective members contribute monthly on a sliding scale for use of the space, and are invited to participate in the decision-making and day-to-day management of the gallery (though none of that is mandatory).
Gallery 1412 recently completed our 5th year as one of Seattle's great independent arts spaces. We see this project as an expression of real grassroots creativity and a way of building, maintaining and sharing resources and infrastructure that is independent of state and commercial interests. There have been plenty of ups, downs and near crises, and all along the core membership of the gallery is what has kept the space alive and available as a resource not just for ourselves but for the community at large.
Please read on below for an overview of our membership rates, and let us know any questions you have. We'd love to hear what you're working on and what your space and time needs are.
Thanks, and take care! -wilson, for the gallery 1412 collective gallery1412.org info @ gallery1412 . org
ps: please pass this along to folks who might be interested!
Membership rates:
--for artists who are only interested in rehearsal and/or teaching space, we ask $60-80 monthly.
--for artists who intend to use the gallery for performances, we ask $80-100.
--for groups or organizations who want to join collectively, we ask $80-100 and $100-120, respectively, for uses as stated above.
--we are willing to negotiate alternative arrangements for folks with special circumstances. just ask.

item.title: repost: Three days of community events at Hidmo
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Ladies First – a project of CARA (Communities Against Rape & Abuse) Every First Saturday of the month at Hidmo 8PM Open Mic / 9PM Features / all ages free (donation) Saturday Dec 5th features: Geneiva Arunga Sista Hailstorm & dj Miss Broadway Peace and Light, CARA Community. Looking for some fire and spice to set a strong year’s end? Join us for the 2009’s final Ladies First THIS coming Saturday. It will be a night of mind opening inspiration with features Geneiva Arunga and Sista Hailstorm with dj Miss Broadway on the decks. Please encourage sister friends to come get on the open-mic @ 8pm; or sister crafts/artists to bring their work to the open marketplace. This Saturday’s featured artists: Geneiva Arunga is a gifted young artist, community organizer and scholar wise beyond her years. Her poetry is truthful and unapologetic utilizing art as a platform to open minds and initiate change. As a youth activist, Geneiva is involved with a number of organizations within the Seattle area. Sista Hailstorm has spent much time over the past several years traveling around the world ripping up stages. A powerful visionary and deeply rounded artist, her style and voice bring new energy to a revolutionary movement. Her work consciously touches the restoring of balance; healing; and training the strongest physical, mental and spiritual self. DJ Miss Broadway started deejaying in the mid-90’s on pirate radio, house parties, and local fund raisers using cassette tapes and vinyl. She has been deejaying at Seattle dance clubs and bars since 2001 using vinyl, playing music of all sorts, mainly from the 1960’s – the 1990’s. DJ Miss Broadway has the most fun spinnin’ Underground Hip Hop and Disco, though her heart is mainly with Jazz. -------------------------- Poplife Pop Life Community Readings Kicks off THIS Sunday December 6 5pm / All Ages $3 _________________________ Open conversations about texts selected for the neighborhood by Charles Tonderai Mudede. FIRST SESSION: Reading from Spinoza’s Ethics: Proposition 14 to Proposition 20 Find readings and session notes online . Follow @poplifereadings on Twitter for updates. Come. Participate. NEXT SESSION: The City of the Imagination 5pm Sunday, Dccember 20 Reading “The Swan” by Charles Baudelaire Will discuss the human body, urban space, the city as memory storage, and connect all of this to the difference between biological evolution and cultural evolution. --------------------- ">S.O.S : Safety for Our Streets Monday December 7th 6:00pm to 8:00pm at Garfield Community Center (2323 East Cherry Street) open to all ages / free childcare & appetizers provided Clothesline Project Greetings Hidmo Friends, Family, and Community Partners: We have been steadily planning the next Hidmo Community Empowerment Project Forum and would like to invite everyone in the community to take part! SOS will be an interactive discussion designed to engage individuals in various ways about safety in the Central District. The forum will be the culmination of Hidmo CEP’s “The Central District Clothesline Project”. Historically, the Clothesline Project was a way for women to use t-shirts and a clothesline to testify about violence that happens to them and their community, or that of someone they knew. You can find out more history at http://www.clotheslineproject.org/History.html. We are expanding this concept to all residents and members of the community, and are partnering with Central District businesses, residents, churches and schools to advocate for safety, in all its forms, within our community. The anonymous T-shirts will be made at Central District community hubs all week long. To find a location to make a shirt visit www.hidmo.org or stop by Hidmo (2000 S. Jackson Street) where we will be making shirts Dec 1st – 4th from 5:30 to 7:00pm. This neighborhood-wide effort is unique in that it seeks to bring together a community stratified, and often fragmented, by our differences. The overall goal of the forum is to continue the work that we are all doing to get to know each other better, to feel safer in our neighborhood and to empower our community. For more information or questions about the upcoming forum or the Hidmo Community Empowerment Project please contact Jason Davison at jason@hidmo.org or 206-328-7088

item.title: December events at the Zine Archive and Publishing Project!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Hello Friends of ZAPP! We wanted to let you know about a few things that are going on in December. First up is Write-o-Rama this Saturday, December 5. Unfortunately ZAPP will be closed to the public but only because we are having an amazing mini-zine workshop as part of the fun. This workshop is being taught by our own ZAPP Interns Bryan and Cambray. To find out more about Write-o-Rama you can visit www.hugohouse.org. Capital Hill Artwalk Thursday, December 10th at ZAPP: Ian Furgeson will be closing his show. He will be there to sell his posters and t-shirts from 5pm-8pm. http://www.hugohouse.org/content/zapp-gallery Calling all Volunteers! Monday, December 14 is the Volunteer Orientationfor Hugo House and ZAPP. If you're interested in learning more about Hugo House and/or ZAPP stop by at 6pm and hang out for a bit, we need your help in 2010. We have Open Hour shifts, zine reviews, zine research.... On Wednesday December 16 we're hosting Lightning Hours in ZAPPand the Member Library. This is time for you (yes you!) to come in and use all the cool materials we have at ZAPP to make or finish that zine you've been talking about. We'll be open for Lightning Hours from4pm-9pm. Remember we have typewriters, long-armed staplers and a light table for you to use! ZAPP is hosting a free workshopon Stamps and Image Transfer on Saturday December 19. Come and learn how to stamp and transfer images for an amazing and unique cover for your zine or project. http://www.hugohouse.org/content/zapp-classes 2 new ZAPP internships are now posted so spread the word: http://www.hugohouse.org/content/zapp-community-outreach-intern http://www.hugohouse.org/content/zine-archives-intern Hope to see you soon! ZAPP

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yeah, come out and participate in a scab-run, stolen zine library event!

item.title: Squaredancing at the lakeside Collective! Friday December 11th

item.content:encoded:
Here's a great event that I was just asked to repost by one of the fantastic people at the Lakeside Collective!
"Are you letting a bad middle school dance experience effect your image of square dancing? stop it!
Dust off your dancing shoes and shake your tail feathers to the henhouse rounders, al pastor and the bac-o-bits. Calling by jordan ruyle, gabe strand, maggie lind, and amy hofer.
Friday December 11th potlucking at 7, dancing at 8
all ages, skill levels and peoples welcome.
at the Lakeside Collective 11748 Lakeside Ave. NE Just off of the Burke Gilman, the 75, the 41, the 522, the 72 and the 65."

item.title: Swap it. Spin it. Bring it. Screen it. This weekend!!!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: THE VERA PROJECT and HOLLOW EARTH RADIO Present Swap it. Spin it. Bring it. Screen it. A DIY Holiday Fair and Fundraiser Featuring Northwest Labels, Crafters, Local Record Dealers, Print Artists & Zinemakers When: Saturday December 12th 2009, 11am-5pm Where: The Vera Project, Warren & Republican Ave N, at Seattle Center, Seattle, WA Website: www.theveraproject.org , www.hollowearthradio.com On December 12th, The Vera Project, Seattle’s non-profit, all-ages music and arts venue, and Hollow Earth Radio, Seattle’s premier online independent radio station, are joining forces to host a one-of-a-kind fundraiser and holiday extravaganza: Swap It. Spin It. Bring It. Screen It. The Vera Project is transforming into a marketplace for independent music and crafts, along with live music, and interactive silkscreening. All proceeds help support music, art presentation, and arts education through the Vera Project and Hollow Earth Radio. The DIY marketplace will feature independent Northwest record and cassette labels, musicians, silk-screened show posters, vintage record dealers, local artists, craft-makers, and designers selling their wares throughout Vera’s venue. This is the perfect opportunity to find a one-of-a-kind gift just in time for the holidays. The event will also include live musical performances by Northwest musicians, Hollow Earth DJs spinning on site, a bake sale, a raffle for hand-printed posters, and much much more! Original Vera Project logos will be designed by 10 local designers and made available to the public to silkscreen. No experience is necessary to silkscreen, and for just $5 a print, Vera silkscreen instructors will help attendees print one of the logos on any fabric item they bring; blank shirts will also be available for purchase. Following the event, the Vera Project logo designs will tour participating Café Vita locations throughout 2009, with prints available for purchase. Come join us for an opportunity to enjoy and support the Seattle art and music community! Interested designers and vendors should contact Sara Brickman and Amber Morgan at diyholidayfair@gmail.com or call (206) 956-8372 for more information. ALSO: come to see performances by: Dashel Schueler, The June Madrona, World History, 1985, iji, The Foghorns

item.title: Always all-ages: supporting youth-driven spaces in every 'hood
item.dc:creator: tsarina
item.content:encoded:
With 2010 fast approaching, I have a new year resolution I'd like to share with all you fine folks.

All over the country, there are basements, grange halls, teen centers, warehouses, back rooms of pizza shops, living rooms and converted store-fronts where people gather for shows. Like SDIY, youth-driven spaces work on the belief that young people are more than just consumers of culture: they're the creators, too. Some of these are organized by a dedicated collective, but most of them don't exist in a city like Seattle where the battle over all-ages music has already been waged, and a permanent venue like The Vera Project exists. But each year, many of them will have to close in the face of scared local governments, police, and a lack of resources.

That's why in 2005, Vera, Music For America (now defunct), Youth Movement Records and Youth Speaks SF came together to form the All-Ages Movement Project. Though our organizations are all very different, we envisioned a national network of like-minded organizations that would share the best practices, inspiration, models; a culture where young people, whether the performers or the fans, never have to hear, "sorry, this show is 21+."

Currently, AMP functions as an online directory of existing all-ages projects around the country, and a resource for folks who want to start their own project, and need advice for keeping an all-ages venue alive. In early 2010, AMP will also publish In Every Town: An All Ages Music Manualfesto: documentation of the ways that people in different cities have created space for young people in the music community, as well as a guide for everyone else who wants to do it.

My resolution for 2010 is thus: I've pledged $10 a month to both Vera and AMP, because I can't imagine what my life would have been like without all-ages shows. And to celebrate the release of the AMP manualfesto, I'm going to highlight all-ages and youth-driven spaces here on the SDIY blog. I'll donate $10 to these projects, and I challenge you to do the same.

Only we know what the true value of always all-ages music and art is in our communities. Ten dollars might not seem like much, but at the same time, when you're young, unemployed, or struggling from paycheck to paycheck, $10 can be a pretty significant donation. And to a small arts organization, or a collective working under the radar, it can also mean a whole lot. Giving young people the access and skills to produce music is more than just an after-school art project. It's a political statement against the way youth culture is represented in mass media.

SeattleDIY has always focused on building and promoting the DIY projects, ethos and communities in our little wet city. But like AMP, we can also be a platform for spreading that momentum out. To build a culture that values art and music, that supports the places and the projects that bring that music to life, and fuels do-it-yourself and do-it-together action.

Trial were probably talking about the straightedge hardcore community, but I found it pretty applicable when they said, "Make this a movement again, instead of only a scene."

If you want to get in touch with me about this, hit me up at: parkranger[at]gmail[dot]com. And for full disclosure: I'm a paid grantwriter at Vera, and we share office-space with AMP.

item.title: Large, Hairy and Literate: Zinesters and Artists Celebrate Bigfoot
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I just read about this on Profanity Hill (http://profanityhill.blogspot.com/), a new blog about local Seattle zine culture, as well as an online distro for zines. This blog is super exciting, and is a must-read for people who want to get more connected to the resurgence of zine culture. If anyone wants to share other local/northwest zine distros, leave a comment about it (Ms Valerie Park Distro is another great one that I can think of off the top of my head). Anyway, here's the event that was mentioned on Profanity Hill: -------------------- Large, Hairy and Literate: Zinesters and Artists Celebrate Bigfoot Thursday, January 14, 5–8 p.m. in ZAPP (at the Richard Hugo House) Well before "Harry and the Hendersons" hit the big screen, the Pacific Northwest has had an obsession with Bigfoot, beginning with Lummi tales of ape-like, cannibalistic wildmen to the Sonics' former fur-balled mascot, Squatch. Continuing the legacy, ZAPP presents a group exhibit featuring new work that draws upon both visual and literary interpretations of Bigfoot lore by local artists David Lasky, Kinoko, Kelly Froh, Greg Hofmann and Darin Shuler, among others, in conjunction with Blitz!: Capitol Hill's Art Walk. In addition to the exhibit, ZAPP will showcase zines and comics from the archive that focus on tales or histories of the Bigfoot phenomenon in the Pacific Northwest. Visitors are encouraged to donate their own Bigfoot zines or comics and are invited to participate in on-site drawing and storytelling. For more information about the ZAPP gallery, email zapp@hugohouse.org.

item.title: Broken Water, Hornet Leg, Witches of..., My Parade at 2020 Cycles
item.dc:creator: Asian Cajun
item.content:encoded:
Ever see a place of business morph into a DIY, all ages showspace?  It's a beautiful transformation.  Coffee shops and pizza joints just move their tables a bit to make room.   At 2020 Cycles they move completed bicycles, racks of parts, tools and machinery out of the way and the display window suddenly becomes a performance stage.  Voila, DIY all ages venue!

Unfortunately, Grass Widow had to cancel due to dire circumstances.  However, the lineup is still solid.  Broken Water from Olympia brings their wall of sound to haunt your soul.  Hornet Leg's (also from Olympia) minimalist garage blues is just what the doctor ordered.  Local band, Witches of... will make you wish you were still a Riot Grrl in 1992.  My Parade (also local) will bring their all POC dance punk party making you want to test out your new dance moves you've been doing in the mirror.  Don't miss it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: too bad about grass widow! oh shit, hornet leg!!!!!!!!!!

item.title: Tonight at New Crompton (01-14-2010)
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
Tonight, at the New Crompton, we have some fine acts to present you with:

  • iji
  • Jason Clackly
  • Jehova's Fitness (san diego)
  • Koalacaust (san-town bay)
  • Cowlick (0.5 of Junk Bones)

Jason Clackly! You know, the fellow with the huge beard, punk-as-fuck, never needs a mic, who is also a gentlemanly scholar and sweetheart? That fellow.

Here's what I've heard: Jason Clackly has a full band. That it's brilliant and amplifies everything great about Jason's songwriting, complimenting the emotional intensity of each song. This is what I've heard and what I'm going to see tonight.

I've never seen iji perform before but from what I've listened to, it's brilliant.

Come over this evening; have fun, see your friends, make new friends, and for the love of your ears- bring earplugs. This is going to be a very loud three hours. Please, bring money to support our touring friends from California- Jehova's Fitness and Koalacaust.

New Crompton
4711 12th Ave NE
Seattle, WA 98105

Love,

-Kenneth-

item.title: Nana Grizol / Pre-Show Arts, Crafts, Baking
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
This Tuesday (January, 19th) will be a very fantastic show at the Vera Project featuring these stellar acts:

  • Nana Grizol
  • The Max Levine Ensemble
  • iji
  • A Million Years ago
Last time Nana Grizol was in town (if I recall correctly), it was done as a small Pacific Northwest tour with backing band and tour partners Your Heart Breaks. These shows were played mostly in houses. The time before that Nana Grizol was on tour with a fabulous band called The Music Tapes. That time The Music Tapes were his backing band and it was glorious. This time I'm just assuming that whoever is in The Max Levine Ensemble / Nana Grizol are each others backing bands and so on... Coming from many years of being a part of concert band (in my more youthful days) I always feel like it's a pleasure and rare experience a full band incorporated with horns. More so, I feel that incredibly strong lyrical emotions coupled with an emphasizing horn line is even more of a rare sight. You don't want to show up late for this show- each band is absolutely fantastic. Also...

Before this show from 12:00 - 7:00 we will be having an arts & crafts baking gathering / assembly / party / whatever you call it... We call it "Get Hella Baked with Quality Papers." It's a baking, stationary, arts and crafts group.

Last Sunday when we did this there was band practice and jamming out upstairs and mega crafts downstairs. We also found a videotape of a funeral taken in the Philippines at the Goodwill Bins that we put on in the background.

If the weather's fine, the plan is to assemble a bike posse to trek to the Vera in time for the show. We have an art closet with a some supplies but it's encouraged to bring your own in case we don't have it. We have a kitchen with spices, sugar, flour, and fluids but we're not sure if our ingredients will meet your baking needs. We do have cupcake pans though.

Pet Seminary 4531 5th Ave NE Seattle, WA 98105

Love,

-Kenneth-

item.title: Author Shon Meckfessel this Saturday (1-23) at Left Bank Books!
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Shon Meckfessel, (local) author of Suffled How It Gush: A North American Anarchist in the Balkans will be speaking and reading at Left Bank Books, your local anarchist collective bookstore, on Saturday, January 23rd at 7 PM.  Come out and learn about the Balkans and anarchism! Left Bank Books is located at 92 Pike Street on the corner of First and Pike, right at the entrance of the Pike Place Market. "Shon Meckfessel bathes in undercurrent discourses and points us to Balkan dynamics contradicting the nationalist loyalties that distort people's lives. Rather than making ethnic claims or endorsing any hierarchy, he clarifies existing struggles against states and points toward a region free of domination." —George Katsiaficas, activist and author of Subversion of Politics: European Autonomous Social Movements and the Decolonization of Everyday Life SEE YOU SATURDAY!

item.title: Tonite: Nana Grizol, iji, Max Levigne Ens, A Million Yrs Ago @ Vera: Just GO!
item.dc:creator: moo
item.content:encoded:
Nana Grizol is playing the Vera tonight. If you're reading this, drop everything and get over there! Mastermind Theo Zumm writes lyrics entwined with melody, thrashed by raw power. They'll uplift, get your ass dancing, and leave you euphoric. Don't miss this chance to see what life will be like in the future perfect. Plus they're touring with the Max Levigne Ensemble.. They also play with iji and A Mllion Years Ago. Iji is the perfect band to play with the Griz tonite, they're basically the local version, in Nana Grizol's own words: "Just a bunch of friends having the most fun possible", plus they keep it horny...
I really can't stress enough the importance of realizing the scope of vision in the way that these kids bring it alive. Okay, enough words: NOW, PEOPLE, MOVE!

item.title: New Crompton Needs a Roommate
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
Here's a really important message from Matt "Comma" Fu:
...so we just had a wonderful roommate move on to the Sherwood collective and now we are looking for someone to fill her space on Feb 1st. We are a DIY venue and event space in the U-Disrict, looking forward to a bountiful spring filled with new ideas for the house including a music and lit library, workshops and classes, gardens and more! New Crompton is on 47th and 12th and you would be moving into the biggest room in this big spacious house! Or lease goes till middle of the summer. We are all fun-loving and easy going and excited for the spring and summer months of productivity! Rent is about average for the u-district and will depend on how much space and storage you want. shoot me an email [masa@resist.ca] if you are interested! or text me on my phone (calling doesnt work so well): xxx.xxx.xxxx love comma matt fu
It's a house full of really good hearted people, for good hearted people. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption="A New Crompton BBQ of Spring 2009"][/caption] Yeah! -Kenneth-

item.title: Bring Out Your Brass! A benefit concert and auction for Honk Fest West
item.dc:creator: BlackBox
item.content:encoded: The Honk Fest West Benefit! For the last two years, Honk Fest West has put marching bands, samba lines, horn players, drum corps, and every manner of rhythmic and melodic noisemaker we could find right where they belong: in the Seattle streets. And in 2010, we’re doing it again and bigger, as we bring the lively sounds of 23 bands from across the United States here for the third annual HONK! FEST! WEST! Our upcoming Benefit on Saturday, January 30 helps raise funds to offset these bands’ travel expenses. When: 8pm‐2am, Saturday January 30, 2010 Where: Underground Events Center, 2407 1st Ave (between Battery St & Wall St), Seattle, WA Cost: $10‐20 (sliding scale donation) The following bands will be working their magic throughout the evening: Orkestar Zirkonium (http://www.orkestarzirkonium.com/) is a mobile fourteen‐piece brass‐punk band that borrows the performative style and Balkan/klezmer‐influenced sounds from the greats of the Roma tradition, plunging into crowds and galvanizing joyous derangement in every time signature. Reptet (http://www.reptet.com/) is a genre bending band consisting of drums, bass and four horns, performing original compositions that incorporate reggae, rock, ska, punk, modern classical, avant garde, eastern European folk influences and more. Titanium Sporkestra (http://titaniumsporkestra.com/) features ex‐members of the Infernal Noise Brigade and legendary Seattle band TchKunG!, and delivers a blend of heavy world drumming and traditional drum line music, tweaked just a little and turned up to 11. Tubaluba (http://www.myspace.com/tubalubabrassband) mixes New Orleans jazz, funky times, blues for the soul, and groovy world sounds into beautiful music that makes you shake your booty and clap your hands. Yellow Hat Band (http://www.yellowhatband.org) plays loud, fun music from all over the world, turning any room they occupy into an irresistible dance party. In addition to our full band line‐up, we’ll also be holding an auction, accepting donations, and running a cash bar. This year's HonkFestWest will occur across the city from Friday April 9, 2010 through Sunday April 11, 2010. Stay tuned for more details. For more information, and pictures and videos from previous years, please visit honkfestwest.com For press inquiries, please contact Tyson Lynn at tyson.lynn@gmail.com or 425.879.6391.
item.excerpt:encoded: Orkestar Zirkonium, Reptet, Titanium Sporkestra, Tubaluba, and Yellow Hat Band play the HonkFestWest Benefit show at the Underground Events Center on Saturday, January 30.

item.title: January News for the local DIY community!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: SECRET CAFE! Do you love books and zines? Spaces for diy culture? How about non-hierarchical and anti-authoritarian organizing? What about eating delicious food with friends in support of all this? On Sunday, February 14th, SeattleDIY is putting on a secret cafe to support our collective work, and the new L@s Quixotes Infoshop/Lending Library in Seattle! SDIY will be serving up a hot dish of lovin' along with a smoothie bar (!), sweet jamz, photobooth, dancing, and plenty of information on the infoshop and our favorite diy projects in Seattle. Look inside the newsletter for the full details, and send an email to sdiycollective[at]gmail[dot]com to reserve your seat. FREE FOR ALL The Really Really Free Market is back in action! We took a little break over the winter, but as of January 30th, we will be in Pratt Park every last Saturday from 12pm to 4pm to hang out and share things and skills. Nothing at the free market is for trade or barter - it's really free! We're also always looking for friendly folks to spread the word, bring food and hot drinks, and help us cart everything away at the end of the day. We would also like to give a shout out to all the Food Not Bombs free markets around town that distribute groceries every weekend - listed in the Regular Events. HUNTING FOR BIGFOOT The SeattleDIY Collective is going on a retreat! On February 20th and 21st, we will be hanging out in a cabin in Sasquatch territory to talk about our mission, the projects we have going on, what we want to be doing in the next year and tell spooky stories. This also means there will be no meeting at Healthy Times on Sunday the 21st, because we'll probably be driving back... If you have any thoughts or suggestions, this is a great time to tell us! LONG LIVE ALL-AGES MUSIC We would also like to bid a fond farewell to the Department of Safety, our northerly neighbors in Anacortes, Washington. After eight lovely years of shows, artist residencies and po-mo-festos, the DoS held their farewell ceremony on January 30th 2010. Though we're sad to see an all-ages stronghold go, we look forward to what the members will do next. And hey - here a benefit event for ZAPP at Fantagraphics Books: This Saturday, January 30, 6-9 p.m., Fantagraphics Books presents the release party for "NEWAVE! Underground Mini Comix of the 1980s," a new book compiling self-published mini-comics of the '70s and '80s, at their store in Georgetown. For every copy of "NEWAVE!" sold at the party, Michael Dowers, the book's editor, will donate $3 to ZAPP. The "NEWAVE!" release party features original artwork from Jaimie Alder, Jim Blanchard, Wayne Gibson, David Lasky, Wayno, Steve Willis, Dennis Worden and XNO. Dowers, mini-comics creator and former editor of Starhead Comix and Fantagraphics Books, will be creating and distributing a mini-comic on site. Plus, an allstar comics jam with music by hot Seattle indie rockers Iji. For more info, visit the Fantagraphics Web site. ----------------------- have more news about community events or goings-on? Email us at sdiycollective[at]gmail[dot]com or leave a comment here!

item.title: Mythmakers and Lawbreakers: Anarchists and Fiction at Left Bank
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
Margaret Killjoy, editor of Mythmakers and Lawbreakers, will be reading and talking at Left Bank Books on Friday, January 29th at 7 PM. Left Bank is at 92 Pike Street, on the corner of Pike and 1st, at the entrance of the Pike Place Market. From Killjoy's blog:
A brief and arguably entertaining evening with Margaret Killjoy, editor of Mythmakers & Lawbreakers. Discuss the role of storytelling in the anarchist movement! Learn about novelist assassins, post-colonial African squatters, writers who fought in revolutions and went on to write childrens’ stories! Find out what Tolkien, Camus, Orwell, and Kafka have to say about anarchism! January
From AK Press (on the book):
The best fiction has always been a little...dangerous. For centuries, authors have used the veil of fiction to cast a critical eye toward the larger society around them: think of Emile Zola, Victor Hugo, Issac Asimov, Margaret Atwood, Aldous Huxley, J.R.R. Tolkien, H.G. Wells, Mary Shelley, and beyond. And now, for the first time, some of the biggest names in contemporary fiction discuss the endless possibilities of the world of fiction with a specific focus on anarchist politics. In a series of interviews with SteamPunk Magazine founder Margaret Killjoy, Ursula K. Le Guin, Alan Moore, Lewis Shiner, Starhawk, Derrick Jensen, Cristy C. Road, Michael Moorcock, and a variety of other up-and-coming young writers reflect on the ways in which their personal politics have shaped their work. Plus, a fantastic introduction by best-selling sci-fi author Kim Stanley Robinson!
Be there!

item.title: Arts & Crafts & Baking & Work Party

get hella baked with quality papers

Pet Seminary 4531 5th Ave NE Seattle, WA 98105 e-mail me if you have any questions: thekennethfoundation@gmail.com Love, -Kenneth-

item.title: TONIGHT at the New Crompton [hint: amazing] (2/13)
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
Tonight at the New Crompton, there are three absolutely-fantastic touring acts performing along with a very lovely local act of our own
  • OK Vancouver OK (Vancouver, BC Canadia)
  • Collapsing Opposties (Vancouver, BC Canadia)
  • Hermit Thrushes (Philadelphia)
  • iji (Seattle, duh!)
I can say that this will be one of the great shows at the New Crompton since the beginning of this calendar year of two-thousand and ten.

New Crompton 4711 12th Ave NE Seattle, WA 98105

Most definitely will be a great night. I'd say something witty but I have to get back to making acrylic ink and a poster. Arts & Crafts Fun Fact: Rather than spending $3 on 1 Fluid Oz of acrylic ink, you can make it from scratch with some gloss medium, water, and acrylic paint. 50:50 water:paint but in the 50 parts water you might actually make it a 20:30 ratio where 20 is gloss medium. It depends on how satisfied you are with the consistency of the acrylic ink that you just made. Love, -Kenneth-

item.title: Support Left Bank Books right now!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Left Bank Books Could Use Your Help, via Slog The Stranger put up a blog post about how Left Bank Books could use a little help these days. It's true! They could absolutely use more business right now. On Thursday there will be a great all-ages show at Cafe Racer in the U-District that will benefit Left Bank Books. It'll be 21+ with ID, and includes a kissing booth, bands, and who knows what other shenanigans. Here's what The Stranger posted: "Slog tipper Chris Estey wanted us to know that bookselling collective Left Bank Books in the Pike Place Market could use your support right now. Here's the situation: The Market Preservation & Development Authority (PDA) is overseeing renovations in the Market for earthquake preparedness. As a result, certain businesses—including Left Bank Books—will have to temporarily close for an estimated three months this fall while the renovations are taking place. I just talked with Jamie Menzel at Left Bank about this and while she wanted to emphasize that the PDA has been working with the businesses to ensure that the financial impact will be as negligible as possible (that's why, for instance, the store is closing in the fall and not the busy summer months, and rent will be pro-rated for the months of the closure), the store could use some love right now. There won't be any revenue coming in while the store is closed, but publishers will still need to be paid for the books they've already sent. The Left Bank collective will be holding meetings to figure out the best way to raise money to cover the invoices that will come in during the closure, but you could help immediately by giving Left Bank your business right now and, especially, buying gift certificates. The gift certificates will serve as a kind of bond for future investment in the bookstore. I love Left Bank for their unapologetically radical anarchist selection of zines and books, and for the fact that it's completely volunteer-run. They could use the help of a few good neighbors right now. UPDATE: James Haydu, the Director of Communications for Pike Place Market PDA just called me back. He says that while phase 2 of the seismic upgrades for the market will be beginning in the fall, renovations to Left Bank Books probably won't take place until the spring of 2011. He says the PDA will work with Left Bank Books to find a temporary space for Left Bank if the upgrades will take more than three weeks. I'll keep you posted as the story develops."

item.title: Solidarity is FUN.
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Seattle Solidarity is a volunteer network of working people who believe in standing up for our rights. Our goal is to support our fellow workers' strikes and struggles, build solidarity, and organize to deal with specific job, housing, and other problems caused by the greed of the rich and powerful. The Seattle Solidarity Network has been battling with a local real estate company (Lorig & Associates) and, as a result, Lorig has filed a lawsuit. They are attempting to silence the network, so they can continue "enhancing communities" (read "catering to rich, white people, while pushing around anyone who gets in their way"). Help them raise some cash for legal fees! They're a completely volunteer-run group & could really use your support. Saturday, February 27 The Big House (a large house in Capitol Hill - email bighouse@dodiy.org & ask for the address) 8:00PM MUSIC BY: Megabog Thousands Joe Martin Wet Paint The Greatest Place To (The Pica Beats CANCELLED) $8 at the door goes directly to Seattle Solidarity. NOTE FOR EVERYONE: Everyone will enter through the back door & it is wheelchair accessible. Only the basement (where most of the music will happen) is wheelchair accessible. Please be kind to people with chemical & scent sensitivies - Please Don't Wear Scented Deodorant or Perfumes & Don't Smoke Near The Non-Smokers. We're trying to make this event accessible to as many people as we can, so please send an email to bighouse@dodiy.org if you need any accommodations. Also Read This: www.scn.org/activism/calendar/disabilities.html

item.title: Really Really Free Market, Saturday Feb. 27th!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: We're baaaack! You thought the Really Really Free Market was lost and gone forever, didn't you? You thought it had been washed away by the cold winter rains (er, mild winter sun) of Seattle's most brutal season? Well, think again! The Really Really Free Market is actually REALLY really happening tomorrow! rain or freaking shine. the details: Come join us at Pratt Park (on 20th between Yesler and Jackson in the Central Area)! RRFM organizers will be there from noon to 4pm, but really it all depends on YOUR participation. This is how it works: bring your freebox! Clothes, movies, music, house goods, snacks, shoes, whatever else that you no longer need and think someone might be able to use. Why buy new things when there is so much extra stuff just floating around our community? Everything is totally free, bring what you don't want anymore, take away new finds. At the end of the day someone will scoop up everything left over and take it down to be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. It's like the biggest free box of your dreams! Look for us tomorrow, you'll see picnic tables covered with stuff (or if it's raining, look for us under the covered area. See you there!

item.title: “Through This Window,” A Quarterly Webzine, Is Launching
item.dc:creator: Through This Window
item.content:encoded: Through This Window is a new quarterly collaborative web-based multimedia project created by a small group of artist friends here in Seattle. Every three months they aim to release a new installment around a unique and interesting theme or subject, exploring it from/through a wide range of points of view, mediums, and medias. There are three main components to the website and project:  1) A significant video component, which might be compared to a short visual version of This American Life with a Northwest bent. Each theme/subject will be treated with multiple stories or angles in a variety of mediums or medias: interviews, poetry, fictional narrative shorts, music, animation, audio collages, etc.  2) The next essential aspect of each month's release is the webzine portion. It's aim is to complement and provide context for the video portion while providing an opportunity to post photographs, writing, paintings and/or other art in a standalone way, while contributing to a fuller story around the installment's theme/subject.  3) The interactive component: There will be an open online gallery of submitted work for anybody to participate in the exploration of that installment's theme/subject. It will remain open for submissions of all kinds indefinitely. You might compare this part of TTW to Miranda July's "Learning To Love You More" project/website (that's now, unfortunately, done.) On March 1st, the first installment will be released to the world via the project website. It is called "Unemployed!" and features a wide range of writing and art, including a short story from Ryan Boudinot, author of "Misconception" and "The Littlest Hitler," a video interview/documentary with/about Aaron Heideman of the "Man In A Van Project", animation, paintings, poetry, a comic, an interactive game, and more. TTW is currently accepting submissions of all kinds for the next installment, titled “Unrequited Love.” The deadline is May 15, 2010 and it will be released officially on June 1st. Check out the official site at http://www.ThroughThisWindow.com ... it'll be changing pretty drastically on the 1st. Become a fan on facebook: http://www.facebook.com/throughthiswindow

item.title: Alleycat Acres Urban Farming Work Party This Sunday (2/28/10)
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Alleycat Acres Urban Farming Work Party This Sunday This Sunday, the members of Seattle's newest urban farming collective need your help to create their first farm. The team behind Alleycat Acres would like to invite 30 volunteers to Beacon Hill to come help dig, till and build on February 28. The nonprofit organization recently acquired a fifth of an acre of donated, underused space near the Jefferson Park Golf Course, and has already started preparing it to be their first in a collection of neighborhood-focused urban farms. From soil specialists to landscape architects, bike enthusiasts to community organizers, the group's members bring a wide variety of skills to the field. With their diverse toolbox of knowledge and connections, the Alleycat Acres collective aims to serve the food insecure. Alleycat Acres operates on the belief that everyone, regardless of financial status, should have the opportunity to eat healthy food. The organization plans to take demographic data and community suggestions into consideration before choosing what seeds to plant. Once they get growing, the collective's members will be delivering produce by bicycle to the neighborhoods in which their farms are located. Produce will be available through CSA, local farmers' markets and eventually in neighborhood corner stores. In the meantime, Alleycat Acres is looking to partner with more local landowners and volunteers to increase their growing power. To attend the Alleycat's first work party this Sunday, Feb. 28, please email info@alleycatacres.com. Space is limited, so please send your volunteer request today: including your name, phone number and hours available. Work party shifts will be from 9 am to 12 pm, 1 pm to 4 pm. If you would like to view the garden or ask questions, please stop by at any time. Getting to the Beacon Hill location by public transportation is efficient and low cost; please ask for suggestions. Further details will be sent to you after your request is received. For more information or to sign up for the newsletter, please visit http://www.alleycatacres.com/. About Alleycat Acres Alleycat Acres is a 501(c)3 organization, fiscally sponsored through Sustainable Seattle. All donations are tax deductible. The group is always looking to develop relationships with community members and organizations. If you would like to volunteer with Alleycats, offer your vacant or unused spaces for farmland or donate tools, seeds, soil or money, please email sean@alleycatacres.com. ### Media Contact Sarah Kuck 360-393-9713 sarah@alleycatacres.com

item.title: BICYCLE! BICYCLE!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Whoa. On Boing Boing! (a great blog), they posted that Google Maps now includes the ability to find directions for bikes. While this is great news for us bicyclists, what are other non-google options for finding the best ways of getting around town on our noble steeds? Well, lookie here: http://www.cityofseattle.net/transportation/bikemaps.htm and here: http://www.cascade.org/community/maps_routes.cfm From Boing Boing: "Bicycle" is now an option for mode of transport in Google maps. Ostensibly, the directions given will help you avoid particularly nasty car traffic and particularly disheartening elevation changes, though Treehugger found some kinks in that when they tried to plot a route across San Francisco. There's not enough uphill slogs in Minneapolis (and I don't know St. Paul well enough) to get you a real solid second opinion from the Twin Cities. But it was smart enough to not send theoretical me biking straight up the feels-like-45-degree incline of 14th street when asked for directions to the University of Kansas journalism school (see above). It also shows dedicated bike trails and bike lanes, to help plan the trip. How's this work for your hometown? Of course, a great DIY community resource that we can't get enough of is The Bikery. They're seriously awesome, for a million reasons. They have a few classes coming up: Wheels Class - Sundays, March 7th & March 14th from noon-2pm Ever wondered what makes up a wheel? Pondered what "truing" is all about? Want the ability to build up a set of wheels? Well all these answers and more will be covered in this two day wheels class! So come one come all and we'll really get you rolling. Ba-dum-bum!! (Attending both sessions in suggested.) Getting Back in the Saddle - March 21st from noon-2pm Haven't ridden a bike since you were a kid, but looking to get "back in the saddle"? This is the class for you! We'll go over information helpful to new cyclists like which bikes are best for which purpose, good places to buy bikes, what other equipment you need to get started, how to ride on streets, and we'll have time to answer questions that you bring as well. And on a side note, does anyone know what's currently going on with The Bike Shack? I haven't been there in a while, and now that Wayward Cafe moved to the Ave, I figured that it's now no more. Updates?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This is Erica with the Bike Shack. We are still at our same location for the foreseeable future. We are paying rent directly to the property owner now. Check out our current schedule (we're open 4 days a week now!) at www.bikeshack.org.
Hey Erica! Are there any photos of the Bike Shack that I can post here on the front page? I'd like to do a shout-out for the Bike Shack to help people know it's still going on. Thanks!

item.title: Deschool Pioneer Matt Hern @ Left Bank 3/15!
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Hey Seattle DIYers! If you've got the time, head down to your favorite anarchist bookshop of horrors tomorrow, 3/15, to hear Matt Hern talk about his newest book, Common Ground In A Liquid City: Essays In Defense of an Urban Future. Matt lives up in Vancouver, B.C., and is super-rad. He's the author of the amazing Everywhere All The Time: A New Deschooling Reader, and the founder of the Purple Thistle Center up in Vancouver. Besides being on the forefront of the deschooling movement and having radical politics, he's also a professor at UBC, teaching about urban sustainability and city design. Come hang with us tomorrow to talk about the scariness of corporate control, the promise of grassroots organizing, and the way to bring funky back. Also, Left Bank needs your love, so come hang out with us anyways. It's going to be SO GOOD. 7:30PM @ LEFT BANK BOOKS 92 Pike St. (1st & Pike, next to the flower shop!)

item.title: Report Night March 26
item.dc:creator: rebecca.nur
item.content:encoded: Hi Everyone, It's time again for Report Night, this month March 26 starting at 6:30 at 936 20th Ave (up the porch and through the door on the left). Of course the basic premise of Report Night is that you pick a topic of your choosing, have some type of learning aid to go with it (visual, audio, food, etc) and then you spend 5-10 minutes presenting on it. And really it can be anything.   Check out our blog at: http://seattlereportnight.blogspot.com/ If interested in reporting shoot me an e-mail back so I can add you to the list.  I usually write here that "you can't come if you're an asshole." And yes, please keep the ass-holery at home, but also we trying to promote a Safer Space (i.e. checking racist, homophobic, sexist, etc. comments) while also assuming positive intent. Shoot a response back for the head count, and feel free to pass the word along to anyone who'd be interested. Cheers! Rebecca

item.title: FRIDAY, 3/26 AT LEFT BANK BOOKS: GREEK ANARCHISTS SPEAK ON THE GREEK DECEMBER
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: At 7:30 PM on Friday, March 26th at Left Bank Books in Seattle: Anarchists (and contributors to the new book, We Are an Image from the Future) from the VOID Network from Athens, Greece will join a US anarchist to discuss the world-famous riots that shook Greece in December 2008 (which were a response to the police killing of a teenager in the "ungovernable" district of Exarchia). This is a rare opportunity to hear about a major historical event directly from the participants! The speakers will also delve into the broader context of popular revolt and state counterinsurgency in Greece, Catalunya (Spain), and the UK, exploring how social contexts that support or discourage revolt are created in a contest between the state and grassroots social struggles. Read more about the Greek uprising and anarchist movement Left Bank Books 92 Pike St Seattle Wa 98101

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: i'm so stoked for this!

item.title: Really Really Free Market at Pratt Park, TODAY!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Is your freebox overflowing with recently unburied treasure? Are you doing your spring cleaning and have some weird/wonderful things you need to get off your hands? Are you in desperate need of some totally free clothes, movies, books, CDs, household goods, instruments, etc etc? Just as I suspected! Well, the Really Really Free Market (aka the answer to all your prayers) is really really happening today! the details: Come join us at Pratt Park (on 20th between Yesler and Jackson in the Central Area)! RRFM organizers will be there from noon to 4pm, but really it all depends on YOUR participation. This is how it works: bring your freebox! Clothes, movies, music, house goods, snacks, shoes, whatever else that you no longer need and think someone might be able to use. Why buy new things when there is so much extra stuff just floating around our community? Everything is totally free, bring what you don’t want anymore, take away new finds. At the end of the day someone will scoop up everything left over and take it down to be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. It’s like the biggest free box of your dreams! Look for us tomorrow, you’ll see picnic tables covered with stuff (or if it’s raining, look for us under the covered area. See you there!

item.title: Democracy as Totalitarianism: Peter Gelderloos Speaks at Left Bank Books
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Wednesday, April 7th at 7:30 PM At Left Bank Books 92 Pike Street Peter Gelderloos--author of How Non-Violence Protects the State, Consensus, and the newly published Anarchy Works--will be speaking at Left Bank Books on Democracy as Totalitarianism. Peter will analyze democracy as a creation of the elite and an evolution from obviously authoritarian forms of governance that allows for greater control of people's beliefs and lives. We will explore the anarchist proposition that all government--including democracy--is authoritarian and a force for domination and thought-control.

item.title: Makeshift Reclamation: New Feminst Art and Activism
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: "Makeshift Reclamation: New Feminist Art and Activism" is coming to the Pacific Northwest!* *"Makeshift Reclamation," a *multimedia event showcasing how contemporary feminists are resisting and creating alternatives to not only gender-based oppression but also a collapsing economic system, climate crisis, and more, will be touring the Pacific Northwest this spring. Featuring live readings, performances, and film/video/audio works by artists and activists including Jessica Hoffmann, coeditor/copublisher of the independent, transnational, antiracist feminist magazine *make/shift*; Hilary Goldberg, whose new project,*recLAmation*, is a Super 8 experimental documentary/narrative film in which queer superheroes navigate a future beyond capitalism; Alexis Pauline Gumbs; Mattilda Bernstein Sycamore; Little Light; Timmy Straw; Laura Piece Kelly; Jessica Lawless; and others TBA. http://www.makeshiftreclamation.com 4/2, Friday, 2:30 p.m.: University of Washington, Ethnic Cultural Theatre 3940 Brooklyn Ave. NE, Seattle, WA Live performances by Hilary Goldberg, Jessica Hoffmann, Laura Piece Kelly, Kai Kohlsdorf, Little Light, and others TBA; original film/video/audio works by Alexis Pauline Gumbs, Jessica Lawless, and Mattilda Bernstein Sycamore 4/3, Saturday, 7:30 p.m.: @ Left Bank Books 92 Pike Street, Seattle, WA Live performances by Hilary Goldberg, Jessica Hoffmann, Kai Kohlsdorf, Little Light, and others TBA; original film/video/audio works by Alexis Pauline Gumbs, Jessica Lawless, and Mattilda Bernstein Sycamore RSVP and invite your friends on Facebook (if you use it): http://www.facebook.com/pages/Makeshift-Reclamation/341352119197?v=app_2344061033&ref=ts http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2233928781&ref=t

item.title: March on April 9th!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Check out this march happening on the 9th! It looks like this will be a pretty rad event. Show up and be heard! Enough is Enough! March Against Police Brutality Friday April 9th, 12pm at Seattle Central Community College Protect Our Communities, Protect Ourselves! On Monday, March 22nd another Portland community member, was brutally murdered by the police. Friday, April 9th we are calling a march in solidarity here in Seattle to recognize that Portland's struggle against police brutality is also our struggle. Police brutality is a systemic issue that is effecting the entire country. We refuse to sit by and just shake our heads as police shoot down people here or in Portland or anywhere. We refuse to feel unsafe in our own neighbourhoods, streets and workplaces. The police are one part of the prison industrial complex that is expanding rapidly, and more and more sectors of our society are gearing themselves toward promoting the proliferation of prisons-- and profiting off it. They are not making us safer. They are killing us and locking us up at an exponential rate. Today the US has 5% of the world population and 25% of the worlds prison population. With the highest rate of incarceration in the world, we have been sold the idea that police and prisons are the solution to crime. Upon investigation of the prison system we find a system that targets poor people, people of color, transgendered people and the mentally ill. Instead of turning to the prison industrial complex, we want to build networks of support and safety within our own neighbourhoods and communities. Instead let's defend each other to preserve community safety. Talk to your neighbours! Form community assemblies and phone trees to create immediate response  to danger in your neighbourhood, from the cops and otherwise. Build an understanding of the root causes of crime and the capacity to think up solutions that could really work to create real safety and healing for all of our community. Let's stand up and be loud! Let's build a community movement against police brutality.

item.title: L@s Quixotes Radical Lending Library/Infoshop grand opening party tonight!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Come to the GRAND OPENING PARTY of the L@s Quixotes Radical Lending Library/Infoshop/Biblioteca! A well timed opening, on a day dedicated to dreamers and those considered fools by the current order, the party will be Thursday, April 1, 2010 between 5 and 8 p.m. at our first home, located in the upstairs of: Pilot Books 219 Broadway E Upstairs You can check out the new space, our growing collection of books and zines, and pick up your new library card! There will be food and doughnuts, as well as music by Pet Dander and Osito. If you have any books, papers and zines which are of interest to anarchists and anti-authoritarians, please bring them to donate to our collection. See you there! item.title: The Truly Magnificent Bob Story
item.dc:creator: zach
item.content:encoded: Most of us would agree that the D.I.Y. music community is alive and thriving, but what about other art forms. A space like Healthy Times Fun Club has potential much further then only doing concerts and I am so excited that this friday they will be hosting a new musical by Shelby Turner (recent seattle transplant from Olympia and member of Sundance Kids, Megabog and iji). The Truly Magnificent Bob Story follows the worlds most optimistic pizza delivery guy as he overcomes problems at home, black magic, and severe world wide environmental disasters. Could this be the worlds first Posi-Pizza Performance? I had the pleasure of seeing the play when it was performed in Idaho last month and it blew my mind. I offered this quote for the flyer "The best play I have ever seen." For real. Fri April 2nd Healthy Times Fun Club 8:00 $5 The half hour play featuring Derek Ryan-Hain and Emily Popp will be followed by Music from An Earth-Like World-Like Earth, Christopher Francis and Son (olympia) and Slow Trucks (san fransisco). Don't miss this one dudez

item.title: Events on Saturday night, 4/3/10!

item.content:encoded: I love going to shows at nontraditional venues. Tonight is a tough decision, though. First, there's the very awesome looking MakeShift Reclamation event (a multi-media event exploring feminist ideas around gender oppression and current events). But also tonight are shows featuring lo-fi young performers at 20/20 Cycle - one of the best bike shops and performance spaces around - and a show at "The Bread Factory", on 20th and Jackson near Moonlight Cafe and Hidmo. item.title: Do It Together projects in Seattle!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: A local writer for the website Examiner.com has been profiling a number of great DIY projects and activities lately, and I dug the most recent post especially. Part of what I really love about the DIY community is not just the part where someone decides to "do it yourself", but when people encourage the community to work collaboratively and "Do It Together"! In the spirit of "D.I.T.", Audrey, the author of these posts, has suggested a number of projects like Food Not Bombs or The Bikery or Seattle Free School that are great to get involved in that empower whole communities. I would suggest a number of other cool projects that people can get involved in, like Bike Works, Alleycat Acres, Justice Works!, or Books To Prisoners.
