item.title: Reminder: Peter Gelderloos Speaks on Democracy as Totalitarianism, PLUS DON'T FORGET THE FRIDAY DEMONSTRATION
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Wow, there's so much rad stuff going on. Don't forget this: Wednesday, April 7th at 7:30 PM At Left Bank Books 92 Pike Street Peter Gelderloos--author of How Non-Violence Protects the State, Consensus, and the newly published Anarchy Works--will be speaking at Left Bank Books on Democracy as Totalitarianism. Peter will analyze democracy as a creation of the elite and an evolution from obviously authoritarian forms of governance that allows for greater control of people's beliefs and lives. We will explore the anarchist proposition that all government--including democracy--is authoritarian and a force for domination and thought-control. And ESPECIALLY don't forget to meet at Seattle Central Community College at NOON on Friday the 9th to participate in coast-wide actions against police brutality! But of course you won't, because we're all telling our friends and we're all going to be there, right?

item.title: April 9th police brutality protest, and a response to the literature handed out.
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: The content of this post has been retracted. For more information, visit this blog post. Thanks.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I took a few photos from the beginning of the march that came out well, I figured someone involved would like to have copies. Is there anyone who's documenting direct actions that I could send pictures to?

I feel like there's clearly people in the DIY community who favor fighting back and self-defense. There's an important critique of capitalism that goes something like this: anything that is not directly fighting capitalism is absorbed into it. Once upon a time, everything was an alternative, but capitalism is global today precisely because it has the ability, in fact the need, hardwired into it, to conquer, colonize, and absorb all alternatives. Thus, the principles of DIY and the broader anti-authoritarian scene it emerged from, come into a conflict with reality, and have to answer the question: attack the system, or be absorbed back into it, just like all our predecessors.

I have never had the idea that "DIY" was a violent or non-violent movement & I don't see any reason to label it either way. In your definition of the DIY movement, were you trying to define the entire movement, or simply what SeattleDIY is all about? If you're trying to define the entire DIY movement as non-violent, that just really doesn't seem true at all, as it definitely involves an extremely broad community. If "the anarchists" (as was signed at the end of the pamphlet) feel as if they are a part of the DIY community AND they also think that violence may be necessary to work toward creating something better, I really think that's completely valid. The statement, "we will not be coopted by a very small portion of this community", hit me kind of hard. "Coopted" just doesn't seem like an appropriate word at all, as I don't see how anyone who is part of the community can coopt the community. And, even if it's true that a very small portion of us agree with violence (which I'm not sure if that's true), I really don't think that should make a difference as to whether they are part of the community.

I wasn't at the march, and I only briefly saw a copy of the pamphlet in question... While I feel weird about addressing this on the internets, I also think it's important to have these kinds of conversations in a public forum. I understand wanting to dissociate the SeattleDIY website from a pamphlet that mentions shooting back at cops, especially when this site isn't exactly secure, and it could bring undue surveillance. At the same time, I find this post to be condescending and divisionist, while speaking for the entire "DIY movement" and the entire SeattleDIY "collective". At least three separate posts in the last couple of weeks have been made here on SDIY about events/talks regarding police brutality, state violence, and the prison industrial system. It doesn't seem so weird to me, then, that this blog would be considered a resource for learning more about state violence and connecting with a community that opposes said violence (whatever form that opposition takes, well, that isn't up to us to determine). Claiming that the DIY movement is about creativity and not destruction asserts another false dichotomy that I find really important to re-think. There's a fine line - indistinguishable, I would argue - between the ideas of creativity and destruction, and to me, DIY is about make that line even more confusing. However, it's not really useful to get into a big theoretical discussion here. I have to agree with worldhistory - how is a pamphlet suggesting SDIY as a resource "co-opting" the movement? Simply because the pamphlet doesn't fit within your pre-determined DIY boundaries? While you state that, "Our ideals and values are not monolithic, and should not be conveyed as though they are," you're actually reinforcing the monolith by announcing on a personal pulpit what is and isn't part of the DIY movement. Instead of opening up discussion in the community on what might be considered DIY, you're setting the boundaries. I also really resent you saying that "I hope none of what I’ve written here disappoints any fans of the DIY movement." Really? Fans? That's all we are? For a "collective" that claims to support creators and participators of culture, that's a pretty rude way to relegate anyone but yourself as merely a "fan". This is not the kind of DIY movement I want any part in.

While I disagree with some of your statements that describe the DIY community in general (for example, I do not think that the flyer citing SeattleDIY coopts SeattleDIY or the DIY movement), I do understand and agree with your statement that the SeattleDIY website should not be taken as a supporter of or source of information about violent resistance.

Thanks for your responses, all of you. I agree with a number of things each of you have stated, and I've edited my post accordingly. I wrote the original post after having been really upset (angry, actually), and I didn't represent myself well as a result. Thanks again.
Benji, I appreciate your honesty & thanks for your openness.
That's fine. You have the right to choose how your website is represented. However, I am removing myself from participation in this website and SeattleDIY's other activities.

[...] warrant some time spent on responses. Several very good responses to his Seattle DIY blog “editorial” have already been posted as comments—please read them. This piece is primarily a response to [...]

item.title: March Against Police Brutality April 9, 2010
item.dc:creator: NaNa
item.content:encoded: March Against Police Brutality March: Arrest Footage Reporting of the incidents of the March Against Police Brutality on April 9th, 2010. Reported by Seattle Independent Media Center Three people were arrested during a march against Police Brutality in Seattle WA, this afternoon around 1:30 p.m. The march was organized in solidarity with the recent shooting of a Portland OR. resident by police, and with actions in response to this murder occurring up and down the West Coast. Around 100 people met in front of Seattle Community College at noon. Police presence was already significant with 4 cops on horses, approximately a dozen cops on bicycles, with squad cars scattered around the surrounding blocks, as well as officers watching from inside SCC buildings. Demonstrators started moving around 12:40, initially staying on the sidewalk while occasionally moving to block traffic as the march snaked through Capitol Hill. Marchers took the street at 11th and Pine, blocking traffic before being pushed onto the sidewalk by police officers with bikes. After circling the block, protestors attempted to move a small dumpster into the street but were stopped by mounted police, who tried to use their horses to physically harm the protestors. The march grew quiet after this confrontation but people seemed determined to continue. As the march moved up Pine, protestors again tried to move a large dumpster into the street but were stopped immediately by police. Marchers were violently pushed aside as cops used bicycles to barricade 3 individuals against the wall of Rancho Bravo, Mexican restaurant. A female-bodied person was slammed into a concrete pole and pushed to the ground. The three people clung together on the ground as the cops tried to tear them apart. Other officers blocked off the rest of the march and attempted to block cameras from the scene. The first person arrested was seen being restrained by three cops, each with a knee in his back, legs and head. He was dragged limp to a waiting police van. The second arrestee was female-bodied and was taken to a separate squad car. While being forced into the car, she asked the press to photograph and document injuries to her face. The police would not let reporters into the street to take photos, but she appeared to have scratches and cuts on her right eye and chin, as well as the left side of her face. Observers say they witnessed the third individual being kicked in the head by officers while on the ground. Presumably due to injuries he sustained, he did not seem lucid while being taken into custody. The march continued on down Broadway until dispersing around 2:30. Jail support is being organized. The police have not released any information on who or exactly how many people have been arrested, though the Seattle Times (who has the corporate privilege of being in contact with police) reports that “Seattle Police spokeswoman Renee Witt said the five were arrested during a march in the Capitol Hill neighborhood Friday afternoon for investigation of crimes ranging from trespassing to inciting a riot” Our hearts go out to our friends in custody In Solidarity, Seattle Independent Media Center

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] against the police in Capitol Hill. Accurate and analytical coverage of that action is available here and here. In contrast, Benji’s writings are poor analyses based mostly on his inaccurate [...]

item.title: Solidarity and Repression in Seattle Anti-Police Protest
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Cops Take Prisoners, How Will We Respond? A description of the protest, and then a look at the questions of isolation and solidarity we are faced with... Passion for Freedom vs. Bike Cops Friday, April 9th, about 80 people came together at Seattle Central Community College to protest the police and stand in solidarity with those arrested for fighting back. Anarchists had published a call-out for West Coast days of action on April 8 and 9 in support of the struggles in Portland and the Bay Area that erupted after recent police killings, and folks in Seattle responded by organizing this protest. In the days leading up to the protest, hundreds of posters, stickers, and flyers were put up or handed out around the center of the city, criticizing the violent role of the police in our society and urging people to come out to the march. The protest, which included a small black bloc, a marching band, a group of homeless youth activists, and others, marched through the Central District/Capitol Hill area. On the way to the police precinct, people took the streets, though after a little more than a block, bike cops and horse cops responded to shove people back onto the sidewalk. In the meantime, thousands of fliers, with a variety of texts, were handed out, eliciting an appreciative "fuck the police!" from many passersby. Some of the fliers presented an anarchist critique of police and social control and argued for the abolition of police, prisons, and the government; another, entitled "Some People Shoot Back," was a text about Christopher Monfort, who is facing trial and a probable death penalty after being arrested for firebombing four police vehicles and shooting and killing a Seattle-area cop in an ambush, after police were caught on tape brutally beating a 15 year old girl in a detention facility. Because of that and another cop killing that occurred around the same time, Seattle media have been able to present the police as victims, in an effort to stir public sympathy for our enemies in blue. Some people were initially confused to see a protest against the police, but the texts, signs, chants, and the presence of the people there all communicated that they are not our heroes, but our enemies, and their violence against us is a daily fact. Some confusion arose within the march as many people looked to the black bloc to lead the way, a role the anarchists refused, so after marching most of the way to the police precinct, people changed direction to return to a busier commercial area. People continued seizing the streets whenever the opportunity presented itself, leading to further scuffles with cops. At several points, people rolled dumpsters into cops to push them back. On the last of these occasions, bike cops moved in to make targeted arrests, seizing at least three people, one of whom they appeared to knock unconscious. After trying to stop the arrests, and then shouting against the police and in support of those arrested, the remainder of the march returned to the starting point and marched down Broadway before dispersing. Isolation vs. Solidarity The riots after the killings in Oakland and Portland have been sparks of life. We are struggling every day against the misery and the blackmails of capitalism, and when the defenders of Capital kill, our struggle will flare up, and we will strike back. The West Coast days of action were an attempt to overcome the isolation, the limitations to solidarity, imposed on us in the US. They have been an attempt to broaden the struggle, and to keep coming back to the streets for those who have been arrested, until everyone is free. Repression is a strategy of encirclement, of isolation, that we need to expand beyond. Hearing about the arrests of anarchists in Olympia on April 8, and seeing the strong police reaction in Seattle, we think the State is trying to stop our wave of solidarity from spreading, to make us feel weak, to attack connections being made between police violence in one city and in another, so that people do not see the State as a common enemy but think in terms of bad apples, complaint forms, better oversight. Solidarity continues only by growing. The arrests are a hostage-taking, a collective punishment. The purpose is to make us feel weak, to doubt the value of fighting back, and to turn our efforts inward, by trying to support them and nothing more. And hopefully we will support them, but by turning outward, by continuing to come back to the streets, by breaking out of the encirclement of repression, by letting all those bystanders who sympathized with us know that people are in cages for doing the right thing. The people who end up doing most of the jail and legal support work deserve our appreciation, but what are the rest of us doing? Solidarity cannot be a specialized activity. Arrested people should take whatever trial strategies they choose, including asserting their innocence, but our solidarity cannot reproduce the logic of legality. *It's right to fight back against the police. *The only reason society finds out about these murders, the only time individual cops are punished, is when we fight back. *No one should ever be kept in a cage. If we shout these things at the top of our lungs, if we talk about these ideas with everyone we can, what will happen? In struggle, an anarchist FREEDOM FOR HOLLY WORKS OF OAKLAND, JOEL DOW OF PORTLAND, THE ARRESTED COMRADES IN OLYMPIA AND SEATTLE! FREEDOM FOR ALL PRISONERS!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: thank you for posting this!

item.title: Cop Killers and Killer Cops: Political Considerations- Kristian Williams Leads a Discussion This Thursday
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
Kristian Williams, author of Our Enemies in Blue: Police and Power In
America, as well as the recently published, American Methods: Torture and
the Logic of Domination, will be at Left Bank Books on Thursday, April
15th, to talk about police brutality, the psychology of authoritarianism,
and how we can fight back. He will be facilitating a conversation about "Cop
Killers and Killer Cops: Political Considerations", a timely discussion in
the wake of the recent West Coast actions against police brutality,
the brutal repression experienced by the demonstrators, and the
ongoing polarity within our community. Our
Enemies In Blue is already an essential text on the subject, and
Kristian's new title investigating American methods of torture sheds
important light on an ongoing struggle against state repression. Mark your
calendars, come join us, and bring all your friends.
Free Event. Donations for travel expenses appreciated.
Left Bank Books
92 Pike St.
7:30 pm
Thursday, 4/15

item.title: Amazing new zine project looking for contributions!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: This isn't Seattle specific, but is definitely relevant to the DIY community here. This looks like a really incredible zine project, and I can't wait to see what comes of it. THE INTERNATIONAL GIRL GANG UNDERGROUND compilation zine aims to document and dissect how Riot Grrrl's legacy has manifested twenty years later, as well as provide guidance for those who want to transform "revolution girl style now!" into "REVOLUTION GIRL STYLE FOREVER!" If Riot Grrrl doesn't resonate with you or your cause, that's okay! We also want to know about all the do-it-yourself, grassroots music movements currently being run by women/girls/trans/genderqueer/queer folks today. We want your submissions! Talking points include, but are not limited to: * ESSAYS ON... o What would a modern-day "Riot Grrrl manifesta" look like? o The successes and failures of Riot Grrrl and what we've learned from them o Your experience as an immigrant grrrl, genderf**king boy, revolutionary pornographer, Muslimah punk, working class queer, etc * REPORTS ON... o What was your experience as a Riot Grrrl in the '90s? o What's going on in your community that supports feminist & queer DIY musicians today? o Scene reports from regional DIY music scenes that traditionally are lady- and queer-friendly (London, Berlin, NYC, or your town) o Individuals who are making a difference--musicians, activists, writers, whomever! o "Where are they now?" (Riot Grrrl edition) * HOW-TO... o "Get off the Internet and meet in the street" o Reclaim feminism for the 4th wave o Organize conferences, protests, benefits, etc o Combat the "dude-first" mentality of your music scene o Use new technologies to organize effectively o Start a band/go on tour/create a zine/etc o Create spaces for working class, POC, international and rural women and queers * BAND/ZINE/COLLECTIVE/ACTIVIST GROUP INFO... o We're creating a directory for the International Girl Gang Underground--send along info on your project to be included! * ART... o Print, digital, audio, video, whatever--so long as it's in an easily rendered format for a black & white zine or can be included on an accompanying CD-R for distribution, we want it!

item.title: An Anarchist Response to Benji's Comments and a Beautiful Statement from April 9th Arrestees
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: The Arctic Circle Collective has prepared a response to some of Benji's controversial comments on the April 9th demonstration against the police.  Please read it here. Also, please read the following beautiful statement from three of the survivors of police violence on April 9th, and show up to show courtroom solidarity: 9:00AM on Tuesday, April 13 Court #302 (3rd floor) Municipal Court of the City of Seattle at the Seattle Justice Center, 600 5th Ave, Seattle WA. Court Info: 206.684.5600 Five protestors were arrested during the April 9 Anti-Police Brutality demonstration in Seattle, WA. This is a statement from three who were arrested at the same time on Capitol Hill. After more than 15 hours of being detained in precinct holding cells and county jail facilities, we were released into the early morning hours of Saturday, April 10th. We wish to extend immense thanks and gratitude to our powerful, all-volunteer jail support team who rushed to post our bail, minutes before the deadline – even putting a car up for collateral. We also thank the circles of family and friends who gathered around telephones to support us, and each other. Though we were confined for only a short period of time (compared to some of our cell-mates who were facing months or years of imprisonment), our hearts were nonetheless overjoyed to enter the cool night air. As we gazed into the dawn sky, we were greeted by a crowd of new and old friends alike. We would not like to make any statements regarding the events of that Friday except to assert our innocence regarding our alleged crimes and to make known our injuries sustained from the police. Two of us are being charged with misdemeanor assault, while the third is facing two misdemeanors of obstruction and resisting arrest. During the arrest incident, the first of us was pinned to the sidewalk before being lifted across the street by his handcuffs. He sustained injuries to his wrists, legs and feet, with continuing numbness in his hands. The second arrestee had her face repeatedly shoved into the pavement and knelt on, receiving massive bruising and lacerations to her face and head. She was punched in the right eye, while her arms were pulled to her back and her legs kicked and stepped on. The third of us was, after being forced to lie prone on the ground, repeatedly kicked and kneed in the back and side of the head. After being dragged into the street this arrestee was let fall unconscious to the pavement after requesting to be allowed to sit down. It is times like these when we realize how quickly the air we breathe is becoming increasingly thin, that we are being fooled into thinking our dizziness is an abnormal condition. We see clearly that a world of opportunity exists for us only insofar as we have the funds to purchase it, and that we can exercise all the freedom we desire so long as we keep our mouths tightly closed and our feet on the sidewalk. We are the crowning node of a greater social claustrophobia which clamors to be set free. We stand tall, arms linked in solidarity with the other two protesters wrongfully arrested during the April 9th Seattle demonstration, as well as those in Olympia on the evening of April 8th, and in Portland on March 29th. Join us in court to show your support and to decry the randomized prosecution of people who peaceably dissent against police violence. 9:00AM on Tuesday, April 13: Court #302 (3rd floor) Municipal Court of the City of Seattle at the Seattle Justice Center, 600 5th Ave, Seattle WA. Court Info: 206.684.5600 We request that all those who wish to attend dress and behave in a way that supports us by showing respect for the court. This will help us prove our innocence and the integrity of our characters.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
something happened on april 9th. people were in the streets (and sidewalks), people were beat up and kidnapped by police, people were confused/angry/afraid/supported/surprised/inspired.
i can easily see benji's editorial about these events on the seattlediy website leading to ideological and personal fall-out and division in the seattle anarchist/anti-authoritarian/ diy community. debate about (dis)organization, stances on (non)violence, and what counts as more or less creative strategies of resistance/attack are all necessary. how else can we learn from our experiences and hear the voices of our communities?
the internet is notorious for fostering ill-will, misunderstandings, and division. i see it as a form of passive and indirect communication - helpful for deepening rifts, unhelpful for understanding their causes.
i believe that these conversations may be more effective and productive if held in person - for example, in a community forum or discussion group specifically gathered to make a space for everyone's thoughts. this would not be a space for a bully pulpit or a gang-up, but rather a honest attempt of all involved to fully hear one another out.
in our own ways we are all seeking to make manifest an ideal world. for my part, i would like to believe this is an opportunity not for further division or ostracism, but to strengthen the seattle anarchist community by broadening the scope of relationships and interactions which we feel we can constructively engage in.
we should all be willing (excited even!) to hold each other accountable and be held accountable ourselves. that's fundamental. i would love to see this conversation continue in person. anyone else?
and the internet is guaranteed to be 100% monitored. how annoying is THAT when it comes to freely and fully expressing ourselves?

Bex, yes i agree, that would be great.
But, I just have to note... Benji's response was quick, brutal, & extremely public. I think everyone who has been involved in the internet discussion thus far, felt that their responses could only be very well heard in the same kind of [internet] forum (or that's at least how I felt). So, that said, I still think this discussion has been healthy.
And when I say "healthy", I'm obviously excluding the Slog.

I feel the same as worldhistory. I feel like the people that I know, who felt attacked by Benji's comments, are completely open to in-person dialogue and discussion. Unfortunately, this was not an option made available to I or anyone I know before Benji made his post. As far as I know Benji did not even approach anyone passing out "Some People Shoot Back" on Friday to engage in dialogue over his concerns. Rather, a very public and very upsetting blog post was made. Many people felt incredibly outraged and betrayed by said blog post, and I feel like a public denunciation and analysis of his complete LACK of solidarity with those involved with the rally was appropriate, and necessary. I feel like it was appropriate and necessary to make public counterpoints to Benji's comments not only because Benji and the SeattleDIY website are such large figureheads in the local community, but also because Benji's comments reflect the ideas and ways of thinking of majority of the populace. I feel like the more opportunities we have to publicly deconstruct these ways of thinking, the better. In regards to security culture, I feel like having a public discourse on anarchist thoughts and ideas is valid, and necessary, and we need it now more than ever. Governmental oppression is increasing, just as public outcry against institutions such as the police and FBI is also on the rise, and I don't feel like it's a coincidence. I feel like anarchists need to have a public face, and have their thoughts and ideas made pubic so that the general population knows of at least one more person they can go to for resources, support, and solidarity against their own oppression. For those that want to know more about good security culture practices when on the computer I totally recommend riseup.net's Digital Security for Activists. The Arctic Circle Collective will also be holding a workshop on practicing good security culture in the very near future, and it will cover the use of technology as well. river

Echoing the other three commenters' above sentiments, I want to say that yes, the internet is notorious for fostering ill-will, and that an open discussion in person (with good security culture) would be the best way to proceed, but also that the response (the intelligent, thoughtful response--not "reaction") to Benji has been healthy and appropriate, and that I have doubts he would have rethought or retracted his harmful comments without people calling him out on them.
worldhistory says it well: "Benji’s response was quick, brutal, & extremely public." "Undoing It Ourselves" is a collaborative piece by the Arctic Circle Collective generated from conversations and signed as a group in agreement, but right now I speak only for myself. I acknowledge that the piece is harsh and unapologetic--but only because we were defending many people, some of whom are very vulnerable right now, from very unfair, harmful, and visible attacks and misrepresentations that Benji made online--that is, publicly.
Anyone who wonders why so many sharp words have been thrown around in the internet arena over the last few days should think: who brought it here first? I am of course for breaking down walls more than burning bridges, but who struck the match? I see no need for leniency when defending our friends from the kinds of things Benji posted.
That said, I am encouraged by his retraction and hope dialogue continues.
river mentions Arctic Circle organizing a future workshop on security culture--an excellent idea. I would also like to add that I am going to look into making some calls to PDX for folks interested in coming here to discuss General Assemblies and how they can be used to discuss strategies, tactics, and goals for actions. Meanwhile, if anyone wants to organize an open, face-to-face dialogue, on any scale, about the action and its aftermath, I would love to participate, but I doubt I'll be willing to continue discussion online. To be honest, I am somewhat embarrassed to have spent this much time on this already when there are so many other things that demand our attention: (legal support, fund raising, keeping a momentum, analysis, etc.) Unfortunately, this was necessary.

PM, the problem with what has happened here is echoed in how you're responding. First - I would have ABSOLUTELY responded well to direct communication. Using the bully pulpit to silence my criticism didn't just lead to me retracting my statement, but has left me feeling isolated, personally attacked, and and disregarded. Second, the "who struck the match" argument is a terrible justification for attacking someone personally and with such fervor. My criticisms were about how things went down and very specific particulars - not any judgments of the nature or quality of the people who partook in the actions. Though I abused my privilege and use of this space in the criticism of the tactics employed in the protest, there are significant reasons I felt like I needed to distance myself and seattlediy from the more aggressive elements of the protest (and the pamphlet) immediately. I'm earnestly sorry for the original tone and some serious mistakes I made in representing both myself and the collective in that original hurried and poorly worded blog post. Still, I don't see how my mistakes (which I tried to remedy quickly) warranted the kind of venom and vitriol that came my way, and so publicly, especially as a statement made by an entire collective of people whom I highly regard and think of warmly. I look forward to having a good-faith discussion in person about these things.

item.title: Retraction, and moving on.
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I would like to acknowledge that using this space to editorialized my personal opinions about the activities of other people may represent an abuse of my position as owner of this website and the influence I hold within the DIY community. More than anything, I would like open and free dialogue to take place that encourages participation and a deeper investment in the kinds of movements, struggles, and activities that help make this a world we'd like to live in, and my criticisms did not reflect that desire. Therefor, I am retracting my criticisms made about the April 9th protests, though I would like to retain one important part of that post. Not only am I financially and legally responsible for the content on this website, but I'm ethically responsible for the decisions that I make as editor, moderator, and administrator of this website, and additionally as but one member of a collective. This being the case, I would like to state that SeattleDIY.com is not associated with or endorse the pamphlet "Some People Shoot Back", despite being listed on the pamphlet as a resource. Members of the SeattleDIY Collective were not consulted in our inclusion in the pamphlet, though likely we were listed because we are a source of information about news and upcoming events. I hope we can all continue to contribute to a culture and community that lifts each other up and provides earnest support for each others' endeavors, as well as holding one another accountable for our statements and actions. This effort requires each of us to be more responsive, not reactive, and to allow the critical eye to turn inward, not just outward. SeattleDIY.com will continue to publish information about how to support and show solidarity for the people who were arrested on April 9th, as well as further activities of activists who fight for social justice. This is but one part of the large and diverse DIY culture and movement, and we will of course also be promoting and sharing information about events and activities that are less overtly political in nature. Remember that our event calendar is open source, and that we try to have the blog posts here represent a variety of voices from within the community. If you would like to be a contributor to this blog (for event and project promotion, not "editorializing"), contact us at sdiycollective at gmail dot com. I'll be posting my personal opinions about the protest in the near future on a more appropriate forum, my blog.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: April 9th police brutality protest, and a response to the literature handed out. – Seattle D.I.Y.
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] content of this post has been retracted. For more information, visit this blog post. [...]

A friend related to a member of the Arctic Circle that, because of a tone that has been set in the discourse following the April 9th demonstration against the police, some people feel discouraged to engage in discussion and criticisms of the action. I want to acknowledge the Arctic Circle’s contribution to this tone and state that it was not our intention to stifle responses and critiques. Rather, our aim was to respond to inaccurate claims about the demonstration that a well-known, very visible member of our community voiced in a public manner that was damaging to our movement and potentially harmful to our friends facing criminal charges. To the contrary, we think that the action must be analyzed, critiqued, and debated as a way of moving on—that is to say, maintaining and building momentum.
We do not, however, believe that there is a singular way forward from our situation, but rather a multitude of situations to be created and connected by diverse, autonomous individuals and groups. We can only achieve this through dialogue. Members of the Arctic Circle are looking forward to participating in upcoming face-to-face conversations about what happened, and what’s happening, and what will happen. Personally, one point I am looking forward to discussing is the lack of participation (for a variety of reasons) in coordinating April 9th, and proposals on how we can strategize together more effectively in the future.
More: http://arcticcirclecollective.info/articles/6/nebulous-trajectories-potentials-for-moving-on-not-forward

item.title: Creative Resistance conference - April 24th at Seattle University
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: "Creative Resistance" is Break the Silence's 2nd annual conference at Seattle University. "Creative Resistance" is a student-led conference for members of the Puget Sound Region to explore and confront legacies of violence. The conference will examine the ways in which systems of violence interrelate in order to maintain one another. Through art, self-healing, and self-determination, this conference aims to develop creative strategies and build collective consent for addressing the pervasiveness of violence in our communities. Through facilitated workshops, dialogue, and artistic self-expression, participants will: 1. Increase their awareness and knowledge of histories of violence and the impact today on our communities 2. Explore the role of consent in all facets and levels of relationships 3. Build concrete strategies for addressing an array of issues related to a culture which normalizes violence and undermines consent. 4. Develop mobilization and movement strategies to further sustain creative resistance in our communities. **Workshop descriptions and tentative conference schedule will be posted within the up coming week. registration is NOW OPEN! register here: http://nwbreakthesilence.wordpress.com/2010/03/22/creative-resistance-registration/ more information about Break the Silence http://nwbreakthesilence.wordpress.com Break the Silence is a student collective is a student collective at Seattle University who believes that through creativity, education, and collective action we can fight against sexualized violence. By exploring the ways that personal experiences are linked to larger forms of oppression, we can transform our communities to embrace consent and be sex positive.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Benji, I wish I could come to this event but I will be presenting in Philly all weekend. It's so great when SU has events I am interested in.

item.title: New media // webzines on the rise!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I've noticed a lot of new exciting projects coming about that are taking advantage of new internet-based social networks and once disparate communities now strengthened by the greater visibility of our peers via blogs (for example, I'm especially excited by blogs like Vegans of Color, and Native Appropriations). It only makes sense that the radical self-publishing ideas developed during the 80's & 90's of the zine revolution would start to really develop and inform this new blog movement. We've had a couple posts on here about the awesome Through This Window webzine before. Well, their next issue (TTW002: "Unrequited Love") is coming out soon, and their deadline is May 15th. They're seeking any kind of content that you may want to make - video, essay, illustrative, whateves! Here's their brief description of the upcoming issue: "First crushes, fantasies/daydreams, "just friends", love letters to strangers, reactions to professing of love, where did things go wrong?, etc. etc. Please submit by 5/15 for a 6/1 release!" I also just found out about Double Take!, a webzine started by Evergreen students and friends. It looks aaaamazing! "Double Take! is a show about and by DIY and Feminist artists, musicians, and social justice workers. We call it a ‘Feminist Video Zine’ because our media content is inspired by zine aesthetics and DIY ethos... Our show features live interviews, segments on DIY art projects and Feminist history, and musical performances. It will be shot at The Evergreen State College in the new HD television studio, the CCAM. If you are interested in being a guest or submitting your own work to be included in a “webisode” or on-air programing, you can contact us at feministvideozine@gmail.com!" Of course, print zines are still going strong, and have even seen a resurgence in recent years. I posted the other day about "International Girl Gang Underground", which is looking for submissions for people interested in the lasting legacy of the Riot Grrl movement. I also just got an email from the zine Give Me Back, which is having a new issue coming out soon, and are looking to take ads from the DIY community to help fund their awesome cheap/free zine. If you're not familiar with Give Me Back, I would recommend checking it out. They were born following the death of the influential zine Heart Attack, and have had some really incredible pieces on activist groups like Philly's Pissed, the Down There Health Collective, and cool bands like Des_Ark and Margaret Thrasher. Anyway, I'll get off my soapbox about things I'm excited about. I hope readers of this site check out what these great folk are up to, contribute to these projects, and start their own!

item.title: April 24th - Earth Day Free Day!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Some great people have organized an incredible looking event on April 24th on Capitol Hill. They're calling it Earth Day Free Day, which is looking to be a great mix of elements, ranging from a Really Really Free Market, a convergence of noisemakers (bring drums and instruments!), a potluck, and a trading-post of sorts. This will be taking place at the "parking lot" on Pine & Belmont, the empty gravel yard where numerous small businesses once thrived until local developers decided to bulldoze the entire block, then back out on replacing it with anything. I, for one, will be there with bells on. Here's the relevant info: http://peoplesparkinglot.blogspot.com/ "Earth Day Free Day: A community celebration, potluck style On April 24, Capitol Hillsters will be able to do something they're not usually allowed to do: take over the vacant space on East Pine. The empty gravel lot, lodged between Belmont and Summit, is typically off limits. No trespassing allowed. It’s a hard reality for some to swallow, as this block used to be home of some of the neighborhood’s best bars and nightlife. But on April 24th we get to take this space back. People's Parking Lot has been granted permission to throw a huge public gathering there. In honor of Earth Day, I propose that we come together as a community to celebrate being here. Getting together, meeting your neighbors and celebrating as a community is greatly beneficial to our world. So come dance, sing, create and communicate with us in the gravel lot on Sat. April, 24. We’ll be loosely organizing, but the main goal here is to make it an event we create together, just by showing up and sharing. If you’re a musician, bring your instrument. If you’re an artist, consider the lot your outdoor studio for the day, if you’re a baker or chef, bring us a taste of your latest creation, if you’re a dancer, think of the lot as your studio, if you love to talk and speak your mind, come find someone to chat with. We’ll be trying to invite barter and really, really free market folks so that there is an element of free stuff as well as free service. Please save the date! Come help celebrate your community and your place in the world. If you can help in any way, have an idea, or just want to get in touch, please let me know. Thanks, Sarah Kuck" (Here's the facebook invite page, and here's their website!)

item.title: Tranny Roadshow at the Lakeside Collective!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Check out this great event going on up at the Lakeside Collective, up in Lake City, right off the Burke-Gilman trail! It's on Friday, April 23rd, at 7:30pm. The Tranny Roadshow is a multimedia performance art extravaganza. It is composed of an eclectic group of artists, each one self-identified as transgender, and includes poets, rappers, filmmakers, storytellers, breakdancers, rock bands, comedians, actors, folk singers, photographers, zinesters, and more. Stationary art (i.e. photography and sculpture) is displayed, but most of the presentation is the live show, a unique variety show where the expression of gender and the expression of self are inseparable. The show is a fluid entity, changing to suit the artists and the crowd, but always it is full of intelligence, fun and humor. Although the Tranny Roadshow is done entirely by transpeople, it is not exclusively for transpeople. It is a raucous evening of entertainment, open and accessible to people of all backgrounds. Suggested donation: $5-10. ( No one turned away!) All Ages DANCE PARTY to follow! **We try to make our home a safe(r) space for all by minimizing the presence of transphobia, racism, ableism, sexism, sizeism, ageism, homophobia, and other forms of oppression.** Our home is wheelchair accessible. However, our driveway is quite steep and not safe for most vehicles. We can assist down the driveway in one of our vehicles, just let us know. Here's the facebook event page: http://www.facebook.com/home.php#!/event.php?eid=112380385457288 The Lakeside Collective is at 11748 Lakeside Ave NE, Seattle, WA

item.title: Really Reeeeally Free Market, Saturday April 24th! That's like, TODAY!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Is your freebox overflowing with recently unburied treasure? Are you doing your spring cleaning and have some weird/wonderful things you need to get off your hands? Are you in desperate need of some totally free clothes, movies, books, CDs, household goods, instruments, etc etc? Just as I suspected! Well, the Really Really Free Market (aka the answer to all your prayers) is really really happening today! the details: Come join us at Pratt Park (on 20th between Yesler and Jackson in the Central Area)! RRFM organizers will be there from noon to 4pm, but really it all depends on YOUR participation. This is how it works: bring your freebox! Clothes, movies, music, house goods, snacks, shoes, whatever else that you no longer need and think someone might be able to use. Why buy new things when there is so much extra stuff just floating around our community? Everything is totally free, bring what you don’t want anymore, take away new finds. At the end of the day someone will scoop up everything left over and take it down to be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. It’s like the biggest free box of your dreams! Look for us tomorrow, you’ll see picnic tables covered with stuff (or if it’s raining, look for us under the covered area. See you there!

item.title: I Want to be Buried by the Pet Seminary[ans]

Golly gee willikers! This Friday at Pet Seminary, four of the most metal bands will unite under one roof for one purpose- to make yr ears bleed.

atticabasement and Hello Shark are on tour together from Georgia whilst Low Places and Sundance Kids (Shelby playing solo this time) are our locals of Seattle. This will be straight up the most metal show you will be to in the week of April 26th to May 2nd.

Hands-essing-down.

Alright:

Love,

item.title: Second meeting to discuss 4/9 march is TODAY!
item.dc:creator: tsarina
item.content:encoded:
Hey friends,
The second meeting to debrief and discuss the march on 4/9, as well as future community organizing, is today, March 2nd, from 5 to 7pm. Meeting space is the conference room at the Vera Project, which is at the corner of Warren Ave N & Republican on Seattle Center. The building is fully ADA accessible. If you need directions or get lost, call Vera at (206) 956-8372.
Metro routes 1, 2, 8, 13, 15, 16, 18, 30, and 81 all stop on the west side of Seattle Center, about a block away from Vera. There are also bike racks in front of the building.
See you soon!

item.title: What We Demand, Instead, Is Life
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: The following text is from a leaflet distributed at the May 3rd Campus Strike Against Budget Cuts at the University of Washington. Following the text are few links for further readings and resources for getting involved. Our bones shift as the professor begins a lecture as stiff and common as this molded plastic seat. We just woke up for class but are already bored. This is routine. This morning’s class is as bitter and over-priced as our burnt coffee. We’ve swallowed this so many mornings that we have forgotten a life beyond daily schedule. This morning’s class, a meeting, another class, and then ‘free’ time. We once held the illusions of higher education; now we hold iphones. We are resigned to facebook profiles to check in with friends that we are actually too busy to meet. We chat with our friends about how much longer we will endure this regime. How many more quarters until we receive the brand name stamp, the university graduate insignia, next to our name? We’ve become utterly disillusioned. Recently there’s been some momentum behind a student and working movement with a specific set of demands aimed at reforming a system we would rather seek to abolish: the university as an institution that integrates us into the spectacle—that is, our lives as separated from and presented to us for our passive consumption. We do not want to reform and improve it; death by any other name has the same stench. Continue Reading...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
you so-called anarchists sound like a bunch of bored self-righteous academics. i'm proud to call myself an anarchist, but this kind of dribble undermines a rich tradition of struggle.
"if you fight in a cage and win, you're still fucking caged." so you would oppose expanding the floor of the cage? you would oppose minimum wage increases? you would oppose shortened workdays? you would oppose giving respirators to campus custodians because they're still working within existing capitalist institutions? tell them that to their faces. your agenda sounds an awful lot like that of their bosses, except you've read guy debord. well done.
seriously, this is lame sectarian bullshit, not the anarchism i love.

Are these questions sincere, or are you just trying to make your point by putting words in the authors' mouths?
Assuming you're sincere, and speaking only for myself, an anarchist who finds a lot to agree with in the text:
"you would oppose expanding the floor of the cage?" No. "you would oppose minimum wage increases?" No. "you would oppose shortened workdays?" No. "you would oppose giving respirators to campus custodians because they're still working within existing capitalist institutions?" No.
But demanding these specific reforms, or else we'll halt "business as usual," instead of earnestly seeking to end business forever, doesn't remind me of anarchist struggle.
If you read the pamphlet, it's clear that the authors are arguing that we should look beyond reforming the system and aim for liberation. This has always been the "rich tradition" of anarchist struggle. Nowhere in the text does it imply that the authors are against reforms themselves, but instead against setting the limits of our struggle in terms of demands and reformism, which the system can easily defeat or recuperate.
"You've read guy debord"--and if you have, too, you know that a major focus of his work was to analyze why every revolution (besides the capitalist one) has failed; agreeing ahead of time to return to our roles maintaining capitalism if its ruling class agrees to be softer and kinder is one reason.
We should be critical of aims, strategies, and tactics of struggles as we participate in them. You say, apparently without irony, "this is lame sectarian bullshit, not THE anarchism I love," (emphasis mine) and question whether the authors are really anarchists. I wonder if your anxiety over what is the correct kind of anarchism has kept you from critiquing what the writing actually says.

I am also an anarchist organizing around budget cuts at UW, and like Ariel and SK, I am disappointed and uninspired by this pamphlet. Of course I agree that liberation and not recuperation must be our ultimate aim and that we must be critical of the movements we participate in, especially since capitalism has shown a remarkable ability to absorb threats by co-opting them. Like the authors, I also want us to break out of our cages and upend the board!
But this pamphlet misconstrues the organizing at UW and makes an easy critique that borders on an attack of UW Student Worker Coalition (SWC) without asking the more difficult questions about what we should be doing in our organizing.
The authors fail to see the university as a workplace, and in doing so treat budget cuts organizing at UW as a "student movement." Yes, the university teaches students to be consumers of their own lives, but it is also a hella exploitative boss for many low-wage and immigrant workers on campus( and many undergrads and grad students like myself who have low paying campus jobs). Custodians were at the forefront of this struggle last year when they organized to stop cuts to swing-shift, and budget cuts organizing at UW continues to be a student AND a worker movement. We are fighting as workers, and when we are fighting for student demands, it is always in solidarity with and alongside workers! I recognize that this was a mistake and was not malicious, but it also shows me that the authors are probably not deeply engaged in organizing at UW. Both SK and Ariel's responses show why this oversight is so damaging: it masks the struggles for workplace democracy of already invisibilized workers and trivializes demands based on workers' material needs.
I also agree that SWC, as a student and WORKER coalition, is reformist in its orientation, if not to the extent of organizations that isolate students from workers or politely beg the legislature or administration for pittances. You're not telling us anything we don't know or aren't upfront about. But it's really, really easy to trash real-life organizing as reformist, and it's so much more difficult to figure out how we should instead be organizing towards liberation.
You start with relatively concrete (if somewhat inaccurate) critiques of the "student movement" at UW, and then you retreat into nice-sounding slogans that I mostly agree with but that are abstracted from the real struggles of students and especially workers. This is an easy out, and it enables the authors to trash our organizing work without ever having to go out on a limb and suggest (let alone organize towards) any alternatives. I'm not saying that short- and long-term "plans" for the revolution have to be filed alongside any critique of existing organizing work, but a piece that dismisses all budget cuts organizing at UW out of hand without suggesting anything else comes across to me as sectarian, arrogant, and a little bit lazy. Circulating a pamphlet like this one that is abstract when it's convenient isn't going to bust any cages--we need to engage in these hard questions and then organize around them.
Those of us committed to liberation continue to wrestle with these same questions about reform and revolution that you raise, but my answer and my strategy, at least for now and in this workplace, has been to organize around demands that are less than ideal but that, as Ariel says, allow us to "learn to work together, fight, and gain confidence in our own abilities" as we hopefully begin to destabilize "the capitalist rhetoric that budget cuts are inevitable and that managers know best." This may not be the best strategy, or our tactics around May 3 may be off. Like many of my comrades, I am open to critique because I care about building something powerful enough to topple the bosses and the rulers for good, and I don't pretend to know with certainty what that will look like. But I'm for engaging in a serious and sustained discussion in the spirit of building something better, not one-upping each other as "more radical" over the internet.
If this was intended to provoke conversation or reshape organizing, why isn't that conversation or organizing happening? If this piece inspires you, what exactly does it inspire you to do? Can we please talk about this?

I am an anarcho-syndaclist who organizes against budget cuts at UW with Student Worker Coalition. While I agree fighting budget cuts is a reform, I think it is an important opportunity to politicize campus and fight for direct democracy in the workplace and the classroom. I don't think there will be a place for the university in an anarchist society, but in the mean time I will fight for democratic control of my workplace.
I was at May 3 the whole time--I am the young white woman in red who was often on the bullhorn. Nobody gave me this pamphlet while I was there or approached me to discuss. I would have liked to discuss tactics on May 3 rather than after the fact on the passive aggressive medium of the internet. I mostly want to ask what the authors of this statement advocate in terms of organizing. This statement is pretty abstract (and I'm an English grad student so abstract isn't foreign to me) and don't know how I can translate a document like this into the organizing and agitating I do with my fellow grad students & the other campus workers I organize with. "Destroy work" doesn't seem that doable to my immigrant comrades with two or three jobs and families to support.
This conversation is continued in much more detail at: http://arcticcirclecollective.info/articles/8/what-we-demand-instead-is-life#comment

item.title: Communal queer veg*n house seeks three new roomies!
item.dc:creator: tsarina
item.content:encoded: Do you enjoy spontaneous cooking; throwing house shows and secret cafes; eating delicious vegan treats; Patrick Swayze and Keanu Reeves romances; playing top 40 ukulele covers; consensus-based house meetings and work parties; sunbathing on the porch; dumpster diving and living thrifty; building a vibrant, creative, welcoming and safe(r) space through living with a bunch of other rad folks? Three rooms/spaces in our gorgeous blue house in the Capitol Hill 'hood will be available by June 1st. Rent is in the 220-380 range, and utilities typically run 20-40/mo. We're especially looking for more queer, trans and genderqueer folks; folks of color; anti-authoritarian movers and shakers; as well as rad allies and people who are thoughtful about oppression and working on their own privilege. If you or someone you know is interested in checking out the spaces & interviewing, email parkranger [at] gmail [dot] com for more details!

item.title: Screening of "CRIMINAL QUEERS" at UW
item.dc:creator: tsarina
item.content:encoded: Friday, May 14, 2010 7:00 pm HUB Auditorium This event will be a film screening of Criminal Queers, which visualizes a radical trans/queer struggle against the prison industrial complex and toward a world without walls. Remembering that prison breaks are both a theoretical and material practice of freedom, this film imagines what spaces might be opened up if crowbars, wigs, and metal files become tools for transformation. Follow Yoshi, Joy, Susan, and Lucy as they fiercely read everything from the Human Rights Campaign and hate crimes legislation to the non-profitization of social movements. Criminal Queers grows our collective liberation by working to abolish the multiple ways our hearts, genders, and desires are confined. The film was directed by Chris Vargas and Eric Stanley. WATCH THE TRAILER!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This sounds great. I plan on being there.

item.title: TOMORROW MORNING: Courtroom Solidarity Needed for Stephen, Amanda Alice, and Charlie
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: <i>Three of the five people arrested at the April 9th demonstration against the police need your support tomorrow at their pretrial.  This is their statement:</i> Our Dear Friends and Supporters: Your presence at the court on Tuesday the 13th was hugely important to us. It felt powerful to enter that arena of law knowing that we had our posse in tow. As the last of us three had our bail papers signed by the bailiff, we all stood as one body, exiting the courtroom in a blatant expression of our solidarity. We also know that for every person who joined us that morning, there are another ten or twenty who supported us from afar. As our friends in Portland have said: “We believe this movement will be successful, and that the key to its success will be cooperation. We are strong together because our actions work well together, and we support one another.” We recognize the outpour of community as an obvious sign of our allegiance to the real work we must do for healthy and strong relationships. As those who were present already know, we plead “not guilty” to the charges thrown at us. But those bogus charges have been swapped around by the prosecutor, which is most likely an attempt to make them line up more consistently with the equally bogus police report, which we were able to briefly review. As of now, the misdemeanor charges against us are: Amanda Alice and Charlie: Assault and Obstructing an Office Stephen: Obstructing an Officer The prosecution seems to have taken away the Resisting charge from Stephen and applied an Obstruction charge to both Charlie and Amanda’s case. We continue to maintain our innocence in the face of these obviously malleable and arbitrary claims. The next step in the process is a pretrial which has been set for: 10am Monday May 10, 2010 Court 1103 (11th floor) Judge Holifield 600 5th Ave. Seattle, WA Court Info: 206.684.5600 We welcome you to the pretrial, so we can continue to meet in community and openly support each other during trying times. We request that all those who wish to attend dress and behave in a way that supports us by showing respect for the court. This will help us prove our innocence and the integrity of our characters. Also, we are working on returning the fees that our awesome support team paid to the bail bond firm, and we are planning many different parties and fun events in the near future. Keep an eye out, and spread the word! +++ Stephen, Amanda Alice, Charlie PS: We are keeping in our hearts and minds the other two people arrested on Capitol Hill on April 9, that they are facing much more harsh and arbitrary allegations than we are, and that they seem to be getting trumped up charges because of their status as minors. We hope that we can be in communication with them and we offer our support and love as much as possible during this struggle.

item.title: Anti-Prison Noise Demo in Tacoma this Saturday
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Saturday, May 15th at 2:00pm At the Pierce County Jail,Tacoma, Washington Meet at South 9th St. and South Yakima Ave “So prison is the ideal kind of death, because it eliminates en masse those whom society could only physically kill in very small numbers.” - Against Prisons Catherine Baker This noise demo is to show solidarity with all those on the inside. We see that the 36 supposed CRIPS charged under criminal conspiracy can be anyone of us. We see our struggle connected to the many types of actions that the state and capital take against people by imprisoning them. Read more at the Tacoma Anarchist Network blog

item.title: Several great shows tonight!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: Tonight there's several amazing shows at cool DIY spaces. First, The Greenhouse is doing their final shows series, and tonight is going to be a great event celebrating an end to a long tradition of putting on incredible shows at that house. Tonight's show features a few artists who have been a strong part of both The Greenhouse and the broader DIY community, and it's a perfect opportunity to join in and see a fitting end to a long tradition of amazing events. The bands tonight are: Orca Team (http://www.myspace.com/orcateamband) PWRFL Power (http://www.myspace.com/pwrflpower) Pill Wonder (http://www.myspace.com/pillwonder) Bryan Appleby (http://www.myspace.com/bryanjohnappleby) All-ages! Doors @ 8pm. Show @ 9pm. $5 suggested donation. The other undoubtedly amazing event tonight is at Healthy Times Fun Club, featuring the band Good Luck! from Bloomington, Indiana. They're a rare creature - full of technical skill and incredible musicianship, but still filled to the brim with earnestness and heart, making them one of the most exciting and captivating bands around right now. The other bands playing this show are also some of the finest that Seattle has to offer, so this show is really one not to miss. The lineup is: Good Luck: http://www.myspace.com/wearegoodluck or http://www.facebook.com/wearegoodluck Agatha: http://www.myspace.com/agatha206 A Million Years Ago: http://www.myspace.com/amillionyearsago Mega Bog: http://www.myspace.com/megabog Need directions? email healthytimesfunclub at gmail dot com.
