item.title: Live cooperatively! Sherwood seeks new roomates!
item.dc:creator: sherwoodcooperative
item.content:encoded: We are not always a party.  But we do live, grow, dance, eat, laugh and play together every day in defiance of a society that moves continually towards isolation and fragmentation.  Come live with us! We are a 14 person collective living in a big blue house in the University District. We live cooperatively, sharing the work, cost, and care of living together. We try to make our home a safe space, and to minimize the presence of transphobia, racism, ableism, sexism, homophobia and other oppressive language and actions.  We are striving to create an autonomous space free from oppression and fear! We value: -       sharing skills and knowledge -       critical discourse and discovery -       an awareness of one’s own privilege -       consensus-based decision making -       art and reclamation of public spaces -       breaking down hierarchies -       sharing vegan meals -       listening to and playing music -       bicycles -       growing our own food -       having monthly community potlucks -       activism We share nightly dinners (each member is required to cook twice a month).  Members contribute to our chore and house work system, attend two house meetings a month, and go on retreats twice a year. Our average base rent is around $450/month, with cost varying according to room size and location. There is a deposit of $700 (payment options are available). We share the costs of vegetarian and mostly organic food, mortgage, property tax, maintenance, utilities, local phone, and DSL. In total this costs around $150 in addition to the base room cost.  Total membership dues at this time range from $593-654. We have open spaces beginning in July and continuing through summer and fall! If you are curious about membershipping, please contact us at sherwoodcooperative@gmail.com. We ask that all interested members come to three house dinners, write a letter of intent, have a one-on-one conversation with a house member, and then attend a membership meeting.  Please only contact us if you are willing to fully participate in our labor and expense sharing system and if you are looking to stay for at least a year. We would love to meet you! - the Sherwood Coop For more information, check out our website: http://sherwoodcooperative.org/ *POTLUCK this Thursday at 7PM at 4746 18th ave NE.  Come hang out!*﻿

item.title: Bold Native screening in June @ NWFF
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded:
The fine local blog Vegan Score has posted this week about an excellent looking film that's going to be screened at the Northwest Film Forum in late June. Be sure to watch the trailer, attend the screening, and support these great activist filmmakers. See there original post here! "Ladies and Gentleman, another vegan-friendly event is headed our way: the Seattle premier screening of Bold Native, a film about animal activism in multiple forms, but made for everyone - activists, pacifists, vegans, animal abolitionists, omnivores, vegetarians, politicians, cyclists, Sumarians (ok, well, maybe not that many Sumarians). Everyone. All of us.

Those of us who avoid eating animals for the animals' sake are used to good documentaries on the topic: Earthlings, Peaceable Kingdom, Meet your Meat, The Witness, A Cow at My Table, etc. but this time it is different: Bold Native is a full length fictional dramatic film.



The topic of activists who are labeled terrorists by the US Government couldn't be more important, timely, or relevant to Seattle. Intrepid speaker and Seattle resident, Josh Harper, (who was himself sentenced to 3 years in prison for animal activism under the Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act), will hopefully speak or be available for Q&A after the film. Here is Josh talking about his experience before his imprisonment.



There will be an early screening at 7:00 pm and a later screening at 9:00 pm on Tuesday June 29, 2010. Each screening will include some Q&A with special guests. This is a rare opportunity to participate in dialog about activism, direct action, and the persecution (and prosecution) of activists by our government.

I like anything that brings together good art, thoughtful purpose, and real stories about people walking the walk.

You don't have to be an activist yourself to appreciate the courage and fortitude that men and women have shown by speaking out to change national and global opinions (and occasionally even change the law). You also don't have to be into direct action to enjoy a well made independent film, so invite you friends and lovers. There may be some other activities before and after the screenings, so stay tuned. We'll all have a good time.

Tickets are already on sale, so mosey your mouse here to buy some. Really. See you there.

Where: Northwest Film Forum
1515 12th Ave, Seattle, (between Pike & Pine)
Date: Tuesday, June 29, 2010
Time: 7:00 pm or 9:00 pm"

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: i am a proud Veggan and it keeps me fit and healthy;':

item.title: Silk screening workshop at Cairo & the Vera
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: I mentioned a few days ago that Cairo has been going silk screening workshops. You're in luck - another workshop is upon us tout de suite! Here's the deets: "Step-by-Step Orientation and Workshop that will prepare you to work in our new silkscreening studio. Workshop Wednesday June 2nd, from 7-9 pm. Cost will be $40, which includes 30 days of access to our studio to create your work!! Studio will have open hours Wednesday 2-6 pm & Thursday-Sunday from 12-6 pm. Once you've completed the workshop, you are then eligible to use the space. Once your initial month is up, you can take a break for awhile, or continue using the studio at a $25 per month fee. If you do take a break, you can rejoin at any time. In addition to teaching you how to use all of the equipment, your membership also gets you photo emulsion (one of the most expensive parts of silkscreening!!), access to screen emulsion cleaner (so you can re-use old screens), discounted equipment (such as screens, tote bags), and use of general silkscreening supplies (emulsion applier, squeegee's to apply ink, etc). What the studio offers: 1. Water-based ink, non toxic environment 2. Four Color Press 3. Exposure unit to create your own screens 4. Flash dryer to set ink on t-shirts 5. Pressure washer and utility sink (to use in cleaning and re-using screens) What the workshop will cover: 1. What makes a good image to silkscreen 2. How to Re-claim or Re-use an old screen (application of photo emulsion, and exposing of silkscreen) 3. Printing 4. Clean-up" ALSO!! The Vera Project has an amazing silk screening studio with affordable rates, quality equipment, and a lot of expertise with training burgeoning screeners. Visit their website (http://theveraproject.org/silkscreen/) to find out all the relevant details. I would highly recommend it.

item.title: Really Really Free Market TODAY at Pratt Park, 12-4pm! Wheeeee!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Is your freebox overflowing with recently unburied treasure? Are you doing your spring cleaning and have some weird/wonderful things you need to get off your hands? Are you in desperate need of some totally free clothes, movies, books, CDs, household goods, instruments, etc etc? Just as I suspected! Well, the Really Really Free Market (aka the answer to all your prayers) is really really happening today! the details: Come join us at Pratt Park (on 20th between Yesler and Jackson in the Central Area)! RRFM organizers will be there from noon to 4pm, but really it all depends on YOUR participation. This is how it works: bring your freebox! Clothes, movies, music, house goods, snacks, shoes, whatever else that you no longer need and think someone might be able to use. Why buy new things when there is so much extra stuff just floating around our community? Everything is totally free, bring what you don’t want anymore, take away new finds. At the end of the day someone will scoop up everything left over and take it down to be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. It’s like the biggest free box of your dreams! Look for us tomorrow, you’ll see picnic tables covered with stuff (or if it’s raining, look for us under the covered area. See you there!

item.title: skillshare at dancylvania
item.dc:creator: tsarina
item.content:encoded: once upon a time, we hosted a weekly craft night at dancylvania. eventually it turned into "craft & conspiracy", which was mostly just a couple of folks watching the x-files from the beginning. with many other projects and meetings and work and life, the gathering died out. we'd like to start it up again, but with more of a focus on skillsharing, and less of scully's delicious power pant-suits. (well, maybe we'll keep those.) maybe you've got fixing old electronics down, brew ginger beer, have some sexy spanish skills, want to spread wheatpasting tactics, or you make a mean risotto -- so share it! the first gathering will be monday, june 7th at dancylvania from 7-9pm. from there, we can pick a regular time that works for most folks, and decide how often it will happen, and the structure. if you want to know more, you can comment here or email dancylvania [at] gmail [dot] com!

item.title: To the future of The Black Lodge!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: The mighty-awesome folks at The Black Lodge, a really great DIY warehouse space, have just recently worked out a new deal with continuing their lease. However, this also means that they'll be responsible for fronting a sizable amount of cash to pay for structural work on their space. Please attend their shows coming up, especially any benefit shows. We'll keep you all up to date with any other ways of supporting them in the near future. Here's their statement from their blog: "Fellow Black Lodgers, Seattle musicians, and other counter culture patrons, As many of you know The Black Lodge has been in a state of uncertainty for many months. We have been unorganized, under stress, and most noticeably unwilling to book future shows. The reason for all of this is because our old landlord was trying to sell his lease, or as we call it, The Black Lodge. Why? Amongst other reasons we believe it is because there are some structural issues in this space that he wasn’t prepared to resolve. So began a long process of determining if we could, should, would take the lease. We were definitely not the only people considered for taking the space. We sat through several tours of other people coming through the space considering what they would do with it once they had it. Every day for months we had no idea whether we were going to be booted out or if we were going to be allowed to stay. After a long and stressful process we have obtained the lease for The Black Lodge, outright. Now we have to deal with these structural issues! With no middle man complicating the process you can expect a different attitude here at The Black Lodge. Over the next three years we will be renovating the space. We will also be seeking support from the community to help us in these efforts. We are in the beginning stages of creating a series of Black Lodge benefit shows. We are looking for bands and individuals to volunteer at these to keep the renovations on track. Thanks for all the continued support, -The Black Lodge-"

item.title: June 7 Countrywide Day of Action in Solidarity with Oaxaca
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: On June 8, anti-authoritarians and human rights activists are trying to break the paramilitary blockade of the autonomous municipality of San Juan Copala in Oaxaca. We need to support them to help avoid another massacre. In 2006, Oaxaca was the site of one of the most inspiring, important social rebellions of the decade. Between the brutal crackdown of the Mexican state and the constant harassment by paramilitaries, dozens of people have been killed and the rebellion was largely crushed, but parts of Oaxaca are still organizing their autonomy. For five months, the Triqui village of San Juan Copala has faced severe paramilitary repression for declaring itself autonomous from the Mexican state and the neocolonial capitalist policies it enforces. On April 27, paramilitaries attacked a convoy that included activists, anarchists, and humanitarian workers trying to reach the village to lift the paramilitary siege. Two people, Beatriz Alberto Cariño and Jyri Jaakkola, were killed and several were wounded. Beatriz, an indigenous Mixtec, was a long-time advocate for food sovereignty, community water management, soil conservation and indigenous autonomy. She directed the organization CACTUS (Centro de Apoyo Comunitario Trabajando Unidos). Jyri, 33 years old, was a Finnish human rights activist who had been involved in the Fair Trade movement and delivering humanitarian aid to Africa. On May 15, paramilitaries kidnapped and beat 12 women and children inhabitants of the municipality, who were later released. On May 20, paramilitaries assassinated Cleriberta Castro and her husband, Timoteo Alejandro Ramirez, who was the leader of the indigenous Yosoyuxi community within the municipality. Multiple indigenous, Zapatista, anti-authoritarian, human rights and other groups are calling for a second caravan to lift the blockade of the autonomous municipality of San Juan Copala, arriving on June 8. For this reason, we are calling for a day of solidarity actions the day before, on June 7, to create pressure and prevent another massacre. The paramilitaries work on behalf of the Mexican government and Mexican and international corporations invested in the area. They do the dirty work that provides the basis for state control and commercial investment. As comrades in Oaxaca go face to face with the paramilitary thugs, all the rest of us need to let the bosses of the paramilitaries know there will be consequences for more brutality. Call-ins or protests at Mexican consulates, visits to corporations invested in Mexico, counterinformation and direct action are all necessary. Because solidarity spreads or it dies. Decentralized Solidarity Actions on June 7: Against Capitalism and its Death Squads! For Indigenous Self-Determination! --anarchists and anti-authoritarians in Boston, Chicago, Phoenix, Portland, Seattle, Olympia, Tacoma and beyond. Para más información en español http://www.kaosenlared.net/noticia/oaxaca-mexico-nuevo-ataque-paramilitar-causa-dos-muertos-san-juan-copa for more information in English see http://elenemigocomun.net/ http://anarchistnews.org/?q=node/11159 A pdf flier may be downloaded here: http://arcticcirclecollective.info/file_download/10/oaxaca.pdf

item.title: Through This Window #002: "Unrequited Love" Out Now!
item.dc:creator: Through This Window
item.content:encoded: [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500" caption=""Kiss" by Brian Forrest, featured in Through This Window 002: "Unrequited Love" out now!"][/caption] Hi Seattle DIY community, I am SO excited about this new Through This Window installment, "Unrequited Love." I love it and hope you will, too. There are fully 35 things to look at, read, watch, and otherwise enjoy, many of them made locally. I hope you'll take some time and go through each of them! http://throughthiswindow.com Please pass the word on and share this project with your friends and families. We are a zero-budget local quarterly collaborative multimedia webzine that relies on word-of-mouth. I really appreciate your involvement in this awesome project/movement! While I've got your attention, I want to remind you to start thinking about sumbitting to TTW003: "So This Is Growing Up..." What does it mean to grow up?, growing up revelations, what milestones?, interview an old person in your life, messages to past selves, etc. etc. Please submit by 8/15 for a 9/1 release! Thanks again! Love, Zach. Zachary Gore Curator, "Through This Window" 206.437.3668 zacharygore@gmail.com info@ThroughThisWindow.com Through This Window A documentary webseries, webzine, and cooperative web-based multimedia project. http://www.ThroughThisWindow.com/ Become our fan on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/throughthiswindow

item.title: REMINDER: June 7 Day of Solidarity with Oaxaca Tomorrow!
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Tomorrow, June 7th, we will be gathering outside the Seattle Mexican Consulate (2132 3rd Ave. 98121) to show solidarity with comrades in Oaxaca who continue to be besieged by armed paramilitaries, and also to create a public awareness of the June 8th Bety Cariño and Jyri Jaakkola Humanitarian Caravan, which will attempt to break the paramilitary siege of the municipality of San Juan Copala and save the lives of the more than 70 families who are surviving under inhuman conditions. We seek to pressure the Mexican government to call off its paramilitary thugs, and to prevent another massacre. June 7th, Noon: Representatives from LELO will be speaking. June 7th, 1pm: Anarchist & anti-authoritarian rally. Background information, news & updates, and a documentary on repression and resistance in Oaxaca: http://elenemigocomun.net/ A leaflet to be handed out June 7th: http://arcticcirclecollective.info/articles/24/the-fingers-of-an-iron-fist An 8.5 x 11 flier promoting June 7th: http://arcticcirclecollective.info/file_download/10/oaxaca.pdf The original call-out: http://news.infoshop.org/article.php?story=20100601225740286

item.title: Friday? Confused?(!)
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
Well... you ought to be After returning from a brief trip and realizing that I'm behind on updating my schedule book, I decided to take some time to update it. item.title: We Are All Jaywalkers
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: On Monday afternoon, June 14th, Seattle cop Ian Walsh began harassing multiple young people attempting to cross the Martin Luther King Jr. Way without permission.   When two of the youth, both black women, refused to become passive victims of his verbal and then physical aggression, he responded by punching one of them in the face and then arresting both. Of course, no one is surprised.  Everyone remembers the recent stomping of a handcuffed Latino man by a white Seattle cop proclaiming, “I’m going to kick the Mexican piss out of you, homie.”  Or the murder of 7 year-old Aiyana Jones, shot in the neck by the heavily armed Detroit police in her own home. Or the beating of 15-year-old Malika Calhoun in a holding cell in November 2009 by Paul Schene—a cop who had shot and killed previously.  Or the public summary execution of Oscar Grant in Oakland, 2008. Continue Reading...

Here are a list of the locations: THE MEAT MARKET 1015 N. State Street BOOMERS 310 N. Samish Way CHAMP HAUS/SUPER MARIOS corner of Champion & Forest St. MARITIME HERITAGE PARK 500 W. Holly CABIN TAVERN 307 W. Holly BLOOM 1320 Cornwall Ave. ANKER CAFE 1424 Cornwall Ave. WHATCOM MUSEUM 250 Flora St. HONEYMOON 1053 N. State Street JINX 306 Flora St. Thursday 17th: 2:00-4:30 – MAKE YR OWN FASHION WORKSHOP @ The Meat Market (1015 N. State St.) - come make your own clothes to show off at the fashion show! bring clothes! bring paint! bring ribbons! bring scissors! bring stuff! bring fashion supplies! 5:00-9:00 – KICK OFF SHOW & POTLUCK @ The Meat Market (1015 N. State St. INVITE ALL YOUR FRIENDS AND MOMS! IT’S GOING TO BE GIGANTIC!

The June 14 incident in Seattle involving a white, male police officer physically assaulting two young women of color might be routine, but it is still disgusting and reprehensible. read more...

item.title: Bend-It Extravaganza 2010
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded:
Is June 24th- June 27th
________________________________________
This year of Seattle’s favorite radical free, queer and all-ages festival in June is more exciting than ever! On Thursday the 24th at Black Lodge (Eastlake & Republican) at 8pm we are partnering with the amazing femmes of F.U.S.S (Femme Unity + Support Seattle) for aQueer Carnival and Dance Party. On Friday the 25th in Cal Anderson Park on Capitol Hill we will have a “Queer Garden: Bands in the Park” with music starting at 3pm, followed by a screening of Travel Queeries at Dusk with local shorts. Friday music featuring The Redwood Plan, Hail Seizures, Black Letter Edition, Junk Bones, Cloudbustr, Council of Lions, Emma, and Christian Mailloux. Saturday the 26th will also be held in Cal Anderson Park starting with Big Gay Field Day at noon featuring personalized rubber ducky races, giant twister, hula hoops, and other fun favorites. Saturday evening we will have our Variety Showstarting at 6pm featuring ArtStar, queerbait!, Scarlett Vain, Dominique Eyesli D’Amour and more! And finally Sunday the evening of the 27th we will wind it down with“Unaccessorized: ‘Acoustic’ and Spoken Word” at 7pm at the Richard Hugo Housefeaturing S (Jenn Ghetto), charliesque, Heart Behavior, Shanay Salas, Henry Luke, young stay young (formerly overcome by the power of love), and more! The Hugo House is on 11thbetween Olive and Pine across the back-in parking from Cal Anderson. Don’t miss this festival of a lifetime!
All events are free of charge with free vegan meals.
If you have time to help out before or during the festival, contact us!!! We need lots of help for fliering and other outreach, food preparation during the festival, set up/break down, and other jobs. Come make it happen!
Bend-It is a queer artist activist collective that makes the world a more fabulous place by building welcoming, liberated spaces, strengthening community, and creating meaningful alternatives for queer people of all ages and their friends.

item.title: queers fucking queers dance party!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: pride weekend descends upon seattle. businesses bust out their rainbow flags and queers converge in bars, clubs, and beer gardens across capital hill. corporations trot out their special pride products, eager to stuff their pockets with money from another niche market. is this what queerness looks like - spending money and getting wasted? wouldn't you rather be celebrating with creation, rather than consumption? the bend-it festival is a fabulous example of this, with all ages music and more happening all weekend, but why stop there? people of all ages and identifications are welcome to join together this saturday night at midnight (that's saturday going into sunday) for a roving dance party in the streets! we don't need bars, booze, money, or ID cards to have fun. we are young, old, powerful, shy, sexy, smart, silly, and prepared to take what's ours. these are our streets and we'll play in them if we want to! wear your dancing shoes and bring your friends. see you at midnight! down with corporate pride! up with "queers fucking queers" dance party! saturday 6/26 at midnight! all ages and totally totally free! meet up at madison and union, on the sidewalk by of pony (not in the bar itself)! come and dance!

item.title: really really free market tomorrow (saturday)!
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded: Is your freebox overflowing with recently unburied treasure? Are you doing your spring cleaning and have some weird/wonderful things you need to get off your hands? Are you in desperate need of some totally free clothes, movies, books, CDs, household goods, instruments, etc etc? Just as I suspected! Well, the Really Really Free Market (aka the answer to all your prayers) is really really happening today! the details: Come join us at Pratt Park (on 20th between Yesler and Jackson in the Central Area)! RRFM organizers will be there from noon to 4pm, but really it all depends on YOUR participation. This is how it works: bring your freebox! Clothes, movies, music, house goods, snacks, shoes, whatever else that you no longer need and think someone might be able to use. Why buy new things when there is so much extra stuff just floating around our community? Everything is totally free, bring what you don’t want anymore, take away new finds. At the end of the day someone will scoop up everything left over and take it down to be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. It’s like the biggest free box of your dreams! Look for us tomorrow, you’ll see picnic tables covered with stuff (or if it’s raining, look for us under the covered area. See you there!

item.title: Benefit for Clyde Petersen (tonight!)
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded:
I case you cats haven't heard, our beloved badass friend, Clyde Petersen was burglarized two weeks ago and all of his $4,500 in essential filmmaking gear was stolen. Clyde doesn't have a real job and he gets by through making documentaries and music videos from his own film production business, Do It for the Girls, and from the occasional tour managing / band management gigs. So... TONIGHT! at 20/20 Cycle (2020 E. Union) at 8pm sharp, this mega-benefit will occur. This was put together the day after the burglary by Garrett, Amber and Forrest and we've all pitched in since to help Clyde with whatever equipment and gear he needs / needed to finish his badass documentary The Unspeakable (it's really good: covers some NW artists). Any monetary help that you (the reader) can provide is totally cool and more info is here at ourheartsbreak.com. Here's the line-up:

item.title: Radio! Radio!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: The Capitol Hill Seattle blog posted today about a pirate radio station on Capitol Hill called "101.9 The Whore" (apparently named after a male prostitute? Read the story for more details about this if-y name, which will soon change to "Spunk FM"), with the intent to play dance music and local community PSA's, especially focusing on the queer community here. It's cool to see a pirate radio station start to go "above ground," and although it looks like the FCC is already aware of them, there does not appear to currently be an imminent risk of the station being shut down. For more info, visit this message board thread. This brings to mind some work done by a collective in Philadelphia, the Prometheus Radio Project, who help disenfranchised communities start their own radio projects, and have been working on passing The Local Community Radio Act, which would allow communities to start their own low power FM stations much more easily. This bill needs only pass the US senate before going to Obama's desk! If this passes, this would be a huge boon to projects like "101.9 The Whore," any other pirate radio stations that would want to go above-ground, as well as projects like Hollow Earth Radio. Speaking of Hollow Earth Radio, they just met and surpassed their recent fund raising goal, and will now have more than $4,500 in their coffers to help them move into their new public community space next door to 20/20 Cycle in the Central District!! Huzzah!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The more people on the internet write about this guy, the faster that he will be shut down by the FCC. Geeze, why are DJs such attention seekers? Read the comments thread on the CHS post, and also this one:
http://westseattleblog.com/2008/02/west-seattle-pirate-radio-back-on-the-air
Bragging about something you are doing that is illegal is NOT DIY. I thought the punks would know enough about security cultue to not perpetuate this kind of thing.

item.title: court/jail support for fin and patrick
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: UPDATE: patrick and fin are out of jail! friends were able to bail them out yesterday evening, and celebrate. they will have a second appearance before the judge today, july 14th, at 2:30pm at the king county jail. they will either be unconditionally released, or receive their charges. thanks to everyone who came to jail, stood up during their hearings, pitched in on their bail, and brought patrick and fin home! two dear friends of the diy community, patrick and fin, were arrested late sunday night. they are being held in the jail downtown and have a hearing tomorrow, july 13th, at 2:30pm. the judge will decide if they can be released on bail. UPDATE: we're gathering outside the king county jail at 2pm! if you can, please come and support them - it's important to show the judge that patrick & fin do have a community watching. this page will be updated with information about their situation after the hearing. (and remember that folks arrested at the april 9th march have another pre-trial hearing on monday, july 19th at 10am in room 1103. hopefully it will be their last!)

item.title: Update: Jail Support for Fin & Patrick
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
Fin and Patrick are now being formally charged for Class C Felony level Malicious Mischief.  On Wednesday, July 21st at 8 AM we will be meeting outside of the King County Courthouse for court room solidarity.  King County Courthouse is located at 516 3rd Ave, and the arraignment will be in court room E1201.
Thanks to everyone who came out for the initial investigation, spread the word, made/dumpstered food, cleaned up, let them borrow bail money ( the returned bail is being issued as a check and mailed to the person who formally posted it, so it will be a little bit of a process to return it, but it will be returned hopefully by the end of the month), covered shifts, or offered help or solidarity a number of ways that might be unrecognized.  It is really inspiring to watch our community mobilize so quickly. I hope we are also able to engage in emotional solidarity with each other, finding ways to process and engage with stress so that we can keep this kind of support sustainable.

item.title: Submit Spoken Word Pieces for a Compilation!
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded: There's this great fellow who has the name of Ed Halliday. He has been wanting to receive submissions for a spoken word tape compilation for a few months now but so far only has one. He'd like more. In a nutshell, this compilation will be predominantly spoken word pieces that can have any assortment of accompaniment with it. Has anyone ever heard of a band called Kicking Giant? There's this absolutely brilliant spoken word song called The Town Idiot that is pretty much my favorite spoken word song / piece ever (aside from everything that I've seen Elissa Ball present as of lately). You don't have to be a band, established or recognized artist to do this. If you are thinking about submitting anything, you should probably just do it. This is a good thing. You can converse with Ed about this and submit material via his email zebrajones01@gmail.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you so much Kenneth!

item.title: New! Seattle Journal! Submit!
item.dc:creator: sequoiaaa
item.content:encoded: Out of the flaming wreck of the Ruckus collective, a new (and much more sexy) journal is emerging! This project is in its early stages and while some content has been gathered, much more is needed to fill this beauty out. ALL art/fiction/non-fiction/poetry/polemic is HIGHLY lusted after. We of this new project (tentatively entitled ENNUI) are more thorough and generally more dedicated than we were when Ruckus still was existent, meaning the end product will be some BOMB-ASS SHIT. We envision a magazine that strikes a balance - we sharpen our knives while still avoiding excess political dogma (we have a very low tolerance for activism), we promote the sexiness of our friends' forays and adventures, we think intellectual property doesn't roll easily off the tongue. This will be a quarterly publication at best, so submit while it's hot! Yer hot! Contact//Submit images and text to: thesedarkwings@riseup.net Let's get famous and buy diamond grillz. Srsly. Artio

item.title: Seattle (almost-) Secret Show!!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded:
"Hey there, So, this is sort of an extension of the Seattle Secret Show but rather than being sneaky, I'm just telling everyone where it is.
This Saturday we are setting up a really good show that will be taking place on the T-Dock on Lake Washington Blvd. For those of you who are unfamiliar with the T-Dock, it is just south of Madrona Beach. If you are into swimming, come prepared and we can turn it into a late night swimming party!
We have two bands coming all the way from Tejas (second biggest state!) to play for us. They are Wols (www.myspace.com/wolsies) and Golden Arrow Holy Face (www.myspace.com). I am really excited to see them and you should be too!
There are also two Seattle projects that will be peforming. They are both amazing and I think a perfect fit for this setting! They are Led to Sea (www.myspace.com/ledtosea) and Mega Bog (www.myspace.com).
This is going to be a really great show and since I am moving to Whidbey Island soon, this might be the last one of these I ever do. Come out, listen to good music in a cool setting and go night swimming! "
-if you're unfamiliar with the Seattle Secret Show series, here's a fun little paragraph detailing its origins and inspiration: "One of the things that has always made DIY shows special for me, is the use of unconventional spaces. I've always preferred to see shows in basements, art spaces, warehouses, etc. Something that I find a really exciting possibility is pushing the boundaries of where shows take place even further, reshaping the definitions of what a show is and where it takes place. I stumbled across the website for the Austin Secret Show (www.myspace.com/theaustinsecretshow) and felt like Seattle could really use something like this. With their blessing I'm using the same name. If you have any ideas for good, non-conventional places for shows to take place, please let me know."
Read more: http://www.myspace.com/theseattlesecretshow

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Benji, this is totally rad! Bear and I have talked about setting up a secret show at the (as it is known colloquially) Pagoda Park on Beacon Hill, across the street from House in the Sky. My organizing resources are stretched thin on Street Medics stuff and household/creative projects, but I'd love to see this go down! There's also a few other super-awesome parks that would be perfect for this, like Anarchy Point over by the Duwamish, and of course the bridge to nowhere. I wish I'd seen this post on Saturday, I hope the show and swimming were loooovely. Be well! -N*

item.title: BORN IN FLAMES: film screening 8/8
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: this sunday, august 8th, at the arctic circle: a showing of BORN IN FLAMES to support the seattle anarchist bookfair! 7pm snacktime, 8pm movie. bring a few dollars for the bookfair. BORN IN FLAMES takes place 10 years after a socialist revolution in the united states, where women are still struggling for jobs, health care, safety and autonomy. through the women's army and other radical groups, they begin to fight back. the growth and impact of the women's army is tracked by the socialist women's media and the feds, leading to the kidnapping of a prominent member. when she dies in prison, the splintered groups organize together and attack. meeeow! born in flames - trailer

item.title: seattle anarchist book fair - a call out!
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: the second annual seattle anarchist book fair is less than two weeks away, and a truly excellent mass of northwest radicals will descend upon the vera project. while the tables & workshop slots are full, the book fair is still OUR space. you don't need an invitation, but we'd like to give a gentle nudge and maybe a wink at yr capture the black flag, guerilla workshop, double-dutch, marching band, poetry reading, film screening, dance party.... this is yr call-out! the possibilities are endless! and if you'd like a more traditional way to participate, there are many volunteers needed to pull off a full weekend of radical fun. email or stop by left bank books to sign up.

item.title: Crisis in the Borderlands (Crisis en la frontera): Resistance In Arizona
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: Arctic Circle House (540 26th Ave S) Sunday, August 15th - 7 PM (reposted from Arctic Circle Collective) The situation in Arizona has reached a crisis point. Borderland communities, long under the pressure of an oppressive and violent border enforcement policy, have been besieged and attacked by a series of racist new state laws that seek to undermine the very fabric of our communities. New AZ State laws have mandated racial profiling (SB 1070), cut off access to social services for mix-status families (HB 2008) and targeted Raza Studies programs in high schools (HB 2281)  A new bill on the horizon proposed by State Senator Russel Pearce wants to get rid of birth-right citizenship for children of undocumented parents. These kinds of policies, motivated by deep hatred, seek to criminalize border communities and spread fear. Come join in a discussion about the history of US border enforcement policy, the continuing and increasing  raids under Obama and the growing resistance in Arizona. Learn how you can support border communities in resistance and help us build a movement for justice, equality and hope in direct opposition to border militarization, white supremacy and state-sponsored terror. Crisis en la frontera Arizona está en crisis.  Las comunidades ubicadas en la frontera, después de sufrir durante mucho tiempo la presión de una política fronteriza opresiva y violenta, han sido acosadas y atacadas por una serie de leyes racistas cuyo propósito es socavar la estructura misma de nuestras comunidades. La nueva legislación de Arizona exige la discriminación racial (SB 1070), corta el acceso a los servicios sociales para las familias de status mixto (HB 2008), y pretende eliminar los programas de Estudios organizados por La Raza en las escuelas secundarias (HB 2281).  Un nuevo proyecto de ley en el horizonte, propuesto por el senador estatal Russell Pearce, quiere suprimir el derecho de ciudadanía por nacimiento para los hijos de padres indocumentados.  Este tipo de política, motivada por el odio profundo, trata de criminalizar a las comunidades fronterizas y de sembrar pánico. Venga y únase a nosotros en una discusión sobre la historia de la política de vigilancia en la frontera de los EEUU, las continuas y crecientes incursiones de la administración de Obama y la resistencia cada día más fuerte en Arizona.  Aprenda cómo usted puede apoyar a las comunidades fronterizas en su resistencia y ayúdenos a constuir un movimiento por la justicia, la igualdad y la esperanza en oposición directa a la militarización de la frontera, la supremacía blanca y el terror patrocinado por el Estado.

item.title: Conspiracy Tour comes to Seattle!
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded:
In light of what's been happening in Seattle, this should be a great opportunity to learn more about state repression through grand juries and ridiculous trials...

Conspiracy Tour Wayward Cafe (52nd & the Ave/University Way) $5-15 donation for legal support; no one turned away for lack of funds.

This summer, the Conspiracy Tour is going on a whirlwind, month-long excursion across the continental United States to raise awareness of and solidarity for political activists from Minneapolis, MN who are facing severe state repression. Come join us in raising political support and much-needed legal defense funds for the RNC 8 and Scott DeMuth. It’s been alleged that the Tour will include a musical puppet show, a scintillating p...resentation on the charges the activists are facing, and various (some would say nefarious) ways you can join the Conspiracy to support targets of state repression. In addition to the usual perks of joining a conspiracy, co-conspirators will be learning ways to strengthen and protect their communities from future incidences of state repression. You know, just in case. Come find solidarity, strategizing, resistance, and community that the state could only dream of! This will be a roadshow to remember even before you read about it in your FBI file. http://conspiracytour.wordpress.com http://davenportgrandjury.wordpress.com http://rnc8.org

item.title: G20 Arrestee Benefit Show
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: G20 Arrestee Benefit show, August 21st 8 pm. All Ages $5-10. At the FBK 6272 Ellis South Avenue, Seattle, Wa 98108 In June of 2010 G20 leaders met in Toronto. Seventeen people where arrested who are now facing trumped up and politically motivated allegations including conspiracy. Many were targeted in the streets and for organizing events surrounding the G20, some arrested at gun point and pre-emptive raids.  Some of the seventeen people were infiltrated by two undercovers who had been organizing with them for the past year and a half.  These attempts by the state to control and deem certain individuals as terrorists by openly organizing, is to criminalize dissent and weaken our courage of acting as a community. Solidarity is a continuation of acts before and after arrests. We need to keep organizing and draw strength even in the face of repression.

item.title: Seattle Anarchist Book Fair - it's here!
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: While you're waiting in anticipation for the unofficial kick-off with the Conspiracy Tour, have a look at the awesome workshop schedule! Saturday, August 21st * 10:30 am Cristien Storm, co-founder of Home Alive and author of Living In Liberation: Boundary Setting, Self-Care and Social Change * 11:00 am Towards Queer Anarchist Theory * 11:30 am The Beehive Collective * 12:00 pm Anarchism & Science * 1:00 pm Squat Birth Journal * 1:30 pm Common Action: Recentering on People’s Movements: Especifismo in Action * 2:00 pm My Baby Rides the Short Bus Book Talk * 2:30 pm Uses of a Whirlwind Book Talk * 3:00 pm For Crying Out Loud: Survivor Support * 4:00 pm Social War: the beginning of a Stratagem of Conflict Sunday, August 22nd * 11:30 am Emma Goldman Finishing School * 1:00 pm Identity Politics: Tactically Inefficient * 1:30 pm NW APOC on Racism, Sexism, Homophobia Now in Anarcho-Radical Movements * 2:00 pm SeaSol strategy, tactics and movement building – How workers and tenants can defeat employers and landlords * 2:30 pm Common Action: Transformative Justice Skillshare * 3:00 pm George Jackson Brigade Discussion * 3:30 pm Seattle Street Medic Training * 4:00 pm One Big Union Book Talk The 2010 Seattle Anarchist Book Fair is August 21-22 at our partnered space, the Vera Project (Warren Ave N & Republican, at Seattle Center). Public hours are 10-5 on Saturday the 21st and 11-5 on Sunday the 22nd. We hope that our workshops and panels will be packed with folks from our communities engaging in discourse about things directly affecting our lives, whether it be strategies or tactics for resistance for putting theory into practice, or how to celebrate our creative passions. We think it is important to be cultivating our own ideas and art, projects and relationships, so that we aren’t lulled into complacency by Anarchist “experts” who have answers for us.

item.title: Cold Lake, Council of Lions (last show), Madonna Bangers (V,B.C.), Imperial Can (B, IN) TONIGHT!
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded: Of my favorite bands in the Pacific Northwest, two of them are playing tonight. Of my favorite bands from Vancouver, BC, there is also one of those playing tonight. This is Council of Lions' last show possibly ever. They played at Friendship City (RIP 2008-2009) in Bellingham with Knot Knocked up and another band that I can't recall at the moment. If my memory serves me right, either one or a combination of Jenn, Davy, Claire mentioned that they had been working on some songs. Everyone was all, like, "yeah, play for us" and they did. It was so great. It was the best. In about a year and a half they've become progressively more badass and still my favorite queercore / rock n' roll band in the Northwest. Seriously. I'm going to miss their unity and inspiration. Cold Lake's cassette EP release is also happening at that same show. WOW! They've been working on this thing since early this month and one of those days I got a call asking if I could download some software to recover a hard drive that crashed (after they already recorded 5 songs)! There's 9 songs on this cute-puppy, it's red, and it's rocked my face off since I listened to it whilst making breakfast both today and yesterday. The internet says that they're "cleaner than Prince's bathroom" and I hope and imagine that Prince has more than one bathroom (where would his guests #2?). Madonna Bangers is from Vancouver, BC. They're the fucking best. Last time they played in Seattle it was about a year ago at the Chai House (that RIP'n café in Ballard) and at the New Crompton. The New Crompton PA couldn't handle The King's (vocals) words and ramblins'. The Chai House PA could but that's not important. Imagine a bunch of "kids" in their early to mid 20's going on a "rock 'n road" trip to America, getting stoked on beer (which is very expensive in Canada), and totally rip dippin' the Chai House, then at some point before the show (or the next day) pooping in Lake Union and screaming "Corn Shark". I know barely anything about Imperial Can the than it's Ghost Mice Chris's new band on Plan-It-X and it's probably fucking rad. Also there's a puppet show, and it's Clyde Petersen's birthday party. Fuck yeah. 5113 Russell Ave NW (ballard) 8pm SHARP, $5-$10

item.title: Really Really Free Market TOMORROW! (Saturday 8/27)
item.dc:creator: bex
item.content:encoded:
The Really Really Free Market is here again!

Come over to Pratt Park (20th and Yesler in the Central District) between noon and 4pm. Bring what you got (clothes? shoes? furniture? books? food? anything re-usable!), and take what you want. No buying/selling/bartering. Just sharing resources and spreading the love. At 4, anything left will be donated to Lifelong AIDS Alliance. On a personal note, my house is relocating to Capitol Hill and we are getting rid of tons of clothing and other assorted goods. I can personally guarantee at least 4 boxes of quality free stuff. If you bring more, it will be like a party of freedom resulting in stylish new outfits for everyone. See you tomorrow!

item.title: friday anti-cop demonstration
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded: you may have heard about the brutal murders that happened yesterday and today by police in washington state (Seattle Cops Kill Again). with all of the work being done to quell anti-cop sentiment, a quick response to this news is appropriate. folks will gather for literature distribution regarding these two specific murders this FRIDAY 9/3 from NOON to 2 pm in front of seattle central community college, on the corner of broadway and pine. people are encouraged to make banners, signs, their own handouts/pamphlets, and respect a diversity of tactics regarding people's public response to these tragedies. this is a perfect opportunity to continue conversations regarding strategies for further timely community or individual responses to cop killings, as well as to find each other while addressing our rage at the police/state.

item.title: Cops Shot Six People this Week in the Puget Sound Region, Killing Five: Some Ways to Get Involved
item.dc:creator: arcticcircle
item.content:encoded:
It's been a week of disbelief. We all know that cops kill with impunity, but their recent spree has unfolded faster than we can even comment on it.

Posting articles on the internet is, by itself, useless anyway. In informal groups--around kitchen tables, in bars, at cafes, on buses, everywhere--our friends have all been discussing ways we should be responding to police violence. We hope you and yours have been, too. In the near future, we hope those conversations will move beyond familiar acquaintances into new alliances and communities. We can all help this happen by organizing our own discussions now, and attending upcoming events.

What will probably be a large protest of John Williams' murder is in planning. One local site set the date, but at the Seattle Times has indicated that the information was incorrect and a date will be announced soon.

Tuesday, September 7th there will be a vigil for John Williams at 5:30 at the corner of Howell and Boren--the corner where he was killed. It looks to be organized by the October 22nd Coalition.

And in nearby Tacoma:

Thursday, September 9th: Leaflet distribution and banners to share information about the recent escalation of violence by cops. Meet at 6th Ave and Oaks. 3-6 PM

Friday, September 17th: Anti-Cop Rally and March. Meet at People's Park at 3 PM

Finally, we'd like to suggest a little postering to get the message out into public spaces in our neighborhoods. Arctic Circle posters available for download have quicken become a little outdated with the speed of the cops' attacks, but here is a good general poster about police violence. Hopefully we can get some more Puget Sound centered materials up in the near future.

item.title: Sept 11th at Cairo: Alexis Gideon, Justin Clifford Rhody, Brain Fruit
item.dc:creator: Kenneth
item.content:encoded: This fair Saturday of September 11th, 2010 Cairo will have the fortune of presenting an outstanding multi-media performance presentation with enough pie to push plotted connections and flow yr bar chart. Show will start at 8:00 SHARP because Cairo's neighbors eat it raw. Be there at 7:30 Slide 1: Justin Clifford Rhody of (Friends and Relatives Records) transversed across multiple states from Bloomington, Indiana. He may throw matches, feces, hearts but rumor has it that he's just showing us a found film or soundtracked somethings. http://friendsandrelativesrecords.com Slide 2: Brain Fruit will be tantalizing ears so much that your higher processes will desire more glucose and sucrose BUT stay away from high-fructose, and lactose (provided y'r vegan or intolerant). During this time you will have already noticed that the room looks a bit different than most of your experiences at Cairo. That's because the room was transformed (or "installed") into bullshit via Slashed Tires. What an asshole. http://myspace.com/brainfruitmusic http://slashedtires.com/ Slide 3: Alexis Gideon puts devils into your brian. He conjures- ney- summons these devils to do his bidding though his warlockian guitar and "soundtracks" in a genre known as "witch-wave" (way cooler and more coherent than "chillwave". Sorry bros). These devils' dance moves send chills in such a way that it seems to only affect ye then... but beware of the night terrors brought to your brain whilst asleep. http://alexisgideon.com There will also be friends and hugs.

item.title: Habitat Restoration on Beacon Hill! Music, Trees, and Free Food!
item.dc:creator: EOS Alliance
item.content:encoded:
We would like to invite you to a community event that The Environmental Outreach and Stewardship (EOS) Alliance, in conjunction with 350.org, is hosting on October 10<sup>th</sup> in the Beacon Hill neighborhood. EOS Alliance and volunteers from other organizations such as: Landau Associates, Green Seattle Partnership, and Cascade Land Conservancy are planning a community event to celebrate the Maple School Natural Area and surrounding community.
Our event will feature free food, music, art, speakers and the continued restoration of the Maple School Natural Area. The Maple School Natural Area is a green space where EOS Alliance is currently conducting habitat restoration work on behalf of the Green Seattle Partnership. We want to create a community involvement for lasting care of the natural area and greater appreciation for the importance of healthy green spaces in Seattle.
Where: The Maple School Natural Area is located on: S 20th Ave. and S. Lucille Street
When: October 10th, 2010 10am-6pm

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great article on habitat restoration. We appreciate the information!

item.title: Call for submissions: "It's Down to This" Community Accountability zine
item.dc:creator: seattlediy
item.content:encoded: via Doris: community accountability zine call for submissions “It’s Down to This” is a new zine compilation that aims to give space to step back, take a deep breath and reflect on where we’re at. Reflecting on our experiences with community accountability processes, survivor support, or general efforts to cultivate community response to sexual violence- this is a space to talk about our experiences with this work, what we have learned, where we want to go from here, what we feel, what we want others to be able to hear, see, think about, engage with. It is an attempt to further give voice to our efforts and experiences in doing this work, to give space and voice to silence. To know and hear how we have survived in this work, how we have sustained this work, or why we burned out. To further document our attempts at figuring out what community accountability looks like, or what it even is. To be able to reflect and grow from our mistakes and epiphanies. SEEKING: stories, essays, interviews, comics, artwork and thoughts reflecting on working around accountability and community response to sexual violence: What has it looked like? What has it entailed? What could it look like? Who does it involve? In what ways? How is a community responsible? How is a community involved? What can an accountability process look like? What has it looked like? What works? What doesn’t? What were the fuck-ups, the successes? *These questions are asked with the assumption that confidentiality will be respected and that stories will not be shared if they are not yours to share. *The word ‘community’ is used with the awareness that it is often used problematically. Looking for submissions that: - explore the importance of accountability and support work as an act of community building and collective liberation, that express the importance of this work within social justice movements. -reflect on the support, empowerment, recovery and growth that have come out of this work -reflect on the pain, trauma and frustration of this work or which is inherent in this work. -develop ideas and methods of sustainability around this work -look at the social and political contexts in which community accountability and response to sexual violence and partner abuse grows and exists. -share our stories Anonymity and confidentiality will be respected. DEADLINE: October 22nd, 2010 For info and submissions contact: responsezine@gmail.com Feel free to send in ideas/proposals and ask for feedback!

item.title: New SeattleDIY.com coming soon!
item.dc:creator: Benji
item.content:encoded: SeattleDIY.com was down for quite some time (ok, like - two months?). We were taken down after we were infected by a virus, though it's uncertain where it came from or how we lacked the security to prevent the infection. Now we're back! But we won't be back to the same old website for long. We'll be revamping how things work on the site, taking stock of what exactly this website exists for (and for whom), how the community is included in its creation, content, and management, and how to make the website better fit the values that we've striven to uphold for so long. That said, important changes from this past year should be noted. This website is no longer run by a collective - The SeattleDIY Collective disbanded in early 2010, after having a solid run for 5 years of hard work. This past years I've taken a real back-seat approach to running the website and have been incredibly burnt-out on playing any kind of active role with it -- after nearly 10 years of paying for the domain and host, and being the sole person responsible for maintaining all the behind-the-scenes business, being its content editor, and building about 10 different versions of this website... I'm pretty done. SeattleDIY has been an important resource for the community here, and so it's work will continue. The website will be passed along to competent hands, and we'll continue to be an effective means for creating community, promoting awesome events, and making Seattle a better city.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Splendid article . Will definitely copy it to my blog.Thanks.
Wicked thanks for your work, Benji. For serious
